description:
Hole in the wall place hidden in an alley amongst the high rises of San Francisco Chinatown. Been to SF so many times before, but this is my very first visit here.  It was quite interesting as you can see how the fortune cookie is created. And I love me some fortune cookies!!!

When my wife and I went, there was a short line to get into the very small shop where we were greeted by a person handing out warm flat circular cookies (before it is shaped into a fortune cookie) for us to taste.  There were various fortune cookie flavors in the shop for purchase as it showcases capitalism at its finest in a touristy area.

Overall, it was a great experience just to see how fortune cookies are made by machine and hand.  It doesn't take too much time (maybe about 5 minutes if no line) so I highly recommend it!
author: Johnny N.

description:
Tiny location that's tucked away in a small alley.

If you've never seen fortune cookies being made, it's a treat to be able to see the machines and cookie-making process still done by hand.

Upon entering the cookie warehouse, we were greeted by free samples of large flat disk cookies (not folded into fortune shapes). There is a huge variety of chocolate dipped, plain disk, and folded fortune cookies that are boxed, bagged, and sitting out in the open ready to be packaged & purchased. 

I'm not quite sure how often the machines are cleaned, but I distinctly noticed that the cookies have a slight burnt taste to them. Still edible, but just a lingering after taste that stayed with me when I munched on my free sample. 

We purchased a bag of plain folded cookies. I also noted a slight burnt taste when eating these, even though I couldn't find any singed or burned coloration. So I can only assume it's radiating from the machines during the cooking process.

The lady who we talked to was really nice. After we made our purchase, she threw in another complimentary handful of more flat disk cookies into our bag. However, since she'd just handled cash with her bare hands before moving on to touch the unwrapped cookies, we weren't so comfortable eating these. Money is dirty after all, and we never know what germs get transferred!

Don't expect to spend too long here-- maybe 15 minutes if you're looking through all the merchandise for sale & observing the machinery and folding process. It's a nice place to swing by if you happen to be in the area, but I wouldn't make a special trip. Happy munching!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Tourist trap? Yes. My sister and niece wanted to visit here.  We were able to find the small location easily.

Inside we rounded the way of the store. Entering and looking around, we were greeted by a person with a tray of sample unfolded fortune cookie wrappers. It was a nice a flavor cookie.

After viewing the workers making the fortune cookies, you see the products to purchase.  My sister bought a bag of mixed coin cookies. When the sales assistant asked if she wanted a bag, my sister said No. But the assistant gave her a nice paper carrying bag and a handful of samples.  Love this place!
author: Marck N.

description: Cool little place to step in and check out if you're wandering around Chinatown. It's down a little alley and you could easily walk right by it! Inside, you're greeted with a sample and there's a couple people working with the machines cranking out cookies. They ask for $0.50 if you want to take a photo, there's a sign right near one of the workers with a place for change. I definitely didn't see it at first as I was intrigued with the fortune cookie making process. Also inside the little shop is a variety of fortune cookies for sale. They have chocolate ones, jumbo ones, frosted with sprinkle ones, some with adult fortunes, etc. One thing that wasn't clear to me was the ingredients, so if you have dietary restrictions make sure to ask!
author: Parker S.

description: Finally toured this place! After decades of traveling to SF finally made the time to do this and it did not disappoint. Make sure to bring cash as if you'd like to take a pic or video you have to pay. You can buy all options there with card. As the location is in a little alley, kind of easy to miss. Aside from regular fortune cookies they sell wafers (large and small) and white and milk chocolate dipped fortune cookies as well as mini fortune cookies and even colored options. We had a blast - great SF activity for kids!
author: Michelle T.

description:
Head down the alley. Follow your nose to the sweet and inviting scent of those cookies. Fast friendly service.  There was a small line and the lady brought us flat warm cookies to sample. Crispy crunchy and perfectly sweet.

It is a cute tourist spot with tasty cookies. They have a spot to give the people 50 cents if you take a picture. 

Definitely stop by this place. You can make your own messages for an extra cost if you want. They also have a giant sized version fortune cookie. Neat!
author: Keith F.

description:
Another amazing hidden gem of SF! I love fortune cookies and I'm so happy I got to visit this place.
They make fresh fortune cookies and you actually see how they make them/fold them. All the ladies were very kind, gave sample of their cookies-unfolded and they tasted like fortune cookies!
I of course grabbed a bag full because they are so addicting!... also took home a giant fortune cookie.. so cool!
author: Maricel J.

description:
Amazing little tiny hidden gem
Lines start to form a little before they open 
The little ladies are amazing making these fortune cookies 
-you can make your own personal label 
Just fill in the paper and hand it to the ladies making the cookie with a box 
It's a buck to make one and if you get two cookies it's only $2.00
-the fresh coin cookies are so warm and perfectly sweet. Super yummy! 
The also make chocolate, dipped, sprinkles and green tea fortune cookies
author: Koi S.

description:
This was the Best San Fran trip ever, our last stop before we left Chinatown, Golden Gate Fortune Cookies, recommended by my cousin. So Grateful for family in SF. 

You're in for a treat because you can get a sample and Golden Gate Fortune Cookies specializes in Fortune cookies, in all different sizes, flavors, and you can create your own fortune and you can even get the fortunes in x-rated version.

I am not a fan of fortune cookies until my visit here, I would not have know this tiny Alley is the home of San Francisco's best fortune cookies. It looks like just an alley to me, walking in this alley to get to Golden Gate Fortune Cookies. 

Here are some facts about the famous Golden Gate Fortune Cookies: 
-All kinds of fortune cookies at this tiny alley
-shop is only 1,000 square feet
-Only 3 employees are working at a time
-They make about 15,000 fortune cookies a day
-The only place that makes their fortune cookies by hand
-Using a machine from the 1950s 
-Fortunes were written decades ago by a mysterious professor
-Flavors or Fortune cookies, chocolate, vanilla, & green tea
-Fortune cookies were invented in San Francisco's Chinatown

After my visit here, now that I know, I've learned to appreciate the fortune cookies more esp. after getting them with my Chinese take out. It was a great learning experience, seeing how the fortune cookies were made. We bought 10 bags because of the buy 10 get 1 bag free promotion. It sure was a nice treat to bring back home to Hawaii. I especially enjoyed my fortunes and I couldn't stop at eating just one, I ended up eating about 10. Did I mention, that the fortune cookies taste so fresh?!
author: Judy C.

description:
Another tourist trap, but definitely a must -see/visit place if it's you're a first timer, like the bf and myself. It's a fun and unique experience :)

The entrance to the place is located in a small Alley way, which you could easily miss. As you can see, there was a decent line forming, but it shortened pretty quickly. Inside, was a small 2 person fortune cookies- making operation, as well as a couple of cashiers ushering guests along and stacking products where you can see how it's all made. I did not see nor hear them request change for pictures, but then again, everyone in line with me purchased something, regardless. We also got ample amounts of samples while waiting in line. 

What we got:

Write-your-own-message Fortune Cookie 
      1 for $1.50 or 2 for $2 of their fresh plain fortune cookies. I'm not going to rate these as it's a fortune cookie.. XD 

Box of Tri-colored Fortune Cookies
      It was a gift for my family members, so I couldn't say what flavors they were, and honestly didn't mind not knowing what the flavors were as it didn't seem too crazy, anyhow. Although they do offer wild, chocolate drizzled flavors, I'm a simple gal, so I opted for more traditional flavors (I'm still assuming here... Haha) I ended up trying  the red and green once the recipient opened it, and my best guess would be strawberry and matcha. The flavors are very mild and just as good as the plain flavor.

I don't see a need to come back as I don't crave fortune cookies, but I can see the intrique of visiting such a place if you're touring SF Chinatown.
author: Christine H.

description: All tourist need to get in line and buy a bag of Fortune cookies here. They usually give out free samples and providing a quick tour of the factory for the kids. We purchased the flat disk cookies.
author: Roy A.

description:
Yes, it's very touristy, but it's fun. You can pick up unique (highly overpriced yet) very affordable souvenirs here.

Souvenir Recommendations
#1: You can write your own fortune, and they make fortune cookies for you. They even put them in a small Chinese takeout container. $1.00 for one fortune cookie; $1.50 for two cookies (a box included in the price). Reasonable price, and a fun gift idea. 

#2: You can find fortune cookies you can not find anywhere. They have chocolate-coated fortune cookies, ones with milk chocolate, ones with white chocolate, with sprinkles and without sprinkles. These are expensive: $5.75 for a container of 6 cookies. They also have fortune cookies for adults (X-rated fortunes).

Last but not least, you can try fortune cookies while they are still warm (free). Don't dismiss it because it's touristy or stupid. I'm sure you'll enjoy it.

******************************
If you found something useful in my review, please hit "useful" so that I can improve my reviews. If you love food and traveling, follow me, or better yet, let's become friends on Yelp! Thank you and happy Yelping!
author: Masanori D.

description:
This was a nice little stop on my trip into Chinatown today, though I was expecting more of a "tour" when I read about the tour of the factory. It was merely stepping into the establishment, seeing them make the cookies right there, and tasting samples they provide.

The variety is nice, the atmosphere is fun, and it was definitely worth the stop overall. I would recommend taking a peak at what they have to offer.
author: Chris D.

description:
You really don't know shizz about fortune cookies until you've tried the real deal at Golden Gate Fortune Cookies.

Thin, light and crispy, as they should be. 
Delicate and yummy without that artificial aftertaste you'd find in other fortune cookies (sorry Panda Express....but I do dig your Kung Pao Chicken though!).
Avail in different flavors (chocolate, green tea etc) and sizes. They even have an R-rated version for those wanting some dirty fortunes. 

I can eat a whole bag of their originals in one sitting, it's that good!

35 cookies for $6.25, get it!
http://bit.ly/2CsTjyf
author: Cin T.

description:
This place is awesome! Who doesn't love fortune cookies?! 

While some people may not, I have to say I do, and I sure went far and wide to find them lol. J/k My friend found this place and brought me here, which really made my weekend!

For some reason, fortune cookies have always had a special place in my heart. Maybe b/c of their positive or nonsensical messages, and my curiosity to know what is in store.

Whenever I come across them in a store, I just HAVE to buy them... and here, I might've bought the entire store if I knew I didn't have to  get back on the plane to fly home. 

This place carries a variety of fortune cookies in almost anything you can think of, flavors such as original, strawberry, green tea, and chocolate. Some have chocolate and vanilla swirls, others are completely dipped. There's even a giant fortune cookie for $6.50! Go big or go home!! I chose to go home... with a variety bag for $5.95 lol

I didn't get any samples while I was in the small factory, but the older man was very nice and pleasant. They can even customize your order to your liking! How cool is that?

When I came home, I noticed he had thrown in a ton of complimentary flat round cookies. They were more crunchy than my variety pack. 
If you're wondering, all the flavors were pretty good except for the green tea. My favorite was the STRAWBERRY.

I will definitely drop by again when I am in the San Francisco area. If you haven't been here, come in and check it out! It's old school, with a few hard working Chinese women folding fresh cookies from the machine. 

Happy eating!
author: Mary D.

description:
This is a cool stopover in Chinatown. If you don't pay attention closely, you'll miss it! Thankfully, when I came here with my friends, there were lots of people stopping on the sidewalk devouring their fortune cookies. I've heard about this place before and my curiosity lead us down Ross Alley...

It has a narrow storefront but the actual space inside is big enough to house the fortune cookie machinery. The line was out the door when we arrived but it moved quickly. We saw how the fortune cookie machine worked and there was a nice man giving out samples of freshly made fortune cookies (flat, and not shaped) to those in line. The cookies were warm, crunchy and pretty darn yummy. There were fortune cookies left and right- matcha flavored, strawberry flavored, chocolate dipped with sprinkles, and most notably, the giant fortune cookies that sat on the machine. 

It was a great experience to not only taste fortune cookies but see the whole production process even if it was less than a 2 minute tour. Kids and adults will love it. And the fact that there's a variety of fortune cookies to gobble up on your way out makes it even better.
author: Cassandra P.

description:
Fun Fact.... did you know fortune cookies were invented in California?  They say it was first made in San Francisco or Los Angeles, depending on who you ask.  I vote.... San Francisco :)

If you want to see how fortune cookies are made, Golden Gate Fortune Cookies is the place to go!  This little shop is tucked away in a small side street in China Town.  Pay attention or you might just pass it!  That's what happened to me anyway.  Haha.  

You walk in and you have all your fortune cookie choices on your left, neatly displayed on the metal shelving.  To your right you may catch them packing the fortune cookies into containers or bags.  Take a few more steps forward and you will see the fortune cookie machine dispensing the batter on little hot plates and the workers pulling the cookies off, putting the fortune in, and "bending" it into shape while it's still hot/malleable.

You'll notice the big signs that say you must pay 50 cents to take photos or is it for each photo?  I'm not sure, but if it's for each photo, I owe them a 'fortune' ;)  I just bought a container of cookies as a gift for friends and the girl didn't charge me to take photos.  She also took some freshly made cookies out of the bin and was giving them out with purchases.  This was a nice treat and the fortune cookies are actually really good!  They're light, crunchy, & just the perfect thickness.  They come in different flavors as well like matcha and strawberry.  They can also make custom cookies for you and make humongous ones for special occasions (proposal idea, maybe?).

All in all, it's a fun quick stop that should take no more than 15 minutes.  I wouldn't go out of my way for it, but if you're in the area -- go!
author: Maria P.

description:
My boys' LOVE fortune cookies and are always asking for them. My parents tried buying some for them in LA Chinatown but they were stale. 

I thought it would be fun to take them to the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie factory for freshly made cookies. It was only a short walk from our hotel, hidden in one of the many alleys in Chinatown. They had chocolate, matcha, and chocolate covered fortune cookies. The factory is tiny and cramped and difficult to decide what to buy so we just bought a big bag of plain ones. 

The samples were warm and yummy like waffle cones. My son kept trying to help himself to more but when we bought a bag the lady threw in handfuls of samples.

We will definitely be back and I might get a bag of adult/x-rated ones next time...
author: Christina W.

description: Small cookie shop with different varieties which include matcha, chocolate, and regular flavors. You can also have the option of writing your own fortune. Fun touristy place. Located inside an alleyway.
author: Windy M.

description:
This is a fun stop while in Chinatown in San Francisco. You can pop in and see people assembling fortune cookies. There isn't a tour or any explanation, you just stand there for a couple minutes and observe. Don't be taking pictures if you aren't buying anything. I mean...it's just not good etiquette. And it's an incredibly tiny area for consumers to walk in, shop & stand so do your thing then kindly roll out.

I ended up buying a couple bags of fortune cookies to bring bag to people. Many are broken in the bag but it's so darn cheap and you get such cool flavors (regular, chocolate, strawberry and green tea! Plus if you buy a bag, they are totally fine with you taking photos and chilling for a couple minutes. I also bought some chocolate covered fortune cookies which I intended to bring to my Yelp Chicago coworkers...but...I ended up eating them all. I'm a beast and I needed all the good luck I could get! Puhaha Sorry team.

They even let you write your own fortunes for people for $1 each. I mean....everything about this stop is super unique and super cheap! It makes for a great souvenir to bring back to people for some funsies. I loved it and recommend to anyone to pop in while in Chinatown. You don't need to allow more than 15 minutes at the absolute max.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Come here to meet the fortune cookie of all fortune cookies. Yes. They sell GIGANTIC FORTUNE COOKIES. 

Located in an alley within SF's Chinatown, I opted to Uber and get dropped a couple stores away. I was on a mission. 

So heres the story: friend wanted to surprise the girl hes dating and ask her to be "official"...and I was basically the fortune cookie bearer. So I wrote two notes, the typical cheesy jibberish guys say, and had the lady mold them into the cookies. At $1.50 a pop, you get a takeout box complete with your two fortune cookies and whatever slips you choose to include. 

So I did that and bought a box of fresh cookies (they have strawberry, green tea, chocolate, chocolate dipped, and plain) for $5~. Lots of positive feedback from my friends who got a taste..."it melts in your mouth" "the best fortune cookie I've had"....great! 

The ladies were friendly enough. Don't expect them to welcome you with open arms. Sample were offered and more thrown into my bag after I paid.
author: Shirly C.

description:
If you are a fan of fortune cookies, you must come to this gem in Chinatown. You'll know you're getting close to the location when you start smelling delicious warm cookies.

Don't let the fact that you will not be going on a tour and that there is a lot of people crammed into a small space discourage you from visiting. What you will experience is a quick view of how the cookies are made, taste samples of the cookie while they're still piping hot, and buy some custom cookies with personalized notes.

Your visit will take about ten minutes, and will be well worth it.
author: Melissa P.

description:
Have you ever been disappointed with the fortune you get stuck with after cracking open a fortune cookie? Well not anymore! Because you can write your own fortunes here! 

So glad we stopped by this little fortune cookie shop! There isn't much room inside because it's wall to wall fortune cookie heaven. You can even buy a gigantic fortune cookie if you have enough people to share it with. They even have fancy chocolate dipped or matcha flavored fortune cookies. We just wanted to make our own fortune cookies. You just jump in line and write down your fortunes. Grab a little mini Chinese take out box hand it to the lady. She will pull a fresh cookie off the line and she will slip your fortune inside. Great souvenir to take home! Super cheap $1.50 for 2 cookies or $1 for one! Comes with a cute little Chinese take out box to keep your fortune cookies safe for the trip home.
author: Karen H.

description: Awesome place! You can come see how the cookies are made in person! Samples are available as well!
author: Dexter C.

description:
Walking around Chinatown, we walked by Golden Gate Fortune Cookies.

Decided to stop by. The lovely smell of freshly baked fortune cookies caught our senses. It's a small store but filled with so much yumminess. They have different kinds of fortune cookies. We picked a mixed bag of chocolate and original. They were super fresh and tasted so different than the fortune cookies we're used to getting at restaurants. I love how you can watch how these cookies are made. They have this down to a science. 

A must visit if you're in Chinatown.
author: Kimberly J.

description:
Had to use my GPS to locate this place, it's hidden down Ross Alley in Chinatown. Super small place, everyone takes turns entering and exiting. When I arrived there were only a few people in the shop. Walking in you are greeted by a gentleman with a hot fresh flat fortune cookie. A nice sweet treat as you check out the packaged cookies to go. 

They had two machines in full force pumping out so many fortune cookies, very interesting to see how fast the ladies fold these things. Pictures are allowed but they do ask for a 50 cent donation. Worth it to get up so close and personal. A must stop when you are in Chinatown!
author: Kelly S.

description:
As a tourist of San Francisco and someone that is easily amused, coming here was pretty enjoyable. My friends were locals and I had asked them during lunch if the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie Company was anything out of the ordinary, and she replied that while it wasn't, it was the place to take tourists. We walked down this small alley in Chinatown and the walls were filled to the ceiling with pictures of celebrities that had graced their presence there. 

Their most valuable customer must've been Clay Thompson because not only did they have his picture framed on their wall, they had a mural of him as well. They had fancy looking fortune cookies, green tea fortune cookies, fortune cookies that were flat and not yet folded into their signature crescent shape, and they even had a bag of "adult x-rated" fortune cookies.  Being the adults we are, we purchased the bag of the x-rated variety... but they were not x-rated. It was more confusing. I would recommend skipping this and just buying the regular kind. 

The fortune cookies itself were actually really tasty and chewy... not at all like the kind of fortune cookies that are free at Chinese restaurants. It's a fun place to visit if you've never been and there's even a lady who folds them right in front of you to perfection.
author: Linh N.

description:
A solid four stars for Golden Gate Fortune Cookies but one star deducted due to the unfriendly girl who was managing that day, handling all of the sales transactions|payments & the rockhard, stale purchase I made.

GG Fortune Cookies is nestled in a random alley located off of Ross Aly in SF's Chinatown. Be advised that the bakery can easily get overlooked so take your time navigating and keep a look out for a random cluster of people in the cuts. When you arrive, you are immediately slapped with the amazing sweet aroma of the cooked dough- Y U M!

The establishment is pretty small in size so don't come here assuming your getting a grand tour of how fortune cookies are made. You stand in line, brushed up against a wall of products for sale and a rope barrier to separate the exit path. This is not the place for you if you are claustrophobic. 
You basically stand from afar, watching the employees turn thinly baked circles of dough into the infamous crispy cookies filled with a paper fortune.

I highly recommend purchasing of the regular fortune cookies and fortune cookie wafers. These come in a number of options: plain, dipped in chocolates, topped with sprinkles, green tea flavored, chocolate flavored, 
&|or strawberry flavored.

FYI: Do not waste your money purchasing the Giant 
Fortune Cookies!! Although they look enticing & the concept is pretty cool, the actual pastry itself is terribly stale, rock hard, and even the two regular-sized  cookies nestled inside were terrible tasting. Needless to say, these went into the trash.

Ultimately a good spot to come, see, and experience but the customer service from the management standpoint needs improvement. Other than that, the cookies are absolutely delicious!!!! Stop by and snag a sample....
author: Ter L.

description:
fresh and yummy cookie that our kids enjoy. those sample is warm n best i have had. 

also green tea and stawberry
author: Kevin C.

description:
This is where the fortune cookie was invented, and such an underappreciated and almost forgotten history of where these morsels exist in SF Chinatown. What a hidden gem and if you like eating fortune cookies- you must come here. One of the few factories that make fortune cookies from scratch with little use of machinery. Their recipe holds true in taste, food history and culture of SF Chinatown, and Northern California.
You can even buy a bag of their misfits fortune cookies- warm, memorable and an awesome experience.
author: Jade M.

description:
When visiting historical Chinatown in San Francisco, Golden Gate Fortune Cookie Factory is a definite "Hidden Gem" for places to visit on anyone's itinerary list. 

Reason I say "hidden" is because of its location. There's an alley called Ross Alley that leads you to this place and its away from the main street where it can't be seen. I say "Gem" because once inside you could see people on desks working their magic, making fortune cookies from a machine. At a quick glance, I saw a little bit of the process. They would flattened the cookie cake with a presser machine then fold them into shape laying them on a baking template sheet.

The only thing I purchased here was a mixed bag of commonly known vanilla, green tea, and strawberry flavors for $2.75. You can't really expect too much from these fortune cookies, unless your fortune comes true later on after reading the paper messages inside, but the texture quality was good. They were simple, light and crisp. Surprisingly, I did like Strawberry flavored fortune cookie, it had a light hint of berry in it. The Green Tea flavor tasted like it was made from Matcha Powder. My family and I had fun munching out the entire bag which it had about ten pieces. The manager of the store was nice enough to give us a sample or two of regular flattened fortune cookies. 

Either you're a local or a visitor outside the city. It's an ideal place to buy souvenirs treats from this shop.
author: Jon B.

description:
Fun little stop if you're touring Chinatown.

It's located in a random alley, but most likely you'll find people waiting outside to get in. It's a small shop with little walking room.

They have employees making the fortune cookies right as you walk in. I assume that was the "tour", but it was still interesting nonetheless. 

They make several different flavors of cookies. You can get an assortment of green tea, strawberry, chocolate, and regular..or you can buy one of their chocolate dipped boxes. 

On the day we went, one of the dads was yelling at his daughter. A little awkward being in their as a customer.

Free samples of fresh coins when you go in!

Worth a stop if you like fortune cookies.
author: Berna T.

description:
Are you a tourist? Do you like to flock to the most touristy spots in the world that are crawling with other tourists, their cameras, and a long line? Are you cool being charged 50 cents per photo you take of someone sitting and pulling fortune cookie flats off the grill, folding and stuffing them with a little piece of paper? Then this is the place to go! 

In all honesty, this place is pretty interesting. You can see fortune cookies being folded live and in the flesh. A little on the pricey side for flour and eggs, think $4.50 for a bag of small unfolded wafers, but there are some great gifts/souvenirs here such as the large fortune cookies, chocolate covered ones, and even flavors like green tea, chocolate, and strawberry. 

Pro-tip: cash only.
author: Alison A.

description: Interesting cookie shop, hidden in the alley. Fresh and affordable, Golden Gate is my favorite bakery in San Francisco. Yummy It is often necessary to wait in line and I suggest people to get there when the store almost close:)
author: Yingying C.

description:
This is a must buy snack, we have been here for few times. It's not crowded at all. We were able to buy few packs of fortune cookies to home. We bought some flat shape and also fortune cookies. Their fortune cookies taste way a lot nicer than others. It has more flavorful. And they seems like have been more creative, has strawberry, green tea, chocolate and other flavors.

The staff was nice and gave us some samples. The price of the packs weren't expensive, still depends on what kind of flavor or shape you like. My sister always wants to come here and get a lot of fortune cookies. She enjoy by reading the notes from fortune cookies.
author: Jaane F.

description:
VERY RUDE!! We were there Saturday and the young owner started giving out samples pushing his way through the people he got very angry at customers very crass and rude, people felt awkward and uncomfortable, and when we went in the store, he was yelling and shouting and abusing to one of his employees in English and Chinese. The place is not worth it, not worth the wait and to expose little kids to such abusive behavior from an ignorant owner. 
There are two elderly ladies making the cookies very afraid whenever this manager walks by them. Terrible atmosphere and there is not much to see the place is a room of 15 ft x 20 ft and 20 people cram in there all the time.
author: K J.

description: What a cool spot to check out also you can design your own fortune cookie for one dollar or for $1.52 and they get their own personalized box different flavors and they also let you try samples. You're coming to San Francisco for a visit or you live in the area this is a great spot to see also to bring your children or to even create a special gift for a holiday I love how you can purchase fortune cookies standard or have them hand made right there with your personal message inside
author: Shannon S.

description: Yes it's down a little shady alley where a loose Chihuahua may be hanging out but worth it!  We stopped in twice- once before lunch and after.  There was basically no one there before lunch but packed after so time it wisely. I have never been to a fortune cookie maker before.  What a great idea to show people just how they are made!  I can say it wasn't what I expected but I appreciate fortune cookies much more now that I have seen that each one is hand pressed!  Also... make your way to the front of the viewing area and take the $1 or $1.50 to create your own fortune cookie (on your left!)  Write a message, watch it be inserted and collect your 'to go' box! Pretty cool, quick little adventure.
author: Holly W.

description: Super fun to see how fortune cookies are made. They charge .50 for a photo but if you buy something they give you a few extra warm cookies.
author: Christy R.

description:
This is one of those hidden gems tucked away in an alley in Chinatown. You can watch the women insert the paper fortune in the cookie and hand fold them.
They make flat cookies sold for $4.25 and assorted green tea, chocolate and strawberry flavored fortune and flat cookies.
I always make an effort to stop by when I go to San Francisco.
If you have friends coming to visit I highly recommend you take them here.
author: Janet I.

description:
Such a fun stop. Don't plan on needing to spend more than 10 minutes in this charming hole-in-the-wall! This is the real thing - a part of Chinatown history ignored and unappreciated by most tourists. 

P. S. You may discover that all other fortune cookies are horrible compared to these. And that warm fortune cookies are DA BOMB!
author: Jennifer B.

description:
This is a classic place in Chinatown tucked into the alley. You can watch the ladies folding fortune cookies right before your eyes...  Also, take some home with you, and they will throw in a few freebies of the reject cookies that aren't able to be folded. 

It's fun and I hope that they will stay there for a long time.
author: Betty Y.

description: The cookies are loaded with butter. If you are lactose intolerant or do not like the taste or smell of butter, be forewarned. There is no listing of the ingredients either on the package or on the website. Emails get returned and phone messages unanswered
author: Mark C.

description: I have eaten many fortune cookies, and never really thought about how they were made. At this place, you can see it all - even the fortune being inserted into the cookies. A perk is that you can sample, and more samples are included in your purchase. My family brought home the mixed box - regular, matcha, and strawberry flavors, and were fans of them all.
author: Natalie N.

description:
I am not a lucky duck...well, sometimes I am and sometimes I'm not.  I had been on one of my unlucky streaks and therefore decided that a trip to Golden Gate Fortune Cookies was in my destiny.  Perhaps it was placebo effect, but after leaving this little factory, I felt that my luck-o-meter had increased ever so slightly.  Warning: the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie factory does not guarantee increased luck to any of its patrons; just as beauty is in the eye of the beholder, so is luck.  As I've been told - you make your own luck in this world, and that's why they let you do just that right there in the factory...one of the best things about this factory/store is that for just $1 you can write your own fortune and have it placed in a cookie that is made right in front of you.  So, quite literally - you make your own luck.

Although I was excited to buy bags and bags of fortune cookies, I was most excited to write the fortunes!  I wrote the fortune for my fiancé whereas he wrote one for me - the fortunes were then placed within the cookies, boxed up and gifted to us.  If you can practice self-control and you want to bring a neat and cheap souvenir to family and friends back home, come here and write fortunes for your loved ones!  It is a gift that is cost-effective, thoughtful and worthwhile - when will you ever run into another fortune cookie factory?  Make sure that you also buy yourself some cookies, in fact - buy yourself a couple bags of cookies.  The flattened cookies, which taste exactly the same, are the bomb.  Needless to say, my fiancé and I finished off the bag of cookies that night while drinking our beer in the hotel room.  Fortune cookies and beer - that made for one classy night.  

All the cookies were super cheap, but to get this deal you have to have some cash on you.  Don't come here without having first gone to the ATM!  Besides paying for the items, you can also provide a tip which isn't too much to ask since you're being allowed to go in and watch these lovely women work at making the perfect fortune cookies in such a cramped space.  It really is quite tiny in here - that means it can get busy and it can get hot.  Be prepared for both, and as much as you want to take your time in here, try to be as efficient as possible.  

Lastly, they happen to have a HUGE fortune cookie that they sell here - we bought it, thinking how awesome it would be to eat such a monumental fortune cookie, but it was super stale.  I literally couldn't bite into the thing without breaking a tooth.  It's a neat thing to buy just for a photo op, or maybe even just to put on display (though that might be weird), but if you're just looking to eat the cookies then go with the bags of flattened ones.  They're really the best.  

Finding your way here can be just a tiny bit tricky as you'll have to look down the alley's for the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie factory.  But!  There were cats roaming all around the area of the factory so I'll just say, follow the cats?  The cats seem to know a good fortune cookie when they see one...that's how you know this place is awesome, and a must-try when in San Francisco.
author: Lauren K.

description: One of a kind place to see how fortune cookies are made. Located in an alley you'll have to walk a bit to find it. Service here is okay - very simple in terms of communication.  You can write your own fortune and put it in a small Chinese take out (2 cookies max) which was cool. It's a nice small gift if you need to find a present. They also offer a variety of fortune cookies which is cool. Overall it's a neat place to check out in china town
author: Nadine Y.

description: SO hard to find!!! IMAP has us walk in circles for 30 minutes. I guess Chinatown streets are not pinged. Cute place and cool to see the machine and woman that makes the cookies.
author: Sara M.

description:
Tucked inside an alley, this small shop offered a few different options of fortune cookies.

The man handed out some samples.

We purchased the mini flat cookies, 10 bags @$4 each. They give a free bag of large flat cookies. They also threw in handful of loose pieces for on the go. 

This place is really small (only 10 ppl allowed at a time, and that is a tight fit). Cash only
author: Jenny L.

description: The aroma of  china town can be complex at times but the aroma of this factory is intoxicating!!! They had me at cookie! Yes please!! Bought 2 bags going to be a treat after dinner to see whatever my fortune is.  they had so many that got cold too fast they threw I. A handful to snack on the way home.. you sure can tell the difference in fresh made fortune cookies and those stale ones you get eating out. Great place to take the kids and show them how factories work and just appreciate everything!
author: Lynn U.

description:
I've never seen so many types of fortune cookies until I came here.  You'll find them in all sorts of shapes, colors, and flavors along the walls of shelves.

The staff will give you a slight discount with a few freebies based on what you can round down when you pay with cash.  However, don't expect a receipt or anything more unless you speak Chinese for customer service.
author: Jenny L.

description: The guy on door and line patrol is a little abrasive & things are a over priced but hey, it's a tourist trap. Cookies are alright, co-workers had fun with the "x-rated" fortunes.
author: Flowers C.

description: This answered so many questions for me. I make my own fortune cookies for New Years, but seeing a pro really helped me. Plus you can have them put a hand-written and personal fortune of your making into a cookie. Just . I'd highly recommend stopping by, and we were lucky enough to come at a time where the local king fu place was doing some practice in the alley and the whole experience felt so cool and you didn't have to get off the beaten path to have it!
author: Rachel C.

description:
I have had this place bookmarked for a few years now and decided to finally visit with my husband. Golden Gate isn't super easy to locate, it in an alley that you wouldn't even think had businesses on and we really had to look for the sign. 

Upon arriving you are greeted with free flat fortune cookies that are warm and taste amazingly good. There are plenty of cookies to buy on the shelves in a variety of coatings such as chocolate and others. We picked up a few items as well as a giant fortune cookie. We spent about $15 and the woman helping us walked over the the bucket of hot fortune cookies and grabbed two handfuls and just threw them into the bag which was cool. These are hot and even though there were at least 20 in there, they didn't even make it to the car. 

The process by which they make the cookies is very cool. They have an automated machine that spits batter into molds for the flat cookies and goes around in a half circle arc. The cookies travel around this arc, cook, and come back out the other end where they are folded into a fortune cookie shape. 

This was a cool experience and they have amazing cookies. Stop by and give it a try!
author: Ashley F.

description:
Trying to get here was a damn journey.  I accidentally went to a more ghetto alleyway and my bf freaked out thinking I was taking him somewhere to get killed.  LOL!  I finally found the tiny little shop and there was the sweetest Chinese man there welcoming me with fresh flat fortune cookies.  It honestly brought a tear to my eye.

This shop really is small and I believe it only accommodate a few people at the time.  Luckily my bf and I were the only one's there so we took the advantage to roam around freely.  They offer a lot of variety of fortune cookie that I didn't know existed.  Strawberry, chocolate, matcha, dipped in chocolate, etc... They also offer novelty cookies such as a giant ass cookies or one's where you could put your own fortune in.  

My darn bf only allowed me to buy 1 bag of mini assortment of flavored flat fortune cookies.  Such a dumb mistake.  That bag didn't last very long plus it was only $5!  The sweet man gave us extra cookies to-go.  My hero.
author: Jackie N.

description: China town is so big!! We happened upon this place on accident. I recognized the famous name immediately. They have a large variety of fortune cookies and snacks. You can see them making the fortune cookies live. Such a cool place. Free samples too. Truly a treasure in china town.
author: Crowlynn M.

description: I cannot go to SF without a stop here for some warm samples and a couple bags to go. Just a fun place to visit. I bring all out of town guests here
author: Heidi R.

description: Fortune cookies that taste like fortune cookies. They also gave free cookie disks with our purchase. They have different varieties of cookies like strawberry?, green tea?, chocolate?, and chocolate dipped.
author: Tracy T.

description:
Have you ever eaten a fortune cookie and wondered to yourself how these little treats are made? Or maybe you just want to find a place that makes them FRESH, right in front of you - rather than purchasing them stale at a market. 

Well here at Golden Gate Fortune Cookies, this is where all the baked magic happens. 

Recently, my girlfriend and I were brainstorming new places to check off on our San Francisco bucket list. While searching up "food tours" in the city, we came across Golden Gate Fortune Cookies, a small bakery that's been around since 1962! Apparently, this is THE place to visit if you want fortune cookies (yes with fortunes inside). 

Golden Gate Fortune Cookies is located on Ross Alley next to Jackson Street (Between Grant Ave and Stockton) in Chinatown. If you plan on coming here, I HIGHLY recommend public transportation because traffic will be horrible on a weekend because of the high influx of tourists. But, if you insist, there's a big parking garage nearby and the occasional opening for street parking. 

First, let me preface by saying that you shouldn't set your expectations for this place to be too high. Golden Gate Fortune Cookies is, in essence, a small store/bakery. It's not really, as some people may suggest on the Interwebs, a "factory." Yes, you see people actually making fortune cookies here, but just like any other bakery, you can get a birds-eye view of how things are being made. If you really want to take pictures/talk to the workers, I suggest coming super early because this bakery gets FLOODED with tourists/customers...which makes sense because this place is hyped up so much. We came in around 4pm (they close at 5 I believe), and it took around 10 minutes to reach the front.

Overall, as I said, Golden Gate Fortune Cookies is really just a bakery. Once you pass through the door, you will be hit with the most amazing aroma. Man all that butter smells DELICIOUS. You just want to buy EVERYTHING. And the best part is that once you are close enough to the front, you will be greeted by a very nice employee who lets you sample a freshly made cookie that hasn't been molded into shape yet. And boy, does it taste warm and delicious. And after you've had a chance to let the taste sink in, you can open your eyes and  see shelves filled with ALL KINDS of different fortune cookies. They range from vanilla ones, to chocolate-coated cookies - all things you never see outside. And the prices are SUPER cheap too! At most, it's like around $10 for a HUGE bag. If you just want the basic ones, it's like $2.5 for a good number (at least 10+). We ended up getting the original cookies. 

I really wished we had longer to decide what cookies we wanted and also check out the gear/tools the employees used for the fortune cookies. But the big problem about this bakery is that it's TINY. With the huge lines, it's almost impossible to spend longer than 5 minutes to enjoy your surroundings. So it won't be one of those places where you can come in and look to see what you want before waiting in line. It's definitely better if you come earlier so you don't feel the pressure to decide and leave. But besides that, the bag of fortune cookies we got were AWESOME! Despite sitting in a bag, they tasted fresh, were crunchy, and smelled GREAT!

All in all, I am happy that we took the time to check out Golden Gate Fortune Cookies. I'm sad that we weren't able to spend longer in there due to the traffic. But, due to the experience + the delicious cookies, I give this place a "nice-su, you can take your parents here and they'll be happy." I do recommend this place at least once if you are in the city!

Have fun and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description: So fun to not only watch but make our very own personalized fortune cookie. I loved eating the fresh cookies just made. So fun! I would for sure go back
author: Nettifer W.

description:
Cool spot to see the work in action. Fortune cookies are tasty but can be a bit expensive if you really think about it. It does make a good novelty gift for someone especially the mega cookie in a takeout box for about $6. 

Fun place and you get a few flat ones to taste on the way in. It's small but just recognize that they are making a living there and not a sideshow. We bought our share of fortune cookies to taste and giveaway. All in all a fun experience down one of the alleys in Chinatown.
author: Clarence E.

description:
Fortune cookies are definitely more delicious than your average, but it's overpriced. Also, I thought this would be a real tour of a fortune cookie favorite, not a literal single room where one woman is using a fortune cookie folding machine. 

I'd visit just to see for myself but definitely would not have spent all the money I did buying fortune cookies.
author: Magnolia S.

description:
We had no idea what we were getting ourselves into when we decided to check this place out before dinner. SO COOL! They have 3 stations/machines where they are making fresh cookies. You can get up close and watch the machines pour the batter and cook the cookies. Then you can see the fortunes being stuffed into the cookies. 

And for $1 you can write your own fortune and they will put it inside a fresh cookie right there in front of you. They pack it up in a little box and you are on your way. 

They also have a large selection of chocolate covered cookies which are the delicious. 

Highly recommend to anyone who has ever had a fortune cookie. We took our 6 year old daughter here and she loved it so much we came back the next day! 

PS - there is a mural of Klay Thompson on the wall.
author: Mike H.

description:
This place is a hidden (literally) gem in Chinatown. I've eaten Fortune Cookies all my life and have never seen them being made in real life.

When you go in, you can see the nice ladies grabbing the hot cookies, stuffing them with the slips of paper, and folding them onto the trays. A pretty neat experience, imo. 
They also offered us some cookies to try when we were in line. The cookies are also reasonably priced.

Worth a quick stop!
author: Sylvia Y.

description:
I wouldn't come back, but I'd definitely recommend to others as a experience this once type thing.

The fortune cookies here really aren't good, but the ladies are soooo nice, and it's cool to see how they make their fortune cookies. There's a vast variety of flavors and shapes. You'll see the huge fortune cookies too.

They give out samples, but the packages are cheap enough to just buy some as well.
author: Tiffany J.

description:
Literally a hole in the wall, in the middle of a random alley. The Golden Gate Fortune Cookies factory is a must for any tourist in the Chinatown Neighborhood of San Francisco. It is not too hard to find, and yes at first you will question yourself if you really want to walk down an alley way, but the experience will be worth it.

You can smell the sweet vanilla aroma of fortune cookies as soon as you turn down the alley way. Inside you will usually find about three ladies taking hot vanilla wafers and folding them into the fortune shape cookies we have come to know and love.

They usually will give you one or two hot out of the oven for free and from there you can purchase as many as you want. They sell them in boxes, bags and even giant fortune cookies! We usually will by a bag of about 30 fortune cookies and bring them back for relatives, but be warned that they are pretty fragile and will break easily.
author: Johnny M.

description: A fun, unique place to visit. We happened upon this little gem and walked right in (we clearly must have gotten lucky based on other reviews). We enjoyed seeing how fortune cookies were made. Plus you can try a fresh and recently made fortune cookie, but be warned - if you ever liked eating a fortune cookie in a restaurant, you won't like them after you have it fresh.
author: Asa R.

description:
A Chinatown MUST experience!!  Wow: fresh off the press, hot flat fortune cookie handed to you upon entering and then bags and bags of original, chocolate & strawberry (OMG too good!) FRESH crispy fortune cookies for a great price (don't listen to the cheapskates who said this place was pricey - for crying out loud you are getting a fat bag with a few dozen FRESH fortune cookies for $5.50.  It's amazing ... kids will LOVE this place!

Our kids got a GIANT fortune cookie in a huge take-out container for $6 and had the time of their life breaking it open.  Down on Ross alley next to the awesome barber who has been seen on the Bachelor and in a couple of movies. 

Highly recommended!!  We thoroughly enjoyed it - it's one of the very best SF 3-5 minute diversion experiences and may be your favorite of the day - especially with kids!
author: Darlene C.

description:
Super fast service! I almost didn't even realize when I went in and walked out...we were given a few flat fortune cookies to try , and they were really good. I loved their creativity by adding chocolate, strawberry, and /or sprinkles. 

The place is small and can get crowded easily so just prepare. 

They would have gotten 5 stars, but they only take cash. I usually never carry cash because well I'm clumsy and leave my purse everywhere so I'm much more comfortable with my card... Anyhow they should start taking card. Good thing I had a few bucks in my purse this time.
author: Brenda R.

description: This place is very cool! It's small but you can see how the fortune cookie is made at a glance. They have custom fortune cookies, different flavors, personalize yours, and free samples! Cool little spot to check out when in China Town!
author: Victoria E.

description: The fortune cookies are worth the wait. It's like eating a waffle cone!! Yummo. If you want to customize your fortune cookie, think of what you'll write, that will help speed up the process.
author: Maricela C.

description:
Not going to lie, I really don't like fortune cookies. They're dry and mealy and don't really taste like anything. The only part I like is ripping out the fortune.

But since my friend and I were visiting SF, we decided to give the factory a visit. I always like seeing how things are made, so I was pretty excited for the tour. Well, the tour isn't actually a tour. And the factory isn't really a factory. At least it wasn't the grandiose cookie factory that I had pictured in my head. Instead, it's a small room down some alley way, and you have two ladies working on the cookies. Nonetheless, it was still pretty amazing to see them at work.

They have a sign saying that if you want to take a photo/video, it'll cost you 50 cents. They don't really enforce it but you should definitely just be a good person and pay it. After all, their "tour" is free and they have to make a living somehow! 50 cents for a glimpse of their process is 50 cents well spent.
author: Mel T.

description: A must see place, it is down an alley but well worth it. Plan on getting there in the morning. It is not a large store and only holds a few people at a time.
author: John D.

description: Everyone must come here at least once. Pretty cool! The workers/ owners must get tired of the tourists coming in and taking photos of them. I just love the alley it's in, I felt blessed to have experienced another day in Chinatown (I've been there dozens and dozens of times over the years). The fortune cookies taste really good. The young woman accepting people at the front of the line looked weary but was nice enough to answer people's questions, "how much for this bag?" Etc (of fortune cookies). The price is outrageous for what you're actually getting, yet they do make the fortune cookies by hand (with a little assistance from a machine) and who does things by hand anymore? They also have adult themes fortunes and giant fortune cookies for less than $5, a great gift idea.
author: Jenny P.

description:
My sister wanted to check out the fortune cookies and I was reluctant. Boy am I glad she dragged me with her. It's pretty interesting to see how the cookies are made, but they hurry you along because they're trying to accommodate everyone and the space is super tiny.

They let you try some samples and then you can make a purchase. I scoffed at my sister when she purchased a bag and now I'm hitting myself on the side of the head because once we got back to Houston, I was wondering why I was so stupid to not tell her to buy another. 

Moral of the story? Never listen to a full belly because it does NOT know what it wants. You just keep shoving more food down and one day it will learn to appreciate.
author: Anh L.

description: Fresh fortune cookies and you can see the staff making them! The flat ones without the fortunes are cheaper and great snacks!!
author: Elle W.

description: So fun! They give out free samples and have tons of varieties to buy - I loved the chocolate dipped ones. They really don't taste like the crap you get in restaurants, almost like ice cream cones. It's sort of tucked in an alley but worth a trip!
author: Molly H.

description: I liked this place. I'm glad I went, but if I had waited an hour in line, I would have been disappointed. You do get to see fortune cookies being made and that's cool, but don't think this will be a factory tour. It's small. You watch the cookies being made for a minute, make your purchase and leave. I bought some chocolate dipped cookies.  She threw in some warm cookies that weren't folded. I enjoyed that warm ones. I would say, it's worth going, but if the line is longer than, say, 15 minutes, don't bother.
author: Julie S.

description:
OMG, there is nothing better in life then a warm fortune cookie.  I love fortune cookies... Like really love them..  waited in line to get my hands on some warm cookies and to buy a pound of flats.

Ate half a pound within about an hour... Then the other half later that night.  

Cried when there was no more.   Regretted that I didn't buy several bags....
author: Sissy T.

description:
Once you walk in, you get to see the people making fortune cookies right in front. And you can buy the bags of the ready made cookies on the sides. You can also ask for the sample of the cookies. 
Their fortune cookies are thinner than store bought or restaurant and taste a lot better!! 
When you buy a bag of cookie, the also give you free grocery bag^^
author: Tina K.

description: Great little place to stop at. It take about 7 minutes once you walk in but about 15 minutes   in line. Cookies are fresh..
author: Felipe A.

description: I stood in line to check out this place and was curious what the big deal was. I was close to entering and the owner (I think) had an issue with a woman blocking the entrance. She did it by accident and was with her family patiently waiting to enter. She didn't appreciate him touching her and he made a big deal out of it. He said "I didn't push you. You don't like it, you leave." He said this over and over again. I was in shock that the husband allowed his wife to be spoken to like that. The owner was a POS and I almost had to say something in the woman's defense. I decided to leave because I wasn't going to give a jerk like that my money. Super rude.
author: Andres M.

description: So damn cool! I'm told this is the last hand made fortune cookie factory in SF. They let you make your own cookies and sell rejects. Also cool: I didn't know they made such fancy fortune cookies.
author: Evan Z.

description: After reading so many positive reviews, I was looking forward to this tour. I have to admit, I was a bit disappointed by the experience. We waited for a while since only 10 people are allowed in at a time. That was understandable because this place is tiny.  Once we got in we just stood there and watched as cookies were made. There was no interaction other than a tray of flat cookies being passed around. We were in and out of here in 5 minutes and that included waiting to pay for our bag of fortune cookies, which tasted like fortune cookies. A little disappointed.
author: Tammy S.

description: We were looking for something to do and decided to check this place out because online it said they did tours. You have to walk down an "alley" like street, so pay attention, because my fiancé and I missed it the first time. There was a line out the door but it was moving very quickly. Pretty much you grabbed a bag of premade fortune cookies while in line. When you got to the front, there was a lady pressing the fortune cookies into shape while a guy quickly gave you a sample of the left over "cookie" parts , grabbed your cash for the fortune cookies you were buying, and sent you on your way. In and out, super quick.
author: Karolina T.

description:
Location: In an alley. Literally. We almost walked by it but we happened to see the line snaking out of the door. Follow your GPS for walking directions if using and then look for the line. 

Service: VERY SMALL PLACE. There is only room for for about 4-5 people inside which is why there is a perpetual line out the door. It wasn't super long when we got there (about 3-4 people) and we got in fairly quickly. One of the guys working went down the line and handed out samples while we waited. Fresh fortune cookies = yum. Service is about what you would expect - they are friendly, but it's not a 5 star restaurant. Get in, make your choices, buy it and leave. They stuck a couple more samples in our bag after purchase. We devoured them all within the first block of walking away. 

Cookies: We tried the mini flat fortune cookies and the green tea cookies. They had a fresh batch of the regular and chocolate ones going too. We enjoyed ALL of them. Just depends on what your preference is. The fortunes are pretty unique too! They also had "fancy" decorated ones with chocolate and sprinkles if you so desire. 

Overall: We will be back for fresh cookies next time we are in SF!
author: Courtney N.

description: Very small, always a line but its fast. You wont be disappointed they pass out warm disks of fortune cookies reminds me of pancakes on a griddle. Enjoy
author: Frances H.

description:
Tiny, quirky place. Fascinating to see how fortune cookies are made and get your hot, fresh free sample. Mmmm they are good fresh! 
If you take photos inside they ask for $.50. 
Don't take a free sample unless they are labeled free. One guy stuck his hand into the wrong pile of flat cookies and got chased out!
author: Anne O.

description:
So I discovered something about this place... Yes, I had seen that you could get the cookies here for a while, but even better when I walked in, you can get coins! Fortune cookie coins are basically the cookies that aren't folded, and have no paper. So you can literally shove like 20 of them down your gullet at one time and not choke on paper. 

But seriously, really cool. Ask for a few of the fresh ones (even though they throw them in anyways) and the coins were my favorite. They had other flavors too like Green Tea and Strawberry, and some naughty ones for those of you who are naughty, but the flavor of the fortune cookies is great. It's definitely down a dark alley, so don't think you're going the wrong way if you find yourself walking down a dark alley looking for fortune cookies, but buy a bag or two!
author: Phillip B.

description:
We had looked up this bakery before going over, and were unsure they would be open since several places warn they have somewhat irregular hours, but we were in luck! There was a line when we got there, but it moved quickly. I am not a fan of fortune cookies in general, but friends had told me that the fresh ones were nothing like the ones you get in Chinese takeout. They were right! They give you samples here, and they are delicious. We bought a container of green tea, strawberry, and plain, and several days later they're still great (particularly the strawberry). They also had almond cookies, which I AM a fan of, and although they're a lot less sweet than I'm used to, I really enjoyed them. When we bought the cookies, they gave us a bunch of fresh ones in our bag. 

It's tiny inside, and as other reviews have noted, if you want to take a picture inside they ask you to pay 50 cents (it was too crowded in there for me to try anyway). 

I was glad we went, and would encourage others to visit as well.
author: Carrie L.

description:
Best fortune cookie ever. They don't let you take pictures here. Sort of crazy. Buy a big bag and eat them all because they're so light and so good and fortunes spot on too. 
It's in a small alley which is so cool so check them out.
author: Amy Jo A.

description: Good tasting fortune cookies! They even sell some dipped in chocolate. Kind of overpriced and some of the workers can be a little rude :( . They accept cash and minimum card purchase is $15. They also give you flat cookie samples as you wait in line!
author: Itzel F.

description: A fun place for kids to see how Fortune cookies were made. They also have a variety of strawberry, green tea and chocolate flavored cookies. They have chocolate dipped and sprinkled ones too.
author: Junelle F.

description: Such a cool spot in San Francisco. Arrived to this spot by hearing a group with their Tour Guide. We got in line which was out the door. The smell from the cookies was incredibly homey. It's like visiting China without leaving California. Definitely returning in the future.
author: Mary Ann L.

description: While visiting SF, I decided to go to Golden Gate Fortune Cookies. The fortune cookies are delicious, but be aware that it is tucked away in one of the alleys within Chinatown. It is an extremely popular place to visit, so be prepared to stand in line to get inside the tiny room where the fortune cookies are made and sold. Also, it is important to note that they ask individuals to pay 50 cents for taking pictures inside the tiny store.
author: Nat N.

description:
It's very a tourist attractions in sf....they give you a free fresh fortune cookie to sample while waiting in line...a little s
Small inside but it's worth the trip here...will definitely come back again
author: Love S.

description:
Whats there not to like about this place?! 
.
In China or hong kong, when you ask for fortune cookie, your going to get a blank and confused stare look. Why? There ain't no fortune cookies in hong kong and china, well at least i don't see any. 
.
You get to see them make it fresh! Like take it on the go and snack on it fresh and warm! 
.
They do have flavored cookies, but i stick to the originals please. 
.
They also make big fortune cookies, i mean a giant one which weighs like 1 pound. I think its like 8 to 10 bucks for one, which is great for a foodie gift. 
.
They are friendly with photos, where some place don't allow it. 
.
Also cookies are sold in small batches or big bags if you like. 
.
Overall this place is iconic, and a must visit for first time visitors in sf. Like a selfie required, sometimes i wish I can host tours around the city or in China town. Ha. Thanks for reading and have a yelpstastic day!
author: Alex T.

description: 5 stars for the fortune cookies but knock off a star for the rude ass girl who is either in her teens or early 20s.  Who the hell in their right mind would put someone so unprofessional and curt with their customers especially when majority of those going through are tourists in a position where they're interacting with customers...perhaps she's only there cause she speaks English?  Anyways, today there was some film crew there and some customers said "am I being filmed?" And she responds "yes they are filming, if you don't want to be on camera get out!"  Like really?!  I don't know any retail or service type job where you would speak like that to your customers or anyone really.  She needs some major common courtesy training for dealing with customers...this person is the face of your business.
author: V J.

description:
Wow oh wow! With more than 570 reviews on Yelp, I've finally discovered this special Chinese bakery located at Ross Alley in San Francisco's Chinatown. The "Golden Gate Fortune Cookies" brings the customers from residents and tourists near and far by experience and taste their sensational homemade fortune cookies right in your own eyes! As my mom, aunt and I were heading to this special bakery factory on 5/30/2016, the atmosphere was quite on-going and active as I welcomed there. The concept is much small, yet it does do the job right from showing the demonstrations of making fortune cookies and prepping bags. Yes, I can feel the smell of these baked fortune cookies while coming here, and it's irresistible.

The employees especially the owner are doing a great job for making the customers like me an enjoyable service. No cons at all.

Every aisle of various formats of fortune cookies are very delicious and eatable to bite no matter how big or small is; original or flat. He did offered me a special deal of a bag of flat fortune cookies at a low price after I did seen this segment on Good Day few months ago. What a win-win deal! Very eatable and incredible to eat!

Parking at the Golden Gate Fortune Cookies factory can be challenging to park. You can park at the nearest surface street metered parking nor the parking garage if it's available. Otherwise, you can also ride a bike, walk, or use public transportation easier without the hassles.

To conclude, Golden Gate Fortune Cookies is the coolest and the most remarkable cookie factory shop that I've ever discovered right here in San Francisco! Perfect for all ages! A must visit for tourists! A well, worthy visit! My rating: 5 solid stars.
author: William L.

description: Well that was disappointing. It was about what I expected, but the machine was down while we were there. It seems that they failed to add sugar to the recipe so the product didn't turn out correctly. GF wanted to get a custom fortune cookie for $1.50 and they normally make them to order, but since the machine was down they just stuffed the "fortune" that she wrote into one of the cookies they already had. How do you forget to add one of the main ingredients to a recipe? Sorry I had to digress, So IF you happen to be in China Town it wouldn't hurt to check this place out. The fact that we walked from haight-ashberry to China Town to see it was a huge let down though
author: Matthew M.

description: To cool!!!!  Don't miss out on this " GEM " experience. Great place !!!!!  Best fortune cookies in the world!!!!!
author: Nathan G.

description:
You haven't had a fortune cookie until you've tried Golden Gate's versions.  Its located in a shady-looking alley off Washington St in SF chinatown. Its so small, the store can only fit a dozen customers at a time.  They sell all sorts of fortune cookies, in terms of size, shape, and flavor (chocolate-covered for example).  You can create customized fortunes, or even pick their adult-themed fortunes for pranks, bachelors, or bachelorette parties.

My wife is a huge fan of this place and she got the basic, round and flat fortune cookies.  Two bags worth and the nice folks threw in a bunch of free samples too. They are among the crispiest fortune cookies ever and its hard not to eat a few!  Best of yet, they are not super dense, but rather sort of airy once you bite in.

They have photos of Klay Thompson all over the store as well!  Go Dubs!!
author: Daniel C.

description: It's like being transported back in time. Still done the original way, pretty awesome experience. It's great to be able to patronize a business that's keeping a tradition alive. We always stop by for a few bags of cookies whenever we're in Chinatown.
author: Gary W.

description: A nice place to swing by if you want to see how fortune cookies are made. I didn't have cash and their Square was down when I came so I could purchase anything. However, they did hand out warm fortune cookie wafers, which were delicious. Would love to buy a fresh bundle of fortune cookies next time.
author: Nathan C.

description: Very cool place to see in SF Chinatown.  Be prepared for a line though because its a popular little place.  Very small inside and they move things pretty quick so be on your toes.  Was a little disappointed with the minimal amount of instruction with people coming in to make their fortune cookies.  Everything felt a bit rushed and didn't really get to fully take in the experience but it was cool seeing how they do them.
author: Cash S.

description:
Golden Gate Fortune Cookie has been added to S. F.'s Municipal Registry, making it an historical asset. it's one of 3 Chinatown businesses added this year as part of the Chinese New Year celebration.

See fortune cookles made the old fashioned way, hand assembled. most fortune cookies passed out in chinese restaurants are machined made. crunching on one is similar to crunching down on rock candy.
author: Victor G.

description: One of my favorite spots in San Francisco! In a random dark alleyway right in the middle of Chinatown you'll find this amazing little fortune cookie factory! Try a sample of one of their warm  cookie flats that's in my opinion best when served straight from the factory it's self! Watch the skilled workers twist the cookies into their iconic shapes and you can even create your own fortune cookie with a personalized message inside. One of San Francisco's best touristy spots to see and best of all its all FREE! I always end up leaving with a bag of small cookie flats!
author: Krystle G.

description:
Cool little place to bring pour of towners its unique. They make cookies and let you put the fortune of your choice in it.  
They have flat cookies and regular fortune cookies. Some dipped in choc and canola.  
Charge $.50 per picture inside and give free samples. 
Cool little Chinatown place.
author: David C.

description: I love their cookies but unfortunately after today I will never come back.   The immature owner was shouting, cussing, and belittling his employees in front of customers.  It was extremely uncomfortable!   A customer asked the owner a question and he directed it his employee and then he kept harassing her on whether she understood them.  She understood but he made it difficult because he's not very logical.  We also saw him arguing loudly outside and he wanted to fight with someone but there was a man holding him against the wall.  OSHA, somebody, please inspect this "factory" for abusive, unsafe behavior towards employees and customers.
author: B. W.

description:
Awesome little gem in Chinatown. 
There is a fortune cookie making machine right in the middle of the store.  Fortune cookie variety is good and there are a few fun flavors. They even offer a huge cookie the size of my hand/fist. 

Give it a visit and make it a day in Chinatown.
author: Marlee B.

description:
This place is located in one of Chinatown's many alley ways.  It's very easy to find with a little help from your phone's gps. Keep in mind this place is very small and usually crowded.  There's 
just  enough room to walk in, turn around and leave.  They have free samples and carry various flavors.  I have taken the kids here several times and we always enjoy watching the lady as she makes them.  We take advantage of the days when Chinatown isn't too busy to visit since it is so small and can get very crowded.  You can also buy the cookies that don't come out correctly at a very reasonable price.  Enjoy!
author: Elizabeth V.

description: A definite must see shop!!!  We met one woman who has been making cookies and other treats for  ~52 years!!!  The man, in the shop has been there a long time too..he told us he also fixes the fortune cookie machine.  The fortune cookie machine is something out of Willie Wonka.   The man was very welcoming to our large group of Girl Scouts and mothers.  He was very gracious and generous to us with the tasty treats!!! So thrilled that we were able to find this shop!!
author: Dawne B.

description: I've been coming  here since I was a kid. I love eating their fortune cookies especially when it's fresh and warm from the pan. I always get the small almond cookies and the cow ear cookie. The fortune cookies taste like any other fortune cookie but it's so much better when it's warm. No need to explain the the almond cookie it's just bomb and the cow ears are shaped like ears  which is why it's called that. The texture of the cookie is addicting. To me the flavor is okay, it's like a crunchy chip but the crunch is so good. You can't just eat one, the crunchiness is satisfying. The bags of these goodies are just under $5 each.
author: Andrew T.

description:
Time to get some cookies!  This place i think writes its own fortune cookie messages! The cookies are great you cant eat just one.  So get two bags of them, one of the flat one and a bag or the reg ones.  

You will be back.
author: Dean S.

description:
If you ever wanted to see someone make a fresh handmade fortune cookie right before your eyes, stop by here!

Located in a very sketchy looking alley. Pretty danky looking place inside. The workers make it look so easy, but I am sure its pretty hard to make it.

Cash only. 

Mix Snack Bag - $2 - Comes with both chocolate and vanilla cookies. Very crispy and tasted fresh.
author: Kevin W.

description:
This place was pretty cool never seen anything like this. My friend took me here saying it was in a back alley*it is* saw some kids doing wushu outside. 

But yeah walked in saw them making the cookies and took some free samples *so good* and then bought some adult rated cookies. Lady was super nice she put some more samples in our bag. Overall I'd say to visit kinda don't see these places around.

-Josh
author: Joshua O.

description: A must see if your in China Town. Taste a freshly made fortune cookie, make your own fortune cookie and fortune, and experience a piece of China Town.
author: Douglas F.

description:
Adult Rated fortunes (some are fun, some make you think to get why its x-rated, and some are plain stupid) 

Original and chocolate flavors + flat options

Custom make your own fortune

Fresh ones coming off the press (literally) 

Overall Thoughts

Well worth the trip
author: Eddie W.

description: A must when you're in Chinatown! Hands-down! I only wish I could carry more fortune cookies back to the car! A free, warm sample every visit, too. We always buy several bags, so we get a complimentary handful of fresh cookies thrown in!
author: Jason H.

description:
The fortune cookies are made fresh before your eyes and are really yummy! There are a lot of different flavors and sizes of cookies to choose from. You can even make your own for a small fee. Pictures also cost .50 to take. 

However, the owners and his employees are also really nice and friendly. He even gave me a bunch of extra samples when I bought a bag (which was only like $5). 

I'd definitely come back to purchase more fortune cookies in the future.
author: Kelly N.

description: It is a cool local landmark. It is a great place to bring anyone who is visiting SF. I love this place I don't get to visit it as much as I would like but isn't that the case when you live here. Will try my best to get out more.
author: Bre M.

description:
Fortune cookies taste really good... but these are
some lame a$$ fortunes lol!

If you're in Chinatown, stop by for a visit. Hopefully, they change the paper inserts for the fortune cookies as the yellow ones are disappointing and useless.
author: Diggity D.

description: A must stop in San Francisco. Our son loved it and the fortune cookies are amazing. So fresh and they hand out samples while you wait.
author: Tara M.

description: Such an experience to watch these hard working people make delicious fortune cookies.  You can purchase all kinds of fortune cookies there.  They have chocolate, strawberry and vanilla cookies.  There are cookies dipped in chocolate.  No some X Rated ones also.  They will make a custome cookie for you with your own message inserted.  My favorite were the flat cookies.  Wish that I had purchased more cookies from them.  Very nice people working there.  Cannot wait to go there again. A definite must go to place, if you can find it.  It is located in a small alley.
author: Brenda S.

description: Fresh fortune cookies folded by hand. Free samples and you can customize your "fortune" for an additional fee. Cute gift idea.
author: Dina H.

description: Always a must stop when in the area.  The cookies are the bomb here; crisp and fresh.  It's a small place but their products are huge in taste.  Only thing is that it's a tiny place so when there's a crowd you'll feel rushed.  Been coming in for over 20 years, tastes just as good each time we visit.
author: Mei T.

description:
Best FORTUNE COOKIES IN SF!! As you enter the alleyway, depending on the day you might here some classical and elegant music played by some local.
