As you enter you are instantly hit by the smell of fortune cookies. It looks like a sweat shop, but for fortune cookies. CASH ONLY! I would say the prices are good and aren't too high or too low. The workers/owners don't speak much/any English. Almond Cookies are a must. Best cookies I've had. This place has probably been around longer than I've been alive. The cookies make for good snacks when studying or gifts for friends. I know that they supply cookies for San Tungs in the sunset. A great tourist destination. 

- CASH ONLY!
- Flattened Fortune Cookies ( So you don't have to keep breaking the cookies)
- ALMOND COOKIES ARE FLAMES!
author: Brian C.

description: It's a tiny little place where you can buy fortune cookies and watch the workers make them! It's pretty cool. they also let you write your own fortunes and the lady will make it right there in a few seconds. they also have different cookie flavors! I recommend the strawberry.
author: Stella C.

description:
Swing by this unique "attraction" to see how fortune cookies are made! Inside the historic Ross Alley, Golden Gate Fortune Cookies is one of SF Chinatown's oldest establishments. Here, you can see the cool contraptions that rapidly cooks the dough into fortune cookies in a two-woman assembly line where the workers quickly takes the flat cookies to bend them before they cool.

The whole affair takes less than 10 minutes to see and it's free. Plus, you get a free sample of a piping hot "flat" fortune cookie! I wasn't a fan of fortune cookies before, but the hot sample was really good. $0.50 to take a photo but hey, it's a very good deal! Anyway, check out this cool spot in Chinatown!
author: Jay Y.

description: A through disappointment-tiny and predictable. The saleslady there was trying to push prepackaged bags of flat cookies when I clearly asked for the fresh ones.  Selected few with the right race get the fresh ones upon request-I guess.
author: Michelle T.

description:
Stumbled upon the Golden Gate Fortune cookie factory while walking around Chinatown. It is located in an alley. It was pretty cool to see how fortune cookies are handmade. 

They also sell a bunch of Chinese snacks like fortune cookies (regular or x-rated) in: original, chocolate, and strawberry flavors, smackles (cow-ear shaped cookies), almond cookies, etc. You could also create your own fortune cookie message for $1 and they will put it in a fortune cookie and take-box.
author: Margery W.

description: Just go...super friendly...tasty..free samples and do customization of cookies with your own message. Kids loved it
author: Judi B.

description: I specifically bought non x-rated cookies. A few x-rated ones ended up in the box. I had brought them to work for my coworkers to enjoy. Thankfully my manager has a sense of humor.
author: Lili B.

description: Worth the walk, worth the visit! It was a fun experience. The best part was getting to write your own personal fortune for a friend and having them fold the fortune into a freshly made cookie. The place is tiny and located in an alley... you will walk past it if you're not careful. Having a walking app on your phone will help you find it.
author: Oscar B.

description: Very interesting and worthwhile quick spot in Chinatown. Is there a bunch for you to do and see once you are in here.. No.. But what this is to see finally answer those unimportant but lingering questions in your head of "how do fortunes cookies get made and folded" and can I have different flavors, shapes, and sizes of fortune cookies..Yes! We loved our flat fortune cookies we purchased to take home and enjoy. We couldn't help but buy then when the man at the front was handing out free cookies.. It just made us want more!
author: Trevor W.

description:
Apparently the roommate's nephew loves fortune cookies! So much so, that he asked me to pick some up if I'm ever walking through Chinatown. I didn't have anything to do during my lunch hour, so I decided to walk there and grab some on Tuesday, October 20th around 2:45pm.

*Mix chocolate adult x-rated cookies ($5.50)
*Regular fortune cookies ($4.50)

The nephew is less than 2 years old, so he can't exactly read. Would it be wrong to get him adult fortunes?! Initially, I just grabbed the mixed adult bag since I wanted some to humor myself. But I started feeling somewhat responsible and grabbed a bag of the regular ones before I left. (In the end, it probably wouldn't have mattered as the adult fortunes are rather tame. I wouldn't call them x-rated at all!)

The regular cookies are good. If you can get some hot ones, go for it! There's nothing like a soft warm fortune cookie. I'd stay away from the chocolate ones as they tasted burnt. Not sure if it was the chocolate flavoring or if they really were burnt, but I didn't enjoy them at all.

I'm actually not a huge fan of fortune cookies, but there's something oddly fun and kind of comforting about them. Given Golden Gate Fortune Cookies history, they're one of the shops that does them the best!
author: Elena N.

description: Awesome place. A bit hard to find. But supercool!! You can smell it before you can see it. Can't wait to visit again I will do a big fortune for sure.
author: Millie A.

description:
Hidden in kind of a sketchy looking alley way in SF Chinatown is truly a hole in the wall gem. 

As soon as you walk in, they have a bucket of warm freshly made fortune cookies. I never had one that was still warm, and it was incredibly delicious. They also have chocolate fortune cookies, but I didn't really think they tasted that great. I'd stick with the originals. They had a bag of cookies with xrated fortunes for $5. My gfs bought a few, but they didn't open it so I didn't get to see what those fortunes actually said. Hopefully, they're not too risqué, cause they're planning to take it back to the office :-p. They also have little mixed baggies with regular and chocolate for $2. I opted for that since I wanted to taste the chocolate cookies. You can also write your own fortune for $1. You write what you want on the piece of paper and hand it to the ladies to fold into the cookies. Awesome idea! 

It's pretty cool to watch the ladies actually make the cookies and fold them into their signature shapes. It is a super tiny shop, and because you're so close to the action it gets really hot in there, real fast. Otherwise a cool place to visit!
author: Miya T.

description: The people are so generous and the older ladies looked happy doing their job. It was hard to find this because it's in a small alley behind some grocery stores. I bought the giant fortune cookie and the lady gave us so many samples and then put more in my bag.
author: Anahi G.

description:
I'm not even a big fan of fortune cookies until a friend who was visiting from Asia bought a bag of the adorable flat round ones and generously split half to us. Omg I cannot stop eating them. It's a good thing they are not located in the same zip code as me.

A definite must try if you're in Chinatown!
author: Chen S.

description:
Yep, this place hasn't changed a bit since the last time I wrote a review over 3 years ago. Now that I am working less than a 10 minute walk from this place, I am sure I will be there more often. It seems to me that the people that leave low reviews for Golden Gate Fortune Cookies have an issue with accepting other cultures. I came in, got a bag of small flat fortune cookies for $4 and moved on with my life. Sure, the people might not be so "friendly" here but I also do not speak their language. Business is business and after all you are in the heart of China Town. 

2016 Review #23
author: Stephanie G.

description: Wandered in here to see the cookies being made. It is very tiny and crowded due to the walking tours that stop by. It is not well organized so you need to get help if you want a personalized message inside a cookie. We tried but then got pointed to a wall and then pushed by the droves of people wanting to get in. I gave up trying to buy a cookie. The good thing is that you get a sample of a cookie upon entering before it is shaped so it's warm and yummy. If they were smart they'd have a person take the order outside and paid for, and then have your cookie made by the time you're done looking at the cookie presses and taking pics. Loss of business due to poor organizational process.
author: MJ L.

description: A neat little stop in Chinatown. The orders come quick and the selection in styles and flavor are pretty good. The service is passable, but since it's always crowded, it's somewhat understandable.
author: Tyler H.

description: Got the chocolate covered cookies as well as an entire bag of green tea cookies. Ate mostly all of them in about 3 days. Chocolate ones were good-lightly sweetened for chocolate which I loved. The green tea ones actually* tasted of green tea. Almost too strongly but i appreciate their authenticity. They also make them fresh on premise and give you the rejects. Not as aesthetic but still get the job done.
author: Song K.

description: Delicious strawberry, chocolate and green tea fortune cookies. Well priced and very cool to see how they are made.
author: Kendra S.

description: Very very small for being called a "factory" and you have to pay 50¢ to take pics. Cash only.
author: Camille R.

description:
It wouldn't be a great visit to SF Chinatown without a visit to GGFCF. My kids love stopping in to get fortune cookies at this institution. The freshness, superior crisp texture and flavor are soooo much better than the prepackaged ones doled out at restaurants. There are free samples of the flat version of the cookies. I love getting the $4.25/bag of the flat cookies and snacking on them. 

There are pics of famous visitors hung on the walls behind the racks of packaged cookies. NBA star, Klay Thompson, from the GSW was featured in one photo.
author: K M.

description: This place is so hidden and cute. You get to watch them make the cookies and they give you samples to try. Great stop.
author: Britta W.

description:
I don't like to eat fortune cookies after a Chinese meal because frankly, the cookies are pretty stale. Who knows how long they've been sitting in the kitchen?

It's the complete opposite when I visit the fortune cookie factory; the cookies are fresh and crispy. I love to eat the fortune cookies here and my favorites are the flat discs. 

The factory itself is small and cramped but I managed to observe them make cookies, pay for a bag of flat cookies and chocolate/regular cookies and got out of there in time before the tour groups arrived. 

I can imagine it gets crazy on the weekends, but if you have time during the week, pay them a visit and get your fortune cookies for the week.
author: Nette T.

description: Definitely worth a visit - fun, interesting and free!  The samples (and the bags of flat cookies you can buy for $4) are fresh and delicious! Really interesting to watch the fortune cookies being molded by hand - and, if you are feeling creative, you can write your own fortune and have it placed in a cookie.
author: Shirley M.

description: After i yelped this place, i decided i wanted to stop by.  Freshly made fortune cookies.  What made me want to stop by this place?  Hmmm... i saw a picture on yelp "Adult X Rated" LOL.. brought it back as souvenir.  As i was in line, the worker was handing out free samples of the fortune cookies and you can see the ladies making fresh ones right in front of you.  There's a sign that says, pictures and video .50. As i paid for the cookies, the lady threw in a few more pieces of the samples.  That's awesome and taste good too!  If i stop by SF again, i will definitely visit again.
author: Julie L.

description: I love coming here for fresh fortune cookies! They have the best ones here in San Francisco. I definitely will come here again. I would recommend for anyone who is a fan of fortune cookies. They are nice and friendly. They also have different flavors from, chocolate, match green tea, and strawberry.
author: Cindy M.

description: This place is a hidden gem in my opinion. When visiting San Francisco, Chinatown shouldn't be missed, so you might as well hit up this tiny spot. It doesn't take long because it is literally a hole-in-the-walk. You walk in, see the ladies making fortune cookies, and get a sample unfolded cookie. You can purchase some where you write your own fortune for a few bucks. We thought this was a fun and authentic San Fran souvenir to take back to our family. The gentleman who owned the place adores kids and was very sweet to give them extra samples. Now my kids want to make their own fortune cookies at home.
author: Christianna S.

description:
These fortune cookies were actually tasty.  They had a hint of toasted sesame seeds in it. 

I feel like as a tourist, this is a must go place to visit....that's just me though...(side note: I wonder why I didn't visit this place the first time I came to SF back in 2013)...with the Yelp map in hand, this place was easy to find. 

I bought a bag of almond cookies and two bags of fortune cookies, one big and one small bag.  The lady gave me some flat fortune cookies for free.  The total came up to $9.  I have her a 10 and she seemed as if she didn't want to give me my change.  I said to her in chinese that is $9 right? And she then gave me my dollar back... (it's the principle gotdammit..lol)

Coming home, I regret not buying more although I had no where to put it...lol
author: Ming T.

description: Best tasting fortune cookies. The small flat rounds are very addictive.  So good. Great snacking and ideal for gifts.
author: Brenda V.

description:
This place has become a tourist attaction.  Their fortune cookies are a great snack.  

Bought 5 bags of fortune cookies only to find out that I only got 4 bags.  Of course I got charged for 5 bags.  

Make sure you check you got the correct amount of bags purchased before leaving.
author: yat c.

description:
Can't beat these fortune cookies! The ladies working here are pumping out fortune cookies like nobodies business! I usually buy the $4 bag of flat cookies w out the fortune. They're just as delicious without all the work of removing the fortunes (also less crumby). 

They're dangerously delicious! I can eat 10 without noticing.
author: Liz N.

description: I could smell their fortune cookie from far far away! It's an old shop, so if you're expecting anything modern you'll end up with disappointment. However, it's pricing is great!
author: Simpkins F.

description: The best fortune cookies in the South Bay. They have very unique flavors for the cookies such as matcha, strawberry and vanilla.
author: Riley W.

description:
I have so many childhood memories here. At least twice a year, I have been coming to this treasure that sells flat fortune cookies. Honestly, you haven't experienced fortune cookies until you've been to this little factory. Not only do you get to watch the hot cookies be produced fresh, the cookies itself are cooked to perfection. I love that it's always the same man working there, passing out fresh cookies in a large platter to those standing in line. And he even tosses in a handful of hot cookies after you purchase a bag. 

Do yourself a favor and buy more than one bag when you come here! I bought 4 today and I have no regrets.
author: Lauren V.

description: Simply follow your nose towards the delicious smells down the small alley. You won't be disappointed! Amazing to see hand made fortune cookies in process. The history was great to see.  Walked away with free samples and bought a bag of chocolate covered cookies. Will be back!
author: Alison B.

description: We love the cookies and ship them often to friends and family. We enjoy watching the Fortune cookies getting made. Walking down the alley to get to this little gem of a store front, you can feel and smell the history of the area- well worth going to as a tourist or as a resident in the area.
author: Susan E.

description:
Everyone has to love the folded fortune cookies with a fortune inside.  The next best thing is a flat fresh fortune cookie.  They taste so good even a few days after you bring them home.  This is a famous landmark to see how it's done and get a free sample. The line goes really fast.  It's not that big inside.  
I remember seeing the long line with my Mom and then going to another store to buy groceries and coming back when the line is shorter.  
Fortune cookies goes great with a cup of tea, a glass of milk, and a good size bag is only $4.
author: Julie W.

description:
We found this little factory by strolling in the side streets, and glad we did.  Get up close and personal watching how the process starts with batter being injected into a mold, then cooks as it rotates; once done, a worker peels off the warm, pliable cookie, stuffs with a fortune, folds on a rod, then puts in a bucket ready for packaging.  

Many of the cookies land in a 'reject' bucket, which one of the owners use as samples for the constant rotation of customers.  My youngest son had a personalized fortune made up for his girlfriend - I'm sure she'll love it. 

Such a cool way to see how things are done - kids of all ages will definitely enjoy this place.
author: Patrick K.

description:
FREE samples! 
This place is in a little alley but you will probably recognize it with the line of tourists outside it. When I went there was a small line but it did not take more than 10-15 min to get in. When you walk in, there are free samples of circular fortune cookies that you can try. Cool to see the fortune cookie making process - it was like a conveyor belt of small pancake molds that a lady would fold into fortune cookies. You can customize your own fortune cookie with whatever fortune you want for $1.50. FYI: it costs $0.50 to take a photo
author: Jenny B.

description: By far a hidden jewel in Chinatown! So neat to watch them make fortune cookies and they hand out flat cookies while you watch. For $0.50 you can take a picture with the ladies making the cookies. The best stop in Chinatown and worth the trip to the alley to see.
author: Kacie M.

description: Not what I expected. It was a small building off an alley. The people who worked there were really rude and impatient. I tried to order two custom cookies and they put the wrong fortune in one and both in the wrong box. You can imagine my embarrassment when I gave the gifts to the recipients. How can you mess up just two cookies? On top of that the two people I interacted with were so rude and all they wanted was my money, no one bothered smiling, saying hello or telling us how any of it worked. Disappointing.
author: Jessica R.

description: Customize your own fortune cookie for $1 or add 2 cookies in 1 box for $1.50. Cheap and affordable goodies to bring back home when you're visiting the area. Inside the shop and against the wall on the left is a table where you can write down your own fortunes. When you're finished, give it to the ladies who will individually wrap the fortune in the cookie. With every purchase, you get a hand-full of their "rejected" cookies. The ladies can only make so many fortune cookies at a time. So the ones that they didn't use, they keep in a bucket. They're still edible and just as yummy. It's a cool place to visit if your walking through china town.
author: Christal C.

description:
So it's a little touristy and it's alley location is a little shady, but DAMN this fortune cookie sweatshop sure can bring it.   I like the traditional twisted fortune cookies which are thin and crispy vs the  flat ones that are a little thicker.   I even got our Chinese friend who basically told me - I don't eat this even when they give it away for free after a meal - to try it and he went in for seconds.   

Nuff said folks!   It's a little pricey so I whacked a star off but who really is going to read this review??   If by chance you do, feel free to LIKE.
author: L D.

description:
Story time: 

The first time I came here was the summer after my senior year in high school. My mom's penpal and her daughter came out to visit, and my mom had heard about this place from some guidebook. This was still the days of guidebooks... no smartphones. So we searched and searched, and finally came upon it: just a small open door in an alleyway of other small, open doors.

Inside, there were two women, quietly working at their seats, folding the freshly baked, flat wafers around slips of paper containing the secrets of our futures.

On the walls are newspaper clippings about the factory, as well as bins filled with the treats they make: regular fortune cookies, chocolate fortune cookies, the flat wafers, even x-rated cookies. 

We bought a bunch of treats, and we left to do the rest of our touring around the city. 

Three months later, as I was across the country for my freshman year of college, my mom sent me a bag of the flat wafers in a care package, reminding me of that fun summer day being tourists. I shared them with my new roommate and friends, and told them all about the small shop in an alleyway in Chinatown. 

A few nights later, my roommate, much less innocent than myself, got an under-the-influence smile on her face as she asked me for some of my "circles of happiness" to satisfy her munchies--the fog in her head wouldn't let her remember what they were called. 

So in my family, the plain wafers have been called "circles of happiness" ever since.
author: Angela H.

description: Loved the samples and seeing the old ladies making fortune cookies by hand. Kinda pricey though if you want to buy anything.
author: Jonathan O.

description:
This little factory brings back memories of walking around Chinatown with my grandpa. He would buy bags of these small coin-like cookies that taste like fortune cookies and let us munch on them as we trailed behind him in Chinatown.

Of course, going by myself was a little different. It was really a tiny open factory with one lady working the fortune cookie machine and the older man doing the sales. It was actually empty at around 5pm on a weekday night so it was nice. I got a pretty decent-sized bag for $4. He also gave me a couple extra large cookies as well.

A couple weeks later, I'm still munching on these cookies and they're not even stale! And they've definitely just been chilling on my desk in the open.
author: Athena C.

description:
Don't miss it if you're in Chinatown.  Its a quiet little place, cranking out the fortune cookies... Fun just to watch the ladies roll them up.  Free, warm samples while you shop... But don't dawdle.  Small space, people waiting.
The chocolate flavored ones, (not chocolate dipped, chocolate cookie), are the best but buy the mixed bag so you get some of each.
They also sell one, giant fortune cookie in a plastic container if you're looking for gift souvenirs. ($5)
Or the mixed bag comes in a "Chinese take-out" container which is cute for a gift also.  
Tip:  GPS will take you down Jackson street but will fail to take you down Ross Alley, (because you can't drive down it), and the alley is about halfway down the hill.  We were lucky on Jackson street parking but you will most likely walk up or down Jackson looking for the alleyway.

Tip:  it's .50 to take a picture.  Just give them a dollar and you'll get more free cookies with your photo.
author: Dawn V.

description: A MUST when visiting Chinatown in San Francisco! Have you ever had flat, fresh, hot fortune cookies? They make them right here and they give out free samples! It's a very tiny hole in the wall place in a tiny alley, but you can't miss it. It's the one with the line of people standing in front it. If you're lucky, there will be no one in line, otherwise, it goes by quickly. Gives you a chance to decide which of the many varieties of fortune cookies you're going to choose. There's regular, chocolate, strawberry, large ones, flat ones, x-rated fortunes, etc. You can't pass this place up. Tip the lovely ladies making the cookies inside for taking their photos. Can't wait to come back when we visit again!
author: Anna D.

description:
Which alley way is it?

I have been wanting to visit this fortune cookie store every time I'm in Chinatown in San Francisco but could not remember the name of the business nor where it is located... all I knew was from memory of my first visit in the 90's, way before Yelp was conceived [in October 2004], that it was in a small alley way and that it was a popular spot for delicious fortune cookies. Literally a hidden gem! I finally found it again when I looked for it in Yelp during a visit to Chinatown on Christmas Day! yay! 

From the dimly lit place it did not look very big and it doesn't even look like a store, more like a manufacturing place. The lighting was poor (we arrived around 5:30ish?). There is no cash register counters or fancy display racks or cool neon signs... our transaction was done right there by the entrance. Once you walk in the metal racks filled with packaged cookies for purchase are immediately to the left. There was a table to the right and this was where an employee was packaging flat fortune cookies in individual packages. He allowed us to try samples from it, freshly made and still warm. In the same room is a female worker sitting next to a machine where she was pulling the small flat pancake-looking cookies from a conveyor belt while still warm and forming them into what we know as fortune cookie shapes. There were rows of these machines but it was a holiday and I only saw her working on one machine. She would take a fortune and insert them in the cookie and fold. She separated the reject flat ones and the formed cookies in two separate bins. I asked permission from her that allowed me to take a video while doing this process. They could be a supplier to restaurants and walk-ins were welcomed. We were the only customers here at the time.

And that's it, folks! We paid for our treats and left. Quick transaction. This place is cash only. $4 for one package of the flat fortune cookies. I also purchased a package of 'Smackles' (it had chocolate swirls). They are not formed like fortune cookies. Light, crispy, delicious. They also make them in chocolate flavored which I didn't purchase. If you must find this place it is near a bakery called Golden Gate Bakery and it seemed to be really popular as there was a loooong line waiting to purchase pastries and desserts there... my next mission!

Review #0404
author: May A.

description:
I have to give this place 5 stars.  There prices are unbeatable and cookies delicious. We stopped in to make fortune cookies for others and loved the idea of making my own fortune. Great place to take kids. Keep in mind it is a little off the beaten path. We got lost multiple times trying to use Siri and map quest. You are better off following the good old fashioned map.  

The store itself may lack ambiance but the owner and employees were very gracious and We walked away with a handful of samples.
author: Cynthia S.

description: I like purchasing the unfolded cookies! I feel like you get more bang for your buck since I usually don't really care for the messages inside. It's worth visiting if you're in the area. Not too much to see and it's a tiny space. If you're lucky, they'll throwing in some fresh warm flat cookies in your bag... mmm
author: Jane W.

description:
I've heard about this place for a while and so was glad to finally make it this week. It's worth a stop but is definitely a no frills place. It's located within a narrow space within an alleyway, and I saw one lady in front, seated and hand folding fortune cookies into a metal muffin tin. There are racks of freshly made fortune cookies and almond cookies on the left in bags.

Almost immediately I was handed a sample -- a warm, flat round circle of a pre-folded cookie that fits in the palm of your hand -- by the guy running the place, who doesn't speak English. All of a sudden my forgotten Mandarin was unleashed and I could communicate with him. It's funny how that you can remember foreign languages when you have no choice!

There are small bags of ~6  fortune cookies for $1 and larger bags for $5. Surprisingly there are paper message strips inside. Which I realized after many of them were crushed in my suitcase coming home. Next time, I'm bringing a plastic Tupperware box as Soo H suggests! At least the flavor and freshness weren't affected.

There's a sign that says "50 cents if you take a photo" which seems a bit offensive.  I think they should just charge more for their cookies.

Now I can check it off of my list of things to do in SF. Makes a great mini gift to take home and people appreciate trying what a freshly made fortune cookie tastes like. Still, I wasn't blown away by the flavor although it is definitely better than one you would get in a restaurant.

Lucky me: I beat the rush as a large tour group of 20-yo Americans came immediately after I was walking out. 

TIP: Due to the construction currently blocking the most direct route to Ross Alley, you may have to make a bit of a circle to get here.
author: Peijean T.

description:
My grandparents use to take us here when we were kids.  I have memories of driving up to Chinatown and walking inside this store with my grandma.  She would buy bags and bags and bags of fortune cookies and distribute them throughout my entire family.  Uncles, Aunties, cousins, grandchildren...etc.  everyone got fortune cookies.

When we recently visited, nothing changed. :)  Such a fun expericne walking into this fortune cookie factory.  The smell made my mouth water.  The gentleman gave us free samples to taste.  We bought the standard flat round cookies as well as almond cookies.  We love it.
author: Steve J.

description:
This was the biggest let down! I found this place on a website of tourist activities for SF and immediately wanted to go! It was a little hard to find Ross Alley because it is literally an alley. You have to find parking and walk up a big hill to be able to go down the alley. I have to be honest, if it was dark outside, I would have been scared. I guess I'm just not used to hanging out in alleys. As soon as I walked in, I realized what a big let down this was about to be.

The "factory" is a small room with a few women making cookies. You're stopped at the front by a man and he offers you a free fortune cookie. It was kinda cool because it was flat and not yet folded. (I had never seen one like that) They let you take photos for a charge. I think the sign said 50 cents. And that's it! That's the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie experience. I was extremely disappointed because I expected a factory and a tour. I do have to admit, the cookie was pretty good. However, I was so disappointed and let down that I didn't even think to buy any until I was at the airport later.
author: Michele M.

description:
When in SF - this is a must for a tourist attraction. Cool that you can place your own fortunes in the cookie right there! Samples are given freely and the man was quite generous. 
Nice to have fresh, warm, tea cookies to snack on while walking around Chinatown.
author: J O.

description:
If you're looking for fun custom made edible party favors - check out Golden Gate Fortune Cookies.

For $35 dollars  - you can get 100 individually wrapped freshly made fortune cookies filled with your own custom fortunes.  Not only are the fortune cookies well made - but they're also delicious. 

Tasty morsels of wisdom.

The staff here work hard and they are very responsive. If you're under a tight schedule - they are open to working with your time constraints.  Just be mindful that they're cash only and I would recommend E-mailing them with your order ahead of time to make sure that your custom fortunes are printed correctly. 

Golden Gate Fortune Cookies is one of those classic San Francisco businesses that produces a fantastic product on the regular  - despite the hype. Though they're perpetually busy - they are quick to pick up the phone and they are efficient at producing fantastic fortune cookies without a long wait.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description: Cool place that used to be a really neat secret. Lines out the door now, so be prepared to wait and be squeezed in to the shop. Fortune cookies were fresh and yummy though!
author: Jessica H.

description:
A must-see hidden gem!

Nestled in a hidden alley in Chinatown, this place is a hit with locals and tourists. Follow the sweet scent of fresh-baked fortune cookies into the one-room factory and you'll be greeted with a fresh-baked fortune cookie as you enter. On the wall are bunch of different fortune cookies available to purchase--chocolate, giant sized, cookies with dirty fortunes and more. Take a few more steps into the factory and watch how the fortune cookies are folded and sealed.

My absolute favorite part is the make-your-own fortune cookie option. Write your own fortunes and hand them to the ladies to fold into a fortune cookie and put in a little, customizable box. It's the perfect idea for a present and you can make as many as you want!
author: Staci L.

description:
Buy XXX-Rated Fortune Cookies made by blissfully naive hard working old Chinese Grandma's
like my wonderful Chinese Mother-in-Law.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

I happen to wander down Ross Alley, while dragging my reluctant Chinese Wife, who kept saying...."there is nothing here....there is nothing here", and thought I discovered an un-Yelped place.....ha ha...yeah right.  Since I could not find it to check in, which was weird, I took a pic of their business card to do a "first".  Well apparently it was a first for us, but not for thousands of others.  Anyway, since it was a quiet post-Halloween Monday, there were no tourists to be seen in the ancient alley & few Chinese for that matter.

Anyway, my wife is neither into Chinese history, culture, nor holes in the wall....so I had to literally beg her to come in with me....later she did love eating what we did buy there...

which are called

PIG's EARS in Chinese 

& look like a flat wavy fortune cookie chip that has swirls of dark & light cracker.... I say cracker, because like so many other Chinese Deserts, it is basically not sweet, and I found it to be too oily.

Anyway, my wife loved them when we came home to Shell Beach, and stated that they were her favorite treat as a kid....but for some reason, after all these years, she did not find them as delicious as she remembered.

ERROR PRONE GASTRONOMIC NOSTALGIA can fool one....again & again.

My wife had various theories:

1) Did her tastes change?
2) Did the Pig Ear change?
3) Was it a different formula than that used in her hometown of Tiashon eons ago?
4) Did her palate become Americanized & spoiled since she move to the USA?
5) Did her old Orangutang of a Slovak-American husband spoil her taste with too much great
expensive gourmet food over the years?

....anyway, she still enjoyed them....

but apparently she still concluded that it was my fault for some reason....
so what else is new.

Too bad, you cannot buy global general "NO-FAULT" insurance when you get married, so that 
you can be cover in these events.

No matter, I almost alway agree that it is my fault anyway....that leads to more harmony in a marriage.

~~~~~~~~~

Back to the shop.

Since we were the only ones in the shop, my wife had plenty of time to yack it up with the "boss-lady".  For some odd reason, she kept gesturing toward the X-rated fortune cookies as she kept talking to my wife.  Since my wife would totally be insulted by even the suggestion that such things even exist....let alone buy them, somehow my wife did not pay attention, nor maybe realized what X-rated Fortune Cookies meant.  Apparently, I found out later that was the case.  

The boss lady kept suggesting that I could always have custom-made fortune cookies, with my choice of sayings, more than a few times.  Obviously, those would cost a small "fortune"...pun intended.

Like many, I really enjoyed looking at the old hand making process & equipment more than the product itself.....

and thus....that is why they have a 50 cent for photos jar...both I an my wife gladly threw in a few bucks.  It was only while I was taking photos of the photo charge jar which was right by all the Chinese "Saints" figurines, that I realized that I was sinfully taking unauthorized photos...
no matter...apparently I could, since I had a charming Chinese wife with me :)

~~~~~~~~~~~~

I did favor the flat fortune cookies and bought a $5 bag of three different kinds (Regular (good), Chocolate (not so great), & Pig's Ear (wife's fav)....as well as... two bags of Almond Cookies.

THE ALMOND COOKIES TURNED OUT TO BE AMAZING!
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
& was a great hit with my co-workers at my SLO job....so fresh &
tasty.  These were far far better than any others that I have had in eons
& reminded me of the ones I loved as a NYC kid.  Like there other products, they
are freshly made with simple "wholesome" ingredients like flour, sugar, salt, water....
& did not contain any crap, that extend shelf life.

SO- TO BE A BIG HIT AT YOUR NON-BAY AREA JOB.....get a whole bunch of these
for your co-workers....I was shocked & pleased at their glowing reviews of them.

~~~~~~~~

I will be sure to stop by this little shop again, when we need another C-town fix of 
Chinese Feet Dim Sum for me, Vege Dim Sum for wifey, assorted high grade teas, assorted
"alien" things that my wife cooks with, and the ever obligatory Chinese junk that you may or may not really need....but hey... why not?

It is cheap & they surely do not sell them in the White Bread area of San Luis Obispo....not to mention that each SF trip costs a bit & is a 5-6+ hr drive each way from the mid-central coast.

~~~~

This new cookie discovery, plus the gloriously cheap & excellent Chic Feet discovery at the nearby Hole in the Wall...House of Dim Sum....will drive me this way again soon.
author: Paul M.

description: A+ for tourist show - always have someone "stagged" making fortune cookies no matter what time of day you come and they even offer free samples so A+ for service and performance.  Unfortunately their fortune cookies have that strange aftertaste to them (sugar substitute???) so I tried going up the street to Stockton & Broadway to Mee Mee Fortune Cookie Factory to see if it was my imagination.  Sure enough bought a bag from Mee Mee and ZERO after taste, the way it should be!  They were also a little cheaper but did not put on show like Golden Gate
author: Terry T.

description:
How much fun was this following our lunch?  We walked up this small little alley (which did scare one of the 6 women, but I am from Detroit - I have healthy fear and this wasn't that scarey) to the Golden Gate Fortune Cookies Company.  Small, dark, busy, crowded with the tourist, and then, BAM, you are handed a sample of the flat cookie, slightly warm, obviously made that day.  One bite and you know that you will never really like the stale, packaged cookies that come with your meal back home.  Nope.  Not ever.

This attraction takes about 5 minutes to see, watch, and buy a bag of cookies to take home with you.

And they are yummy with peanut butter and bacon for breakfast!
author: Liz T.

description: Kind-of-fun tourist trap.  Yes, it is a factory. Yes, they make fortune cookies which is something one doesn't ordinarily see. Yes, you get a free sample. No, it's not very big.  The factory's output is probably just enough to keep the local Chinatown merchants stocked, but I can't imagine that these cookies are going too far from home.  If you're visiting SF, it's worth 5 minutes of your tour of Chinatown.
author: Al T.

description: Love this place, it is in an ally and you can smell the selicious cookies before you arrive, just follow your nose.
author: J.V. S.

description:
I love the fortune cookies here! Try to avoid going when tour groups come; this is the only time I've had to wait in line. It's in a shady looking alleyway, but don't worry too much!
I always buy a couple bags to bring back home when I'm up in SF.
author: Katie C.

description: So cute and so fun- we made our own fortunes. Definitely go in with a plan so you don't panic on the spot and don't have any cute/funny fortunes to write, they file you in and or very quickly!
author: Amelia H.

description:
This is a neat idea. super cute. cash only.
Busy busy when we went. But what can you expect, it's chinatown. tourist area galore.
we came in on a wednesday, grabbed a couple cookies. they literally have a jar with blank paper and you write your message. then as soon as you blink, all done-paper in cookie and bye.
author: francis c.

description:
We went in here really quickly, just because it was a famous tourist attraction in Chinatown. We stayed less than five minutes. We did get free samples of hot fortune cookies, which are better x100 BTW.

It was cool to see the ladies sitting there and making fortune cookies by hand with the help of a machine. I watched for a few minutes, but the place is very small and I probably would not have been able to stand there for very long.

Nevertheless, the employees were nice. The one thing I saw here that was unique was that you can buy a really huge fortune cookie!
author: Nikki Rose T.

description: A must-see when I visit San Francisco.  I love coming down the small alley to find a fortune cookie shop with piping hot flat/pre-molded fortune cookie samples!  I bought the small flat cookies to take home with me.  The small cookies are easier to eat than the larger ones and they stay crispy and fresh for days!  Great to share with the family in LA.  If you take a picture they want you to pay 50 cents so be ready to pay... or be a ninja with your camera.  But you should just buy some fresh cookies!  They also have chocolate fortune cookies and erotic adult fortune cookies haha.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
here we can get freshest fortune cookies and golden coin cookies. They offered 2 flavor : vanilla/original and chocolate. The factory door is located in the alley inside china town, so it could be tricky for first timer.
When I was visiting, there was a grandpa standing at the entrance and said : NO PICTURES INSIDE! But I read the latest review that they allow to take pictures finally with some donations.
author: Loena Loeloeh L.

description: Don't expect a factory tour or a thorough history of how the fortune cookie came to be invented. This is not what this is. This is a tight space with a few Chinese ladies making a lot of fortune cookies. You walk in 10 steps, you walk out 10 steps. There is no thrills to be had here. If you're in the area and you love fortune cookies, go take a look inside, but this is not meant to be a tourist attraction. With that said, I got a box of fresh fortune cookies with custom messages for my boyfriend. I filled it with messages like, "today is your lucky day - free back message coming your way". And it was only $1 for a small box. A good place for souvenirs. :)
author: Betty W.

description:
Even if the fortune cookies tasted like garbage (you know, like most fortune cookies), I would still love this place. Where else can you get commission 100 custom-made cookies* and have them made within the hour? Where else can you handwrite a fortune for someone special in your life, and pretend like it was difficult to get it done?

But the fortune cookies don't taste like garbage. They are the tastiest fortune cookies you've ever tasted, probably because they are hot off the presses in what really does look like a fortune cookie sweatshop. 

Assuming the folks making the cookies aren't slaves, this place rocks.
_____________

*You have to provide the fortunes.
author: Peter D.

description: I don't love fortune cookies...but I loved these.  Fresh hot fortune cookies are a whole different ball game and they are the only ones playing it!  DO NOT MISS the strawberry and green tea cookies (I prefer strawberry).  It's the best thing that'll happen to you walking down an alley.
author: Tom T.

description:
Yahweh: You've been unhappy because you've desired things that cannot be.
Lucifer: That's what desire IS. The need for what we can't have. The need for what's readily available is called greed.
Mike Carey - Lucifer

friend:  Why are you going to San Francisco for fortune cookies?  They are nasty!
me:  You never had a fortune cookie that is still hot and fresh out of the machine.  You are correct that the fortune cookies you eat at cheap Chinese restaurants that have been sitting in shrink wrap for months in the store room are nasty.
friend:  Oh...
me:  If I had one wish it would be to get fresh fortune cookies out of the machine anytime I wanted.
friend:  So can you bring me back some fortune cookies?

This place has the best fortune cookies I have ever eaten.  Step inside and the owner will offer you a fresh cookie right out of the machine.  Pay the fee and take a photo.  It's worth it to have a souvenir of how fortune cookies are made.  Empty your mind and experience a fresh cookie.  The crunchy texture, the delicious flavor.  There are few things better in life.  They have flat ones.  They have regular folded ones with fortunes.  There is a tiny difference in flavor due to the addition of paper to the hot cookie.  I get both kinds and stick them in tupperware so the cookies don't get crushed in my suitcase.  Keep them in tupperware and they stay fresh about a month.  :-)  One month a year I can experience the bliss of fresh fortune cookies.  :-)
author: Soo H.

description:
Absolutely historic factory in a very old building in the alley. 

This is one of the "tourist attraction" places that our hotel suggested. Oh~ yes, many tourists all show up here, some even came with tour guide. 

It is a very small shop/factory, making fortune cookies. It is interesting to see how the machine operates. Only 3 staffs needed to operate the machine. 

The staffs are very friendly and even offer us samples. They do sell different kind of cookies, very reasonable price.
author: Cassandra Y.

description:
Awesome to see how they are made and to be able to taste a fresh one right of the press.  Black and white cookies were great. 

Caution: tight spaces and they charge you .50 per
author: James B.

description: Cool tourist spots! Try the samples that are fresh and warm! If you've never had a warm fortune cookie, definitely stop here and get a sample. We also bought a bag of the xrated ones which should be fun to open haha
author: Lysa D.

description:
I think this "factory" is worth a stop in for a few minutes if you're in Chinatown. It's a little hard to find because it's not really much of a factory, it's actually just a room in an alley with a large fortune cookie machine in it and a few people working.

That said, it is pretty cool to see how they're made, you get a fresh sample, and can buy a fresh bag for pretty cheap.

They do ask for 50 cents if you want to take a picture, which I don't think is a big deal.
author: Elena K.

description: Love the fortune cookies and cow ear crackers!!! So delicious!! The cow ear crackers aren't actually made from cow ears, it's just the name of it. You can't get cow ear crackers that tastes so good anywhere else!!
author: Susan L.

description:
Located in Ross alley in Chinatown. It is a pretty tiny place in a little alley. The place gets packed with customers but luckily I got in before the rush. There is an old man in the front providing samples and helping customers. Towards the middle to the back you can see the workers making fresh cookies.

You can make your own fortune cookies, grab various size bags of regular fortune cookies, chocolate fortune cookies, or almond cookies. They also have bags of X-rated fortunes for those adventurous ones.

The cookies here are amazing! They are great fresh and will get stale after a few days of leaving it out. Very cheap tourist stop when in Chinatown and a great place to fill up on snacks. There's not too much to see here so I was in and out in about 5-10 minutes.
author: Michael C.

description:
Almost every summer since I was born, my family and I would take a week-long trip out to San Francisco to see our relatives.  Living in a tiny cramped apartment on Washington and Ross are my grandparents.  The scent of vanilla perfumes their place from their third floor window.  Enter Golden Gate Fortune Cookies!

From as far back as I can remember, my parents and I would cut through Ross Alley to get to other destinations like ABC Bakery and dim sum places.  Every time we walked by, I'd tried to drag my parents in to buy me some Smackles [AKA elephant ears] or flat-shaped fortune cookies.  My parents were never interested in the tourist traps, as they were in town for good eats and dried goods to bring back home, so my grandparents would sneak off with my brothers and me later on so I can get some goodies for the long 12-hr car trip back to Arizona.

Loud ladies folding cookies by hands are definitely more of a tourist attraction but it's still a mesmerizing sight.  Even now as an adult, I stop in whenever I'm visiting my grandparents to see the old ladies bending and manipulating round flat cookies into the pinched shapes everyone is accustomed to.  While this small discreet shop is tucked away at the cove of an alley, be sure to stop in if you're in Chinatown!  Bring some cash and buy some treats.  Don't be ornery and scoff at this small tourist attraction.  The smell of freshly baked cookies alone is worth it [oppose to the trash smell that seems to permeates everywhere else in Chinatown].
author: Joyce W.

description: My wife who is Chinese for some reason insists on coming here every time we visit San Francisco.  We are always the only Asians in line......Don't get me wrong the fortune cookies are great but at the end of the day, they are only fortune cookies.   They taste pretty much like the thousands of fortune cookies we've all had growing up. You don't see much of a factory and the lines are ridiculous.  There's an older Chinese gentlemen who plays American classics such  as Yankee Doodle and the national anthem on a Chinese string instrument for everyone waiting in line.   It might be interesting to go check out if you're touring China town but no need to go out of your way to go there.  I don't see what the big deal is.
author: Kobe K.

description: The owner is a bully that yells are his elderly employees in front of customers. Regardless of the reason it was wrong!
author: Michael C.

description:
This place is not a factory in the usual sense of the word.  It's more like a bakery with machines, which produce round soft cookies quickly molded into a crescent fortune cookie shape after an employee slips in a fortune.  The cookie is delicious and the bakery sells varieties of fortune cookies.  

I assumed it's okay to take a picture of employees making the cookies since there's a sign in front of the machines to pay 50 cents for picture taking.  But when I took a photo, the employee who I took a picture of seemed displeased.  I deleted the picture out of respect for her after I left.  So if you would like to take a photo of any of the workers, please note, that you should ask permission from who you would like to photograph.  This should be done in general.
author: Jane D.

description: Aaaaaaahhhhh! Fortune cookie lovers rejoice! Although tucked away and was once unknown to most, this place ROCKS! Made right in front of your eyes, watch an amazing show as fortune cookies are made from scratch. Eat em as they're hot or take some bags to go, it's perfect either way!
author: Alexander D.

description:
A tiny little shop tucked in an alley in Chinatown, with the most amazing selection of fortune cookies in different sizes, shapes and flavors.  You can watch the cookies be made, take a photo of the place (for a nominal donation) and sample warm, fresh fortune cookies!  
I took home several bags for myself and gifts for friends and family, and was rewarded with a large handful of free samples (20 cookies?) in my bag that I munched as I walked up and down the hills of San Francisco all day!
Very friendly place, great cookies and a cheap gift to take home to the family!
author: Jen A.

description:
My family has been coming here for years to pick up fresh fortune cookies. It has since become a tourist attraction but we do stop by every once in awhile to pick up our favorite flat, coin size fortune cookies. The smell of fresh, fortune cookies can lead anyone to Ross Alley. This is the real deal here. They still use their old school machines and fold them by hand. 

For $3.50, you can pick up a bag of small, flat fortune cookies. No matter what you buy, they always throw in a handful of fresh off the machine large flat fortune cookies. This is definitely my go to place for fortune cookies. This can not compare to any of the cheap fortune cookies you get with Chinese take out. Once you've had this, there's no going back.

Note: CASH ONLY.
author: Steph F.

description: This was one of the coolest things I saw in San Fran. I walked down a little alleyway to find fresh fortune cookies being made that you could customize with your own messages on the spot. So cool for a small gift for family and friends!
author: Monya O.

description: We ventured through the streets of Chinatown to check out this special place that has been making fortune cookies for years! The smell of fresh cookies filled the little shop. We were excited to see these cookies freshly made and assembled right in front of our eyes. The crowd quickly grew but not before we picked up a bag of our favorite chocolate and plain cookies. We can't wait to read our fortunes. They even tossed in a handful of warm flat cookies into our bag. Thanks for the crunchy disks. Sweet!
author: M S E.

description:
I really liked this place. Very cool experience for those who are both new to SF and local. I had never never been before and my cousin from out of town suggested we see it. 

I followed him down a sketchy looking alley and really thought we were going the wrong way but sure enough there was a 20ish person long line coming out of the little fortune cookie shop. There was a guy playing violin there which was very SF-ish but really cool either way. 

 The sample cookies were fresh and the line moved quickly considering how long it was. They tasted great, way better than any other fortune cookie I've had before. 

My only gripe with this place was the employee doing the samples seemed like she was in a really bad mood. I felt like she gave a stare that pierced my soul when I asked. Maybe I'm over exaggerating or maybe she was in a bad mood but either way it really didn't detract that much from the experience. 

All in all I would return and I would recommend this place to tourists.
author: Lacey C.

description:
This place has been here for as long as I remember.  It hasn't changed a bit.  Not even a face lift that I can tell.  Golden Gate Fortune Cookies (GGFC) stays old-school.  The workers place the fortune slips on the soft cookies and fold them by hand.  There's a reason why they don't upgrade their equipment.  Tourists love stuff like this.  I have a hunch they won't automate their production line any time soon.  That's right, the last thing you want is to mess up the feng shui!

Once upon a time, they wouldn't bother when you took pictures.  Then, they got fed up with the flashes and started telling people, "No buy, no photo."   These days, a sign is posted that reads $0.50 for taking photos.  I don't know if the price is per shot.  

I wouldn't go out of my way but when friends visit from out of town, Chinatown is an obligatory stop. Then, we'll swing by GGFC for some fresh cookies.  I usually pick up a couple of bags of the rejects for myself.  The rejects are cookies that didn't get folded. Still taste the same. They work well with Nutella or Biscoff.
author: Allen C.

description:
Down a kind of dark ally between Jackson and Washington is this tiny business, it feels like a hold over from another time.  Started in 1962 the company still makes the cookies with machines that look like they could be in a museum and folds them by hand.  You can also by the unfolded cookies here for less.  If you are like most people and have only had cookies in restaurants, you should taste the fresh ones... They are so much better.  

From the looks of the place the machines are probably original, and the staff may be also. A large bag of folded cookies costs $5, the unfolded ones  $3 (but what is the fun in that?) and pictures of the staff 50 cents each.   Cookies come in regular and chocolate.

It is a fun experience to come here,  it feels different then the tourist parts of China town even though there is usually a line of tourists trying to come in.   Inside the tight space you work your way to the back of the public area to watch the experts fold cookies.  They have to go fast as the cookies harden almost immediately after they come off the griddle. 

They also have signs that you can supply your own messages for a fee. I have also seen messages geared towards bachelor/bachelorette parties and thing like those.  

Tip: don't worry if there is a line, there isn't much to see so the line moves fast.
author: Mark B.

description:
When my sister told me I had to check this place out on my trip to San Fran I legitimately just laughed and thought it was going to be such a waste of time. Truth is, it takes like 5 minutes out of your Chinatown trip and is extremely interesting. In one of the many cool alleys around Chinatown this spot is a little sketchy at first because it kind of looks like a sweatshop...a bunch of older Asians sitting down at their stations with their heads down but once you're greeted with a tray of free samples the mood changes completely. 

They have thousands of traditional forture cookies for sale and they even have chocolate flavored! If you're lucky you can get them when they're warm,  so it's safe to say that I am a fan of their end product. My GF bought a couple of bags to bring home but we ended up eating most befor getting on our plane :s oops! 

As many have said it's $.50 for a picture but just give them a dollar and take as many as you want, you really only need a couple haha. It's a really cute and cool place that is so easy to visit if you're in the area. As I mentioned it only takes about 5 minutes.
author: Kenny O.

description: This is a must stop if you are visiting SF, especially with the kids. The line was put the door when we arrived on Saturday around 4. The line moved quickly and they handed out samples while we waited. Once inside you can watch o e of the ladies use the machine to form the cookie and put in your own fortune message. It's a quick experience but we snapped a quick pic for .50 cents and retrieved our cookies and we were on our way.
author: Jennifer O.

description: The ladies that are here are very nice. The cookies are delicious, and after buying two bags of cookies, she threw in a handful of the sample disks. Highly recommend! Also, the "alley" is not scary at all. It's down on your left. Enjoy!!!
author: Sarah R.

description: Superb fortune cookies... They're made fresh baked and folded right in front of you. We got a few free samples too, which the woman there straight up stuffed into the bag my girlfriend and I bought.
author: Robert L.

description: I visited today for the first time, and I will make sure to visit when I'm back in SF. Delicious free samples and good prices!
author: Maria C.

description: This place was great! I found it on a blog and we decided we had to check it out during our trip. The family who runs the place is super friendly. Be ready because they will be giving you more hot off the press fortune cookies than you can hold. It's a quick thing to see and such a cool place to walk through. They allow as many pictures as you want, but do ask for a dollar donation. Seemed more than fair, especially for the amount of free cookies they will be giving you.
author: Jennifer M.

description: Oh for F's sake. They are fortune cookies, they are great, and when you come here they are amazing fresh, before they are even folded into the shape that we all know them to be, yummy as can be. The part I like best is the x rated fortunes, get them, they don't make sense, but you will have a blast of a time trying to figure out what they are supposed to mean.
author: C W.

description:
Gamble today. You married the right one. Go to Vegas tomorrow.

What do all of these statements have in common? ... They're all custom fortunes that I was able to have inserted into hand folded fortune cookies for my father's birthday.

This was a last minute gift idea, so if I had it to do over again I'd take some time to be more creative and I'd try to write more clearly. I'm proud of myself for being able to follow directions on the signs because that seemed to be the biggest reason for the long line to get inside. Fair warning: everyone is judging you! Edward L.'s Mandarin isn't the best, but he was able to understand what the employees were saying about the people who couldn't figure out what was going on.
author: David K.

description:
I never expected to be impressed by fortune cookies before, but Golden Gate Fortune Cookie proved me wrong. It's in this tiny alleyway and if I hadn't looked it up, I wouldn't have even thought to walk in there. Upon entering, this fine gentlemen opened up a tin with flattened fortune cookies, and thrust it in my face. I'm a pretty cautious person when I'm traveling, so I had to confirm if they were samples...and they were :) 

Everyone in our group grabbed a piece, and they were really flavorful. Typically, fortune cookies that come with Chinese takeout are pretty damn bland and tasteless, I eat them like I drink water. These fortune cookies had some magic crack sprinkled in there or something. 

It was really awesome to see a few ladies actually working on a fortune cookie assembly line in there too. There was this conveyor belt going on in the back, and these ladies were folding and forming the cookies as it went along. Be warned that they don't let you take a picture unless you pay 50 cents; there's even a sign posted up in there that says so. Yeah...not worth it for me. 

They have a bunch of the cookies on sale, and I grabbed 2 huge bags of those flattened cookies for about $3.50 each. The guy working there even threw in a couple of handfuls of their flattened samples for good measure :) My parents were pretty shocked that a fortune cookie could taste that good when they tried them too. Let's just say that bag was gone really fast. My sister is supposed make fortune cookie ice cream with the extra bag, so we'll see when that happens. It's been 2 months already -_-
author: Matthew L.

description: Always hard to find because it is not on the main two roads of Chinatown, Grant and Stockton. If you want junk and gifts, walk Grant. if you want groceries and the real Chinatown, walk Stockton. I digress. My first visit her was when I was young, maybe nine years old. I was fascinated, and totally blown away, to see that one small smiling woman created thousands and thousands of cookies with such a simple, yet perfect procedure. I remember Dad saying ti was time to go but  wanted to watch forever as she peeled the hot dough from the griddle, deftly grabbed a fortune from this gigantic box, laid the tiny piece of paper against the now cooked dough and swiftly, agilely folded the cookie just so, and seconds before it hardened, dropped it onto a conveyor type chute where it cheerfully bobbed along and fell into the box with its hundreds of brothers and sisters. A mandatory stop if you are headed for Chinatown. 2017 summer note: Never ever ever ever have we waited in line. This year, oh my, the line went out to Jackson and then some.
author: Anne S.

description:
Gotta go with a 4 star for this place. The business looks like it's been operating in the same manner since it's inception.
The lady making the regular (they also make chocolate) fortune cookies has been doing it for like 40 years. She's the expert on fortune cookies.
There can be a small line to get inside, but don't let that stop you. It moves fast since it's a small operation. They also had out flat (unfolded) cookies that if your lucky are nice and warm. 
They sell a bags of cookies for 5 dollars or so. Grabbed a bag of x-rated adult fortunes. They haven't been dirty just slighlty more adult such as: Fu Ling Yu says the length of a lover's leap is the distance between 2 beds. 
All in all, very satisfied.
author: Zachary H.

description:
...another place I've been meaning to check out since moving to SF.
I was super excited and planning a self-guided mini tour through Chinatown. It was busy as I had expected but the service was pretty lacking. Two younger girls were making the flat cookies into their fortune cookie shape and not friendly at all. With no one directing customers anywhere, I didn't even really understand what I was standing in the line for. I grabbed a box of mixed cookies, paid and left. No smiles or thank yous...
author: Leina K.

description:
Best fortune cookies EVER.
Guaranteed!
Located in a small alleyway, but you will know which one when you see plenty of people... mostly tourists haha, walking in and out of the alleyway. They are more than happy to give you plenty of fresh samples to try and you will have bags of fortune cookies in your hands in no time. 

THEY NOW HAVE X-RATED FORTUNE COOKIES! I just got them for the first time. Get your bag of X-RATED cookies to find out what your fortune says haha.

Lets just say I come here every time I visit SF... WORTH IT! I buy tons to bring back for family and friends too! Okay, maybe no the X-rated ones for the family, but my homies love em HAHA!
author: Andrew S.

description: This is a tiny, cute little place. Whenever I'm showing out of towners through Chinatown, I often take them there. You can see how fortune cookies are made, eat a hot one, and buy some if you like. And it takes about 2 minutes to see it "all."
author: Jason P.

description:
I've had a lot of fortune cookies in my life, and I have to say I have NEVER EATEN A BETTER FORTUNE COOKIE. No place even mildly approaches the FLAVOR, the TEXTURE, and the LOOK of the fortune cookies at Golden Gate Fortune Cookie Factory. 

The FLAVOR is super LIGHT and SWEET--it leaves the most pleasant aftertaste in your mouth that I've never, ever experienced before in another fortune cookie. I have never tasted such a good fortune cookie in my life. 

The TEXTURE is immaculately FLUFFY and LIGHT--other fortune cookies fail in this aspect because they're usually very dense and stale.

And finally, the LOOK of it is just amazing--it's nice and golden brown, slightly shiny, and very signature of this particular company's fortune cookie. The other fortune cookies that I've eaten look too grainy or too dark or light. 

THIS IS THE GOLD STANDARD FOR FORTUNE COOKIES. HANDS DOWN NO DOUBT ABOUT IT THE BEST. 

(Side note, who in their right mind called this establishment Golden Gate Fortune Cookies when they created the Yelp profile for this business?! It LITERALLY SAYS GOLDEN GATE FORTUNE COOKIE FACTORY on the sign outside. The person that created this weirdo name for Yelp didn't even have the integrity to lift their brainless head up to check the name of the place, which CLEARLY SAYS Golden Gate Fortune Cookie Factory!) 

To mere mortals (ahem, people that haven't eaten this fortune cookie sent from the gods), this is just some silly novelty that has a little quirky saying and some lottery numbers in the back. But to me, this is the representation of EAST meets WEST, of a CAREFULLY CRAFTED and meticulous FLAVOR that has STOOD THE TEST OF TIME. It represents my San Franciscan native culture and upbringing. I've eaten these fortune cookies since I was 5 years old and I still come back to buy some of this fluffy goodness whenever I visit SF Chinatown. 

Situated in the heart of historic SF Chinatown, Golden Gate Fortune Cookies resides in Ross Alley, one of the most hackneyed and iconic images of SF Chinatown. It's not super clean, but you know you're at the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie Factory when you see a whole bunch of tourists standing in front. I'm not exactly a fan of tourists traps, but this is a huge exception. NEVER FEAR, GO INSIDE ANYWAY.

After you push yourself through the crowd of tourists, you realize that It's quite a small place and it's not much too look at...except the SUPER COOL FORTUNE COOKIE MACHINE, the old Chinese ladies that really know how to quickly man the machine and take the little pieces of goodness and fold them into fortune cookies, the huge variety of fortune cookies, the SMELL OF IMPENDING GREATNESS, the free samples, and of course, the $1.00 payment (or did they up the price? Yikes!) for pictures...ok maybe that's just a bit annoying any probably why I didn't take pictures of the inside. 

Regardless, pick what you like, I usually go for the flat round ones since I'm there for the taste, not the fortunes or chance of winning the lotto. But if I'm grabbing some for friends that haven't had the chance to taste this greatness, I'll buy some of them with the fortunes. They price is around $4.50-$5 per bag, but it's well worth it. You get at least 20 of the folded ones for the $4.50 and at least 30-40 pieces in the flat fortune cookies bag. After you pop one into your mouth, you won't be able to stop--they're addicting.   

TASTE: 5 stars--the best fortune cookie I've ever tasted.
SERVICE: 3-4 stars--I love the free samples they slap into your bag. They aren't the most cheerful people, but no complaints.
TOTAL: 5 stars--although the people could be a little more cheerful, this fortune cookie is unrivaled, so I have to give a rare 5 stars. 

Bottom Line: Gold standard for Fortune Cookies. I dare you to try other fortune cookies after this one and private message me if you've found something better. I'm coming here to get fortune cookies until I die.
author: Andrew C.

description:
It's a tiny outfit in an ally in Chinatown, but friendly welcoming storefront. They serve you freshly made fortune cookies. You could take pics for 50 cents. 
+ free to "tour" (takes no more than 15 minutes. Maybe even just 5 if no one else is visiting)
+ friendly
+ fun to watch how fortune cookies are made
+ pleasant smell of pancakes welcomes you into the alley (freshly made fortune cookies smell like pancakes or baked goodness)
+ added bonus: a man from the next door barber shop busted out his violin and played nursery music and Christmas songs for the kids

Out-of-towners: for parking, we found a convenient parking structure a few streets away, maybe just a five minute walk. If you enjoy kitchen or candy factory-type tours, this is a fun, quick trip. Then you can peruse Chinatown knick knacks, herbs, teas, dim sum, etc after. I would come back again. With my kids or someone else's ;)
author: Dot B.

description:
Love this hidden gem in Ross alley off of Jackson Street.  We've been here several times on our visits to the "Golden Hill".  We always pickup a few bags of the fortune cookie disks to snack on and bring back as goodies for family. 

Upon each visit and purchase, they always throw in a bunch of disks for free into your bag.  Very cool.  Will be back again.
author: Iakona C.

description:
I always have these stocked in my kitchen.  They are hands down the best fortune cookies ever.  Simply no contest.  My favorite are the flat original ones (I tend to try to look for a bag that's a bit more golden brown because I love the bolder vanilla flavor that seems to shine through vs. the lighter ones); although the chocolate ones are also good.  

Always fresh (made that day, if not moments before you buy them!), always delicious.  

I used to live in Russian Hill and this place was on my walk home from work, so way more convenient to stop in than now (I currently live in the Mission).  However, when I run low, I make sure to make a special stop in to stock up again.  

Highly recommend.  Do yourselves a favor and stop in here (even if you HATE the crowds and tourists that are littered throughout this area!).  It's worth the 10-15 minutes of misery.
author: Rachael S.

description: It's really cool to see how the cookies are made. $.50 to take a picture and you can buy cookies there, chocolate or regular. Definitely a place to check out in Chinatown
author: Ashley S.

description:
Yes, seriously, a little hole off a side street in Chinatown gets a 5 star rating. And they earned it.

For anyone visiting San Francisco, budget 5-10 minutes out of your trip to Chinatown to stop by the Golden Gate Fortune Cookies company. It's off a small alleyway, so you can't drive right up to it. During the summer, I was told that lineups can extend out the door, but when we went on a wet January evening, there was no one there.

You will be offered a chance to eat an unrolled (yes, they actually roll fortune cookies) fortune cookie that was literally made a few minutes ago. You will get to watch some lovely women hand-craft thousands of fortune cookies per day.  You can also write a personalized fortune, and have these ladies roll your very own fortune cookie souvenir for less than $2.50.

This is SF as its best.
author: Jason A.

description:
Not at all what I expected. That or it was just a kinda surreal experience for me. 
Going in, we were greeted right away, and then we see other tourists taking pictures beside workers. That was certainly amusing. 
What was cool was seeing the assembly line or cookie baking machine, and the variety of fortune cookies they had. 
Service was cool. We didn't get to talk to the assembly line staff, but they were certainly having small conversations with the tourists. The greeter was also cool. Gave us fresh cookies (literally warm) to sample, and it was yummy! Hahaha... He gave us more since we purchased a couple bags too.
author: Agnes S.

description:
This is the ONLY place to get your fresh fortune cookies.  The place is a little hard to find, down a narrow alley in the middle of Chinatown, but worth the search.  Not only do they have the typical fortune cookies, you can customize the messages of your cookies, or pick up a large bag of the flat round ones (the ones that didn't make it to the folders, or are a little misshapen).  
The taste and texture of their cookies are 20X better than any you get at the end of a Chinese restaurant meal ---- super crispy and not too sweet.
The owners always stuff a handful of the flat cookies in your bag if you purchase at least a couple of bags.  
Even though this is a factory, do not expect a factory tour.  In fact, they don't even like you hanging around or taking photos of the workers.  You are there to buy fortune cookies, and if you don't, they don't make you feel very welcome.
author: Wendy W.

description: Been here 200 or so times over 45 years. You buy the flat fortune cookies that weren't warm enough to get to the bending machine wheel for about $4.00 for a big bag of them! WE paid $1.50 in high school then used them to pitch to each other in our roommate pad in college and break and shatter them with a small plastic baseball bat for about a half hour of college entertainment! it was worth the buck fifty. The photos they used to have in Ross alley of famous movie stars et walking through to visit the little narrow long shop was a tourist landmark for decades! Hummm,from the photos looks like you pay $5.000 a bag and for less weight as well as of course the good old 80's!
author: Brian D.

description: We wrote our own fortune cookie message hidden in the cookies that cost only $1.5 for 2 with a miniature Chinese take out box.  They also have different flavoured fortune cookies, Almond , strawberry etc.  and the gigantic cookie.  I like their unfold cookie which is crunchy and tasty.  The owner was super nice.  He handed out so much samples and put extras in our bag.  My daughter couldn't stop eating them.  I will definitely recommend to our friends.
author: Emily W.

description:
Pretty cool place!  It was easy to find-- from the entrance to Chinatown on Grant/Bush, walk down Grant to Jackson.  Turn left on Jackson.  Two alleys later take another left.  Look for a small yellow sign that identifies the place.
As other reviewers have written, this is a very small business.   You can literally be in and out in 5 minutes and still leave with that feeling of seeing something very cool.
Definitely a slice of life not to be missed.
author: Thomas D.

description: Omg I'm in heaven! My secret love is fresh fortune cookies. After coming here a few times before I needed my fix. You would never know it existed if you were just walking around . it's in this small alley on a side street. This place looks like something straight out of the movies. You walk in and you get greeted by this sweet little lady who is pushing the hell out of those cookies. I always go for the flat ones and xrated adult fortunes always fun for the office. If you take a  look around you see the ladies working. This place is a true little factory. Today was very fitting because around the corner someone was filming a movie based in the late 60s. This place is a must try fit those visiting the city. Everything is super fresh and the prices are great. I failed to notice if it's cash only because when ever I'm in china town I assume everything is.
author: Tony B.

description:
You are in and out real quick. It's mighty warm in the place. You are given warm fortune cookies while you wait to get in. It's a fun and free experience! 

We got a bag of X Rated cookies (we are adults, lol) and the first two cookies were the exact same fortune. That was mighty disappointing. But the cookies were so delicious and extremely better than the ones we get at home.
author: Erin D.

description: So interesting enough, I found this place on yelp! I was in San Francisco for a few days and wanted to find things to do. If you're in San Francisco and in the China town area, I would stop by. It is a super small shop, literally you walk in and bammmn thats pretty much it. Anyway, very authentic little shop interesting but never the less insightful. Never knew how easy it is to make fortune cookies. Anyway, it was kinda cool you can pay $1 to customize two fortune cookies with any little quotes you can fit on the little paper. Also, my boyfriend thought it would be cool to put $1 bills inside the fortune cookie as souvenirs for his coworkers. The ladies that work here are super sweet. Cookies are real inexpensive, fresh and crisp. Overall, it was a cool little spot.
author: Evelyn G.

description: Golden Gate Fortune Cookie factory in SF, makes the "BEST" fortune cookies in the US (in my opinion.) Always a treat for my friends. We like the round flat ones (w/o the fortune...faster to eat)
author: Rowland W.

description:
Sometimes hidden gems are found in out of the way places. Golden Gate Fortune Cookie is one such place,located down the type of alley you would not want to be walking alone through. During my time in Chinatown I was actually looking for dim sum when my trusty Yelp app pulled up this business. Always interested in an adventure I made my way to the address and because there was no number on the door walked by it twice.

However once I found it and walked in, I was transported to another time and as I admired the hand folding of each individual fortune cookie I was given a sample to try as I watched.
