It was quite tasty and I purchased some of the unformed flat wafers to munch on throughout the afternoon.  They also had chocolate ones but I am a purest and had to go with the original flavor.

 Great hidden gem. I am so glad I found this place as it gave me a new appreciation for these little gems that we all get with our Chinese take out.
author: Anne C.

description:
Five stars for authenticity. If you are accustomed to stale fortune cookies wrapped in cellophane don't come here.  Everything is fresh and made on site.  

This shop is located in historic Ross Alley. If you read the history of this spot you will know that this area has changed for the better in the last 100 years given the unsavory businesses that previously existed here.

Excellent way to experience San Francisco's contribution to the American version of Chinese cuisine--the fortune cookie.  This is a must see.
author: Robert D.

description:
Cons: The website said there is a free tour. THERE WAS NO TOUR. The place is tiny. They allow max 10 people. We had a group of 10 girls and 10 moms so we took turns waiting outside. They were rude to us and did not allow us to take our time and browse through their products. Still, every one of us bought items from there. 
Pros: we all got samples of warm fortune cookie. The cookies are delicious! The products are reasonably priced.
author: Missy R.

description: I made the trek out here because my friend requested I bring her some, as she claimed they were the best fortune cookies ever. So I brought home a few bags of these cookies and they lasted for about a month, and they still tasted pretty fresh and good after a month! For some reason, the circle/flat ones taste better. I appreciated the free samples too -- he gives you a lot! This is a must visit in Chinatown and you can also see a lot of tour groups pass by here.
author: Mary T.

description:
It was shortly after dark.  My wife and I were on a self-guided walking tour of Chinatown, with step-by-step directions.  Even with said directions, it took us two tries to find Ross Alley, where Golden Gate Fortune Cookies allegedly existed.  Ross Alley was a tiny, dark patch of asphalt straight out of a Mickey Spillane novel.  Dark, quiet, looming . . .

About half-way down what was nothing more than a path, there was light shining into the alley.  It was oddly mysterious, so we took our chances.  In the back of my head, a little voice was saying, "Don't fly into the light!"  We did, and indeed the light was the destination we were looking for, where we were treated to quite a wonderful experience!

Small does not begin to describe the place.  It is long and narrow, with a few steel racks on the left, a counter on the right, and two odd-looking contraptions that are reminiscent of the machines in "The Sneetches," by Dr. Seuss.  At each of the machines sat a woman with magic hands folding fortunes into cookies and placing them into custom cookie holders.
 
When we entered, we were exuberantly greeted by the dude who runs the place.  He gave us samples of warm, pre-bent cookie wafers and invited us in to look around.  Schmoley, were the cookies FANTASTIC!

We were allowed to watch as long as we wanted, take photos, and asked a whole bunch of questions.  We were stunned and amazed.  The whole process was simple, yet mesmerizing.  Everyone was polite as they could be and we had a blast.

We were probably there a total of 20 minutes, but we talked to the guy who runs the place for around 10 minutes.  It was easily the best 20 minutes we spent in Chinatown.  It was truly a unique experience, and for around $10 we got personalized cookies that we wrote our own fortunes into, a box of mixed-flavor cookies, two bags of flat cookie rounds, and two packs of almond cookies . . . all warm off the presses.  We also had cool stories to tell everyone back home!

This is a can't miss place if you are in Chinatown!  And, it's FREEEEEEE!
author: Michael S.

description: If you're​ visiting Chinatown you MUST stop by the fortune cookie factory! It's a tiny lil place with limited occupancy inside so you might see a line forming in the small alley. Trust me, there's a huge difference between fortune cookies at a Chinese restaurant and these fresh ones at the factory! You can get delicious hot cookies here as samples and buy them in bags for $5!
author: Amy V.

description: Super Fresh! love the fortune cookies here. When you buy some they give you handful's of the rejects... winning!!!!!
author: Erica K.

description:
I am mortified! I was helping my niece with her "Flat Stanley" project and took it to what I thought was a gem spot in the city. I explained to the woman (young adult daughter who understood and spoke English about the project). Especially for the fact that my niece was in 4th grade. Without knowing I guess I ended up buying the X rated fortune cookies... 

They were handed out in my niece's classes room and the teacher was shocked! I was never told they were xrated... Naively picked out the mix color bags, "cool they make chocolate ones, the kids would love it..." 

Please, please, please watch out for the X rated fortunes. It totally shadowed the work I did for the project and embarrassed my niece! I am furious that I wasn't told, or warned by the lady... I didn't see a sign! It was a mistake and never did I ever expect that...
author: Erica M.

description:
Quick note: it's in a dinghy alley that looks kinda sketch but definitely worth going to...

This is definitely a must see if you're a tourist wondering around in Chinatown. Even if you're not a tourist, you should still go anyways for the fresh fortune cookies... Even though it is a super touristy thing to do. 

They hand make all their fortune cookies and it's pretty cool to see how they make it. The workers are so fast and they make it look really easy. They do charge you if you take pictures though ($0.50 I think) ... So either commit what you see to memory or bring some spare change to pay. 

The owner is super nice and gives you free samples of the cookie wafer before its folded. Sometimes you can get the hot and fresh ones that are oh so delicious and crunchy! (I would suggest you brush up on your Cantonese if you want extra free cookies!)

If you buy something, they'll even toss in a few extra cookies for you. 

Everything there is so cheap. I know there's not too many options to choose from, but it's all under $5, cash only of course. 

What to buy: the almond cookies, and the flat pre-fortune cookies, and of course fortune cookies!! My favorite is the flat cookies because they're so addicting, you can't just have one. I would skip the chocolate fortune cookies because their not that good.
author: Cathy P.

description: If you are going to San Francisco you must visit the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie Factory in Chinatown. It is a hole in the wall. Really good cookies. I prefer the flat ones.  The only thing, don't get the bag with the small wafers, they tend to be a bit burned.
author: Honest Abe E.

description:
Great hole in the wall place. Small factory with free samples. They also have packs of fortune cookies for sale, along with chocolate-dipped and giant ones. You can also hand-write your own message and have them put it in a cookie along with a cute little chinese to-go box. 

Fascinating to watch the fortune cookie-making process and worth stopping by!

Quick 5 min stop.
author: Marcia N.

description:
Best and freshest fortune cookies you can find! Super neat to watch them made in this little alley way. I've been coming here since I was a kid.

Bonus - They always hand you some fresh warm cookies right off the press!
author: Aleyna S.

description:
Eating warm samples is the best! They now offer a jumbo fortune cookie for $5, but my favorite are the flat round vanilla wafers. There's also chocolate and chocolate covered, ribbons and almond cookies. 

Yes there's another shop up the street that offers colored cookies and various favors, but I still love this shop.  There's nothing fancy, but it's been here for a long time and also consistent. 

Cheers!
author: Carlyn C.

description: What a little gem hidden in an alleyway of Chinatown.  The cookies were crispy and flavorful.  Courteous and quick service.  Plenty of free samples.  Got a bag of flat cookies as well as the fortune cookies for adults.  There's not really much of an x rated content on the adult cookies readings. It was more hilarious to read them.
author: Wayne L.

description:
Love the flat fortune cookies.  The flat ones are easier to eat and cheaper.  I personally don't care for the fortune so I always opt for the flat ones.  They're still crispy and crunchy and with the same great taste.  Tried their chocolate flavor too but original is way, way better!  

The place itself isn't fancy and it doesn't look that nice either, but their product is top notch.
author: Samantha C.

description: Super fun reason to explore Chinatown.  Kids feasted on the bag for the rest of the day.
author: Lisa H.

description: I don't think these are great cookies it just tastes me like ice cream cone biscuit nothing great to go for. If ur at china town can go for a visit , and I purchased a big packet
author: Sandeep R.

description: They are a tiny little shop and factory, but definitely have  well made cookies at an outstanding price. This shop sells not only the original fortune cookies, but also the Adult X-Rated in regular and mixed chocolate, the flat cookies in mixed and regular, the mini flat round in regular and mixed, and Jumbo Sized regular. They have been around forever and will continue to flourish, so long as they keep doing it like day one.
author: Joseph A.

description: TBH when the SO and I lived in Chinatown for a bit, we sometimes when here whenever I wanted a snack as  we were looking for where we were going to eat in Chinatown. This is a pretty standard typical stop in the traditional let's go visit Chinatown adventure. You get to see them make fortune cookies! And they are super nice and offer you so many samples which is fantastic. You can see the production of the flat cookie and how they fold it into the shape and you can also buy gigantic bags of cookies in case you want more. Pretty fantastic and a great, easy quick stop.
author: Jasmine X.

description:
Golden Gate Fortune Cookie Co. is a San Francisco treasure!  A must see/stop in Chinatown.

We were visiting SF as our daughter was getting engaged.  I came up with the idea of doing a congratulations fortune cookie for the couple's engagement dinner and party...and Kevin Chan of GGFC made it happen and helped us with what to say (he even added the date as their lucky number...nice touch!), then he had trouble printing out the little papers.  So he sent his daughter to a printer to get a better print..then he showed us how he hand made each cookie.  Did you know if it takes more than 4 seconds to grab the hot cookie dough, insert the fortune, and then bend the cookie...it goes straight in to the waste/sample bin.  The price after he finished making about twice as many cookies as we ordered was about half what it should have been.  Beyond reasonable, and a wonderful experience all the way around.  Thank you Kevin, your daughter, your mom & uncle too.
author: Peter H.

description: A factory with fresh fortune cookies and free tasting, you can't go wrong!!! This place was awesome. We have been here a few times and really enjoyed the yummy fortune cookies. The aroma of the cookies just permeates out the door. The cookies are fresh and delicious. They also offer chocolate flavors! Everyone raved about how fresh the fortune cookies are. Will return for sure!
author: Patti S.

description:
Ah, now this is more like the Chinatown I'm used to from New York.

After walking down the gutter alleyway to find this tiny little sweatshop-looking place, we went in and were completely ignored upon entering. I expected that from the poor women working non-stop rolling the fortune cookies, but the gruff slave-driver guy that is supposed to be the salesman was not doing a very good job. We finally asked him what the deal was and his only response was "Picture. 50 cents. Go".

So ya know, when in Rome, I took a couple of sad pictures of my wife posing with the women making the fortune cookies and gave him 50 cents. My wife lingered near him since we read in most of the Yelp reviews that they give you free samples, but the guy was not biting. And she's pretty good at coaxing free stuff out of people.

It did smell really really good in there for some reason, so we were tempted to buy some fortune cookies, but then we remembered and said to ourselves: "wait, fortune cookies taste terrible, right?". So we left, out only two quarters for a couple of funny pictures.

It was pretty cool to see how they make the fortune cookies, from the flat pieces that get folded into the shapes we know, using the far-too-intricate-looking machines they have. All in all, I guess it was worth it for the experience, albeit a pretty sad one.
author: Mike C.

description:
YUM. This place has perfected their fortune cookie recipe! I have never heard about this place until our tour guide (my aunt) decided she wanted to make a stop here and buy a few bags of fortune cookies for us. TINY TINY place in an alley. What is Chinatown and their dingy, sketch looking alleys?! I don't get it.

Most of us waited outside since we came in a crew of about 22. They even give samples as you wait in line! We got about 5 bags of fortune cookie skin ($4/bag). It was just a regular circle. The fortune cookie wasn't molded into it's shape but thats how we wanted it. Unfortunately that means no furtune inside too.. I was curious as to what the fortunes would say but oh well! Definitely a must try when in San Francisco!

**Be careful if you are waiting outside. 3/22 people we were with got pooped on by those stinkin' pigeons hanging around above! We all had a pretty good laugh at those 3 people but you know it's never funny when it happens to you ... You have been warned =)
author: Amy P.

description: Awesome! You can also make a special one as a gift! Like I missed you, Viky! :)))))). Nice to see how they make it.
author: Veronika J.

description: This place is cool if you're in Chinatown with tourists. We brought a friend that was visiting and we happened to pass by this spot on the way to Garden Bakery just around the corner to get some Wife Cookies. Although the line looks long, it doesn't take more than a few minutes. They give you a sample of a fortune cookie to try. If you want to take a photo/video you have to pay a quarter or something I paid for my friend to video since he was from out of town. It's a cool place and the cookies are yummie.
author: Grace P.

description: Fun to visit and watch the cookies being made.  The fresh/warm cookies are delicious.
author: C C.

description:
Such a fun experience to be able to watch those hard working ladies at work and to taste freshly baked fortune cookies! Our kids LOVED snacking on them while we are strolling through SF streets:-) I wish we bought another bag of the flat ones, they are easy to snack on:-) Definitely coming back again:-) 
I loved the location, a little hidden and feels like treasure hunting or scavenger hunting:-)
author: Anna K.

description: When looking for places to see and do in San Francisco's Chinatown, this one popped up and I had to go.  Glad I did.  I love seeing how things are made and you can see three women sitting there making fresh handmade fortune cookies.  My daughter and I thought it would be fun to pick up the "x" rated adult fortune cookies but were disappointed in the fortunes as we didn't really understand them.  For example.  One read "Don't buy your girl bicycles or she might peddle it all over town".  What?  Is it telling me she's going to pee all over town?  I don't get it.  You can also custom make two fortune cookies by writing your own fortune in them for $1.50 plus it comes with a small cute take away box.  Very cute!  You can also get a huge fortune cookie for $6. I do have to say that there's a man that works in there that's constantly yelling at the women in Chinese.  Don't understand what he's saying but it sounds abusive to me and the women don't say anything back.  He's so loud you can hear him in the alley.  People asked the woman taking the money about him but she doesn't say anything about it.  You do have to walk down this sketchy alley but a visit is a must.
author: Mary M.

description:
CASH ONLY.  Golden Gate Fortune Cookies is a tiny shop on Ross Alley @ Jackson in SF Chinatown.  Ladies are sitting down with the cookies getting ready to be stuffed in the paper fortune, some are just kept whole & not folded over.

Old guy gives you samples of the whole cookie not folded.

Pre-bagged cookies are for sale.  I got a small bag with 6 fortune cookies for $1.  Think it's not the best price, I should have spent more like $4.50 to get a bigger bag.

I saw a cop come out of there with a bag full of cookies.  I wonder if he paid for them or not.

If you want to take a pic of the workers it's 50c.  I didn't this time, maybe another time.
author: Ann L.

description: I've visited twice and I'm still in awe of the process and deliciousness of the fresh fortune cookie.  If you're in SF and near Chinatown, I'd definitely recommend stopping by.  This last time I visited, I didn't have the fifty cents for a bag of fortune cookies that cost $5.50 and they just let me go with my purchase!  So generous.  If you make a purchase, they'll toss in a ton of fortune cookie discs for free!!!
author: Jessica A.

description: It was really fun and interesting to see how fortune cookies are made. The only thing is I wish they had someone there to explain the beginning to end but still cool to see. And to have a warm fresh fortune cookie piece was great!
author: Lisa H.

description: If you're on Jackson (one of the main streets through Chinatown), Golden Gate Fortune Cookies is on a little alleyway down one side. You'll know you're there when you see the line. They move you through crazy quickly so don't be intimidated by the line. It moves. They walk down the line and give  you samples of the flat fortune cookies. SOOO good! Then you can purchase them flat, folded, chocolate, regular, swirled, and even a giant cookie! Our favorite part was getting to watch the hot fortune cookies come down the line & seeing the ladies quickly roll them into cookies. We even go to write our own fortunes & have them folded into cookies!
author: Kari G.

description:
I remember it was so hard to find my first time here. It's located in an alleyway with a small yellow sign way above the door way that's viewable from the main street. Both times I used my Google Maps to take me here with the Yelp listed address, on point! It can be easily missed.

The entrance is super small, just one door that leads you into a factory of a few ladies on machine folding the freshly baked cookies into the recognizable form. By the door is all you get to go/see. Free samples are available. Bags of regular/chocolate/mixed fortune cookies are for sale (forgot the price but I think it's $4-5). Irregular flat cookies are a bit cheaper (~$3.75) and doesn't taste nearly as good. Haven't tried their almond cookies and other treats. But I enjoy the crunchiness of their regular flavored fortune cookies!

Cool to come/see briefly and get yourself a bag of fortune cookies to munch on if you're in Chinatown. I wouldn't purposely come just to visit this place as it's more 3 minute stay location. They charge 50 cent for photographs!
author: Winnie T.

description:
Is it just me, or has anybody else ever hated a particular food until they had a gourmet version of it? It's happened to me with hummus, hot chocolate, and fortune cookies. I used to hate them. Think about it... what's so great about a dry, folded sesame oil wafer? As a kid, any time we got Chinese takeout, I would give my cookies to my brothers and pretend to be a food martyr, sacrificing my dessert for the benefit of my siblings' happiness.

That all changed on a sixth-grade field trip to Chinatown when we stopped by Golden Gate Fortune Cookies and I fell in love.

Who would think that a dumpy shack tucked into a corner off of Grant would turn out such great cookies? They've got plain ones, chocolatey ones, XXX-rated ones... you get the drill. But they're always super fresh and crispy and delicious. Since my conversion I've even become perfectly happy consuming the stale, take-out versions I used to throw away.

Anytime I'm in Chinatown I always venture down the narrow alley (permanently smelling of urine) to the fortune cookie factory, and the locals always seem to be impressed when I leave with a couple bags full.

Seriously, you don't know fortune cookies until you've been here. Try a couple samples and buy a whole bag for like $2. This place isn't on tourist lists but is a real Chinatown staple.
author: Jennifer B.

description: Every time I'm in San Fran, I go seek this place out and stock up on the fortune cookies and of course...their most wonderful almond and sesame seed cookies.  Love the place and they are great people who answer questions, smile for pictures (you do have pay .50 for a picture), and give out free samples.
author: Barb G.

description: This is a hidden gem.  A local mentioned it to me so I hunted it down in a back alley of chinatown.  Wasn't quite sure what to expect but the experience was so interesting.  When I was there, there were 2 women sitting at the machine hand-making fortune cookies.  A helpful man at the front assisted me in making my own fortune cookie, plus he gave me & my toddler lots of nibbles.  Just a really fun, off-the-wall experience.  We'll be back!
author: Chris L.

description:
Hidden in a quaint little alley of Chinatown, this place makes you feel like you got in a delorean and went back in time.  A small little shop with a small little machine assembly line to make fortune cookies.  The owners and employees are super nice and give you free samples as well as throwing in a few misshaped fortune cookies into your bag with purchase.

My only gripe is the idea of these ''adult'' fortune cookies.  I was expecting something funny or pervertedly humorous or something, but instead I got fortunes like "do your taxes before april 15th" or "you have girlfriend now you have money , you have wife you no money"  I guess their idea of adult was "grown-up" fortune cookies hahahahaha
author: Anthony C.

description:
This is one of my official stops whenever I am showing people around SF Chinatown, great for children and adults alike. I always take any visitors for a brief visit here (~3-10 minutes max). The owner is all about business and charges 25 cents if you want to take photos of the process. Don't worry if you only have large bills, he has lots of change ready. He will also offer you some freshly-made, free samples of unfolded fortune cookies.   

It's truly fascinating to watch how quickly and methodically the three expressionless workers process the fortune cookies and interesting to see the dough being baked and molded in the machines. These are probably some of the only fortune cookies that are handmade instead of mass produced. At the same time, this also seems like a fortune cookie sweat shop.   

Be careful about lingering too long or staring at a particular product-- you may be started by the owner barking at you asking what you are going to purchase. There is a small selection of different items for sale that are only a couple dollars per bag. You can purchase a variety of regular or chocolate fortune cookies and even "adult" fortune cookies. I usually go for the unfolded ones and munch on them as a snack.
author: Kristin C.

description: Rude owner and service. Not very sanitary either. Definitely not buying any of their products.
author: Ed W.

description: Walked down a random alley in Chinatown and there it was. They make fresh cookies and give samples out when you walk in (much better than any cookie you'll eat from plastic wrapping). It was fun to watch the process of how it's made.
author: Ryan J.

description:
I've never been to a Fortune Cookie Factory before.  But thought it part of our SF Chinatown experience.  Not a big deal, but cool anyways.  I thought it a cool option that you can write your own fortunes/messages and they will fold a cookie around them.

Grabbed some pre-made cookies and fortune cookie chips.  Everyone liked them as they devoured them.
author: Geo P.

description: I came here with my family while walking around Chinatown.  We got a box of chocolate dipped fortune cookies.  These were good, but really the original plain cookies were better imo.  We were in and out of there in minutes, and they even gave us a handful of free extra cookies!  I mean, who doesn't love that!?  I'd definitely go back!
author: Kasie G.

description: This was a hole in the wall kind of place. We kept walking past it and didn't realized it was in a dark alley. When you first walk in you are greeted by the workers who are making those fortune cookies right in front of you. You also get a sample of the fortune cookie before they are folded into their shapes. It was interesting to see how those little cookies are made.
author: Lynn H.

description:
If you think takeout fortune cookies are the shiz, I truly feel bad for you, my friend. I don't only like this place because the old man who owns this place and his workers are my peeps from Taishan, but it is the epitome of an old Chinese factory.

Say what you want--sweatshop, old, cheesy, etc. but it's rare to see old factories like this exist anymore, especially in the city where some of the first Chinese settled in 'Murica. Ross Alley is  like a different world away from the rest of Chinatown and this is one perfect place to sum up of what it is. I don't know if the old man has a sixth sense but the moment we peeked inside, he was incredibly nice to us until the time we left. Must've been because he sensed the Taishan in me. Are we even talking about the same old guy, dammit?! We had no intention of buying--just wandering and I even laughed at the sign on the door that said "50 CENTS FOR PICTURES." That is really a first and I thought to myself, 'Damn, must be run by grumpy people.'

But no.

Old, Chinese man was incredibly nice and friendly, showed us the way of making fortune cookies, gave us fresh samples and didn't really push us into buying anything. BUT THE FORTUNE COOKIES WERE SOOOOO GOOOOOOD THOUGH. It was very flavorful and it didn't taste like another manufactured product from the dollar store. The best thing was that it tasted like Hong Kong egg waffles and you know it was made with eggs. It's amazing how these were made how easy they can be made. You know they are truly traditional Chinese people when they sell the imperfect scraps, which we bought because we didn't want to crush the fortune cookies in our luggage. Didn't get to take pictures because I didn't want to cough up 50 cents but I'm sure the old man wouldn't have minded since he seemed to enjoy our company. Workers were very friendly and all smiles. Anxiously finishing my bag of scraps and I NEED more.
author: Sharon T.

description: Cutest little Shop ever with cookies being made as you watch. For a buck fifty, u can have your own cookie made. I bought a big cookie as a souvenir for my daughter and an individual one with my special message inside. I loved the free unshaped wafers they added as a treat! Will definitely come back next time I'm in San Fran!!!
author: Sophia L.

description: Off the beaten path in SFO China Town, this small little room down a seemingly dingy ally is a true gem. Nowhere else can you watch the making and get warm tasty samples fortune cookies. They offer a variety of sweet crispy treats. We opted for the unfolded cookies and and the cocoa swirl - we were not disappointed. For about $6 bucks we got way more cookies then we needed lol
author: Keny R.

description:
TOTAL NOSTALGIA! 

After visiting my grandfather in Chinatown when I was a kid, my mom would take me through the Ross Alley and I would get all giddy as I smelled the fresh aroma of fresh cookies permeating in the air. Every time, I would use the lai see fong (red envelope) my grandfather gave me to buy a bag of the flat fortune cookie and leave with several fresh samples that I would devour on the car ride home with a smile from ear-to-ear. 

Since I was in the area for a meeting this past Friday, I decided to stop by Golden Gate Fortune Cookies. As I was walking on Jackson Street and turned into the Ross Alley, the sweet aroma immediately hit me in the face and brought me back to my childhood days. As I stepped into Golden Gate Fortune Cookies, I was welcomed by a big smile from the owner, the SAME man who use to greet me with a smile when I use to go there as a kid. I spent a few moments watching the workers take the cookies out of the iron cookie press, put a fortune in it and shape them to into a fortune cookie. 

They have an array of different shaped fortune cookies: the original shaped, flat, small flats and broken pieces which they sell for cheaper. They also have chocolate flavored ones which I would veer away from (very artificial tasting). The original flavor is the best for a reason. They even have "adult fortune cookies" with naughty fortunes which is great for bachelorette parties or gag gifts.

After all these years, the flat fortune cookies ($3.75/bag) are still my favorite. Their super light, airy and ultra crunchy with a subtle hint of sweet vanilla; simplicity at its best. THEY'RE TOTALLY ADDICTING!

The owner always throws in samples of cookies FRESH OFF THE COOKIE PRESS into your bag. But this time, he grabbed a bunch and placed it in my hand. It was HOT and he saw the pain in my face and giggled as I wrestled with them to throw it in my bag. Apparently, he thought it was funny and I guess I would have thought so also seeing someone play the cookies version of "Hot Potato". 

I noticed a lot of the 1-2 Star reviews were from tourists. I have to kindly note the following: 
1. Chinatown is not 5th Avenue; it can be dirty, grimy and smell.  Yes, the Ross Alley may look sketchy but it's very unlikely you will be robbed in broad daylight in Chinatown of most places.

2. Golden Gate Fortune Cookies is not Nordstrom, so you can't expect them to greet you upon entering or leaving. Sadly, it's a cultural thing so you can expect rude or poor service from Asian establishments.

3. Yes, it's a small place and may seem like a "sweat shop" to outsiders. However, it's the old bulky equipment that makes it look that way. With strict SF health and building codes, an establishment would not be showcasing to the public if they were a sweat shop which Golden Gate Fortune Cookies is NOT.

20 years later and Golden Gate Fortune Cookies is just the way I've always remembered it. They only thing missing is the lai see fongs I use to get to buy the cookies. Hmm, I wonder if I can resign from Adulthood...
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Anytime I am in the area, I will grab half a dozen fortune cookies for a dollar.  They are the freshest (they have samples), and the fortunes inside are actually very pleasant with some contain sage advice!  Service is quick and super efficient.  They've got it down!
author: Maile N.

description:
Tucked away in Ross alley. Everytime you see a "ghost" in the alley, you know they are looking for the Fortune Cookie Store!

I like their flat fortune cookies. They can get addictive. $3.50 - $4 a bag! What a deal!

The guy that mans the register and hands out the samples is nice! 

Remember please pay .50 for each picture you take inside!!! :P
author: Peter L.

description: Delicious cookies because I think they use more egg. Just way more hearty then most. Great service too.
author: Edward M.

description: I didn't want to spend too much time here, but seeing how I was on a roll with my being tourist in Chinatown, it seemed appropriate to stop here and check off the box. I picked up a small bag of their fortune cookies for $1 and was on my way before I could get into anything else.  There seems to be the option to customize your fortunes, but to be honest, I didn't have the patience for it after waiting behind the tourists who were asking a lot of questions.  Stop in here if you're curious, or in need of a history lesson or some quick (and delicious!) fortune cookies!
author: Lisa I.

description: Tiny little place you just go in and out of....maybe a 5 min. stop but these fortune cookies are the best you've ever had!  Warm samples in the factory and you can buy cello bags of the same cookies in the neighboring market stores....thin, light, crispy - almost melt in your mouth!  Fun to see....if you're hungry for something more substantial - walk down to the corner on Washington Street and hit Pho restaurant!  Sitdown restaurant -nice bathrooms - huge menu...and excellent food but that's another review!
author: Peggy M.

description:
When it comes down to authentic , you can not do better ,  
Sam Wo's might be gone but the Fortune Cookie Factory lives on  ! 
Its a must place to stop and check out to see how Fortune Cookies are made , also , when here get a bag , though my favorites are the ones that are not folded but rather flat which are just so good when you sit down to have a cup of Coffee or Tea !
author: Joseph A.

description:
You just HAVE to come here if you are in the neighborhood. The cookies are crispy and flavorful... the way they melt in your mouth as you savor each piece is just ridiculous. They are baked fresh here fortune cookies should not taste like anything else but these. 

Each time I make a trip to China Town, I make an effort to pop on by and purchase at least three new freshly baked bags to bring home. Yes, they are amazing and I don't think fortune cookies will ever be the same.
author: Marlene T.

description:
Such a whole-in-the-wall place...and in an alley...you'd really have to be looking for this place to find it.  But once you find it, it's such a treat.  It's really cool that you can see the fortune cookies being made.  And the people are so friendly - they offer you a whole (flat) fortune cookies to sample.

The fortune cookies are delicious.  My family and I just love the plain and chocolate cookies.  So yummy (and cheap)!
author: Rose A.

description: A stop everyone needs to make in SF! We always come here when we are in SF. Its a hidden gem! Now I know exactly how many bags of fortune cookies and coins I want so I move past all of the tourists, pay for my items, grab some fresh samples, and then get out of there!
author: Kristi B.

description:
.Still a hidden find in SF Chinatown, and I'm glad they're still around! =)

I heard you can get personalized fortune cookies.  Would be a fun idea to put my own fortunes in a cookie and trick someone with it! hehe
author: David W.

description:
When we took our East Coast friends here, my friend Cat had told them it wouldn't be more than a 20-minute excursion. When it ended up being a 2-minute tour, Cat was immediately cursed to bear our relentless teasing for eternity.

After you find the alleyway, the entrance to the "factory" is a few feet forward on the left. Stand in line; grab some samples from a large circular tin near the door; stare at the woman grab the flat circle of dough, put in a fortune, fold it in half, and bend it over a metal rod; pay $0.50 for a picture of woman doing said task (optional); turn around and survey the numerous bags of fortune cookies (unfolded circles or finished cookies); purchase said fortune cookies; leave.

The chocolate fortune cookies aren't as tasty as they sound, so I would recommend sticking to the good ol' regular.

A 20-minute tour bahahaha. As if :P
author: Adele F.

description:
GO HERE.  Immediately.

My husband and I went on our honeymoon here in San Fran, so we bought one of those Fodor's "Insider's Guide" books so we could maximize our time, see the best things and also attempt to experience San Fran like a local.  

One tiny blurb in the section on Chinatown referred to this fortune cookie "factory" nestled in an alley between streets in Chinatown.  I am SO glad we followed the map and found this gem.  

I keep putting "factory" in quotes because this seemed like the opposite of that.  It was tiny with about four employees.  There were a few people just pressing small, flat circles of fortune cookie into the familiar shape we all know from restaurants and take-out.  It smelled WONDERFUL in here and it was really cool to see the process of shaping the cookie and stuffing it with a 'fortune.'

Insider's tip: buy a bag of the unpressed circles - they taste EXACTLY like fortune cookies and they are cheaper because they haven't been transformed into a breakable cookie.  A HUGE bag of them cost about $5 and it took days to eat.  

Please note: If you plan to take pictures, plan to buy something or leave a tip.  I think that's a more-than-fair system to compensate these hardworking men and women.
author: Jenna S.

description:
You can find this place in the heart of Chinatown.  Almost looks like you're walking through an alley way. 

I thought it was gonna be an actual factory, but there's like 2 people working there. haha.
Pretty cool to go see though.
author: Audrey C.

description:
The website calls this place a factory but that's a misnomer - it's a hole in the wall the size of a small shop but "factory" floor instead with four women inside, two shaping the fortune cookies by hand. The machine though ingenious, could fit inside my apt kitchen.

As you can see from the photos there's a big container where the dough is poured, then it flows through a clear tube to the nozzle that squirts out just the right amount of batter onto individual baking presses - think like waffle maker but fortune cookie sized with round grilling surfaces. A whole bunch of these presses are arranged on a conveyor belt that takes them into the oven then out the other side where the baked but warm cookies are pulled off by one of the women who then shape them using a small metal tick to bend the half moons into their familiar shape. 

One woman per machine. Extremely efficient. I'm not sure how many they make each hour or if all fortune cookies are made by hand. There's not much information posted anywhere (there's not any information at all). 

On a Monday afternoon the place was empty. Only one other person showed up while we were there and that was just to buy some cookies. If you're so inclined they have the flat cookies and the shaped cookies for sale. And you can get samples just by showing up. They also have chocolate cookies but not to sample and you have to buy the entire $4.95 bag.

I felt a little awkward just standing around and watching their operation but they didn't seem to mind and didn't push me to buy anything. I noticed that photos are now ¢60 but I forgot my camera.

Probably not worth making a trip to see but if you happen to be sight-seeing with some out-of-town friends in Chinatown it's right around the corner from GG Bakery (a must stop).
author: Jean K.

description:
I was really looking forward to coming here. While I have never found fortune cookies tasty, I've always thought the concept cute and am always interested in learning how things are made. Unfortunately, reading Yelp reviews raised my expectations and the place did not deliver:

There was a small line when I arrived (maybe 8-10 people in front of me) and the older gentleman that ran the store just corralled everyone like cows. He kept us confined to the 20ft area right by the wall of products sold. Basically, once you got to the front of the line you were expected to immediately buy something and then hurried out to store. 

I MAYBE got 30 seconds to peak at one of the ladies at the machinery hand folding the cookies... 

Perhaps it was the fact that I came by on a Saturday morning, maybe the place has become too touristy - either way, disappointing visit.
author: Ankita K.

description:
We were following the GPS to a recommended yelp restaurant when it led us through Ross Alley. Suddenly all of us looked at reach other and said, "What is that amazing smell???" 

Turns out it was this place! The sign is so high up you miss it if you're not looking. They handmake fortune cookies right in front of you. It's $.50 to take a picture (cash only), but definitely worth it. 

They have regular fortune cookies, chocolate fortune cookies, gold coins (flat fortune cookies, which you're also greeted to a handful of when you walk in), chocolate gold coins, and a mixed bag of chocolate and regular fortune cookies. They also have adult fortune cookies. 

If you're in Chinatown you have to go to this place!
author: Rachel K.

description: The absolute best almond cookies I have ever tasted.  I bought 10 bags to bring home.  Love the ladies and the old machines are cranking out fortune cookies.  Also delicious!  Can't wait to go back
author: David A.

description: Kevin the son was very friendly and helpful. Awesome to see the cookies made right in front of you and the ability to eat them still hot off the machine. If you're visiting Chinatown this place is a must.
author: Caleb J.

description:
I love myself some fortune cookies to snack on while traveling the streets of SF. I stopped by this small factory located between Jackson and Washington on a Tuesday morning just before leaving back to LA. This place is easy to miss since it is pretty hidden away but it's definitely worth going to. 

There are two flavors of fortune cookies they make here: vanilla and chocolate. They also sell "cow ear cookies" and flat fortune cookies. 

Every time I go to SF, I always have to bring back cow ear cookies($3.75) for my fellow Angelinos because they don't have that brand (Snackers) back home. 

What I love about this place is whenever you purchase anything, the staff grabs a handful of fresh cookies and tosses them in your bag so you can snack on it while you journey off with your day. 

Price: Ranges from $1-$5

Parking: Good luck, parking sucks in every Chinatown around the U.S.

Staff: Although the staff do not speak English, they are pretty nice and easy to understand with hand motions
author: Winnie M.

description:
This place is legend - like Bruce Lee...

Evidently some of the [walking] tours come here because when i passed by, there were groups and groups of people throughout the 10 mins I was in the area. 

First of all, this place is in an alley. If it was dark, man, I wouldn't dare do a walk thru! Luckily, it wasn't creepy and there were lots of people around, so felt safe. 

Pretty small hole in the wall and when you walk in, the old man gives you samples of the cookies they make! 

What bothered me a bit is the fact that you "pay" to take any pics inside. REALLY?! 

I ended up buying 3 bags of cookies - 1 flat (look like sand dollars) and 2 fortune cookies. The fortune cookies I bought had a mixture of regular and chocolate flavors. 

It's hard to understand the guy, but whatevers, I made out with bags of cookies like a bandit...

Note: Several blocks uphill from the Chinatown gates... Be ready to huff and puff it up!
author: Maria C.

description: Does this really qualify as a factory? It's so tiny! But definitely worth a visit. I loved checking out the regular cookies, chocolate cookies, giant cookies, chocolate dipped, etc. We bought a dozen cookies and the man who checked us out scooped a handful of bonus cookies into our bag. So nice!
author: Kayleigh S.

description:
The child in me gives this place five stars.  The adult me who works for a labor union really really really hopes the workers here aren't chained to their chairs, but I was afraid to look.

The fortune cookies are delicious and cheap, but the working conditions?  I feel the need to go all Einstein-quote on this one, but I'll spare you that.

The alley it's in is freaking awesome.  Chinatown is so strange.
author: John S.

description:
Stumbled upon this gem exploring the alleyways of Chinatown. I was immediately greeted by the owner and invited to see how the fortune cookies were made. Was even offered samples from a freshly made batter.

You can customize your fortune cookie messages - perfect for messing with friends or asking that girl in class out for a nominal fee. You can take pictures of the equipment and the whole process, but they kindly ask for 50 cents as a donation.
author: Dan T.

description:
Now the New Year has just rolled around - Happy Year of the Snake! - desserty celebrations have been on my mind & what better way to ring in the New Year but w/ a cookie!

Golden Gate Fortune Cookies have a little something for everyone.....

It's like a hidden treasure ( that everyone knows about ) but you actually have to search this place out - it's not prominently displayed for all the world to see but down an alley that makes you think at first you've taken the wrong turn but just keep going....you'll be glad you did

They operate a very small & somewhat dark shop, making fortune cookies all day, everyday & if you want to take pics, be ready to cough over $0.50.  But hey - I'd hate having my pic taken ALL day by tacky tourists & would prob charge for it too!

They offer "regular" fortune cookies of different sizes & also flat fortune cookies - which you can buy by the round shape or via bags of Broken Cookies - they all taste the same b/c they pump out so many cookies every day that they're always fresh so basically you're paying for shape here

Even though I'm not a huge fortune cookie fan, I do get the random craving & when I make my visit, I actually prefer their flat cookies - for some reason, my mind tells me they taste better & you have a choice of vanilla or chocolate.....but do yourself a favor & just get a bag of each

Vanilla have a nice, light, crisp texture & very mild flavor.  
The chocolate has the same light texture & just a hint of cocoa to make it addictive

You can get the "standard" fortunes or the "adult" fortunes if you're feeling a little nasty & getting your Janet Jackson on

1 time, I also got some kind of Almond Butter Cookie-like thing & it was crumbly & pretty stale.  I think Fortune Cookies are the go-to item here & w/ the tourist-trap yet sweet ambiance & free hot cookie samples, you'll be glad to say you were here
author: Adrienne G.

description: A must to if you are going through Chinatown and I love how you can buy a whole bag of the cookies. Will never eat wrapped and rolled cookies again.
author: Devika B.

description:
I don't get my fortune cookies anywhere else! This place is the best!

For less than $5, you get a big bag that'll last you a while! Plus the guy throws in hot fortune cookie samples in your bag before you leave! Nothing beats a hot fortune cookie so NOM NOM NOM on it quick!
author: Kelly L.

description:
Adjust your expectations: this isn't a sprawling industrial complex. It's a smallish storefront, and it can get pretty packed, but the staff was kind, patient and engaging with my kids when we dropped by between tourist rushes.

The prices for the cookies are very reasonable, and it's a kick for the kids to write a fortune of their own, then to see their cookies get made and packaged up. That's easily worth the dollar they charge.

Just don't build your day around your trip. Allow ten minutes or so (plus waiting time, depending on the crowds), and then maybe a half hour to walk off that giant fortune cookie you couldn't help yourself from buying.
author: Rob C.

description:
Where do tourists usually ask locals for directions?
Your Jeopardy answer, What is Golden Gate Fortune Cookie factory?  Ding ding ding... daily double!
This neighborhood institution has long been a Chinatown landmark for locals and out of towners.  Walk in and you'll say, "This is it?!", evidence of how simple life was back in the day.  Everybody knows the fortune cookie wasn't born in Asia and strictly a westernized sweet ending at Chinese restaurants especially during the 60's and '70's.  The patriarch of the business often sits on an outside chair catching rays or greeting local neighbors.  Typical of Chinatown businesses, it is family run in minimalistic fashion.
As a huge tour group draw, you will often see crowds split in two, visiting this store or watching the erh-hu toting barber play holiday songs or Happy Birthday to his captive audience.
Pop in and sample their 'defective' (overcooked or wrongly shaped) goods which actually are my favorite.  My dad loves their flat version as a pill chaser every morning.  Hey, whatever works.
Just remember, when you hear factory, don't think Willie Wonka scale wise.
author: Mike C.

description:
Fun to stop by to see how they are made, but makes me a little sad because it's a kinda gloomy looking factory!  I came by to buy my out of town friend the flat fortune cookies (without fortunes of course)..sometimes I think the flat ones just taste better!  I bought two big bags (one for me and one for her) and I was trying to get quarters out of my bag and the guy was a little impatient and kept repeating the total...I said back, "I know, I know, I'm getting change out!"  Maybe that's why he threw in some extra loose cookies in the pink plastic bag (grossly touched them though after I gave him the cash, aka not being sanitary).

When I left there were little kids stopping by with adults on a mini tour of some sort.  Stop by for a bag when you're in Chinatown!
author: Cat C.

description:
If Cookie Monster is blue, I wonder what color the Fortune Cookie Monster would be? He might end up eating the fortunes as well as the plastic bag wrappers.

Either way, Golden Gate Fortune Cookies is not just a fortune cookie shop and factory, it is also a museum and a piece of history. Sure, debate all you want that fortune cookies were ripped off in concept from Japanese senbei (rice crackers), it's all in the wikipedias and what not, but regardless this is still a SF icon. Great fun for the family, provided you are not some tourist wrecking digital havoc (where you have to pay 50 cents to get a picture, and you end up blocking the shoppers while they wait for you to finish snapping photos so they can browse or buy the goods). Best thing to do is to buy a bag of cookies (a small bag of 4 to 5 is about a buck, or $3.75 for a large bag) or better yet the large plain wafers (without the fortunes) to get more mileage per bite. Then you might be able to take a few snapshots without forking out the coins.

Fortune Cookies do not exist in Hong Kong, although there are a myriad of baked goodies made with the same mixture over there (that are also available here to some extent), whether it be crispy egg rolls (the dessert kind), or egg puffs/eggettes (gai daan jai). The egg batter mix used in the fortune cookies borders on a tad too sweet for my liking (may be acceptable to most of you)...should the sugar content be reduced, it would be perfect.

Bring the fam and/or the kids here. The old man who works here is very nice to the young ones, and he gives out the free samples...aka the rejects from the molds that are not fit to be folded into fortune cookies, but are safe and perfect to eat. Most of them are pretty much hot off the press, so the free samples taste the best. If he really likes you, when you buy a bag of cookies (or wafers) he'll reach into the reject tin and take out a handful and throw them in along with your purchase. They have chocolate flavored fortune cookies here but that's about it. Nothing fancy, and no x-rated fortune cookies here.
author: Ken K.

description:
I love fortune cookies.  I don't care for the novelty of it, I just love the cookie.  If it wasn't for The Real SF Tour, I don't think I would've found this place.  I've been to San Francisco twice before and was never aware of it's existence.

Tucked away in Ross Alley, Golden Gate Fortune Cookies is a super teeny tiny hole-in-a-wall factory that cranks out the best fortune cookies ever!  There's not much to see and the items are limited because they only make...well, fortune cookies.  After I bought two bags of fortune cookies for $3.75, I noticed just the flat cookies bags for $3.50.  I rather have gotten that so fail on my part.  

Picture taking cost $.50 which I thought was ridiculous but whatever, you get a free cookie sample for donating to the cause.  So delicious because they were hot off the plates.

After my SF trip, I'm determined to try make some cookies at home :)
author: Michelle L.

description:
We actually visited early September.
Try and park on Jackson. Closest to end of ally where "factory" is. As other reviewers say, it's not really a "factory" but more of a large room with two ladies sitting at antiquated machines forming the cookies and entering the fortunes. Of all the years we have been coming here, we never knew this place exited until I found it on a blog. It's a visit that will take you about 5 to 10 minutes to see, take picture and buy a bag or two of cookies. But have your $1 or $2 ready as you walk in if you want to take a picture. It's like .50 a shot but worth it for your social media. The cookies were actually very good, crisp and light. Try the mixed bag of vanilla and chocolate ones.
author: Steph G.

description:
What an awsome find! I love that the same lady who's been hand folding the fortune cookies from the beginning is still working there! 

We bought the chocolate version and got lots of samples of the regular to go. Crunchy and a good snack, whether it's healthy or not...I'm not to sure lol!
author: Louise C.

description: Cute mom and pop for fortune cookies! They make it there and give you generous samples.  The samples are nice and warm as well.  After you buy your fortune cookies the owner adds more samples in your bag.
author: Alice T.

description: OMG is all I can say!!!!  These are the freshest fortune cookies that you'll ever taste!  They have cripsy, warm samples for you to try.  Whenever I am visiting San Francisco and am near Chinatown, I will always member to come to this small, but great place!  Highly recommended by me!
author: Ryan C.

description:
Quaint little fortune cookie shop.  Was in Chinatown this past weekend wandering around and thought "where was that little secret fortune cookie shop?"  Naturally, I found Golden Gate on Yelp and walked on over.

My memories of this place was akin to that of the description of the "speakeasy" type bar the guys were going to in Swingers, only this place now does have a sign.  Can't remember if it did when my mom took me here as a child, but it is still a somewhat nondescript place down an alley.

There was a modest line when we arrived which moved pretty quickly.  We snacked on some samples left out in a tin while we waited in line.  Once it was our turn, we bought a couple of bags of both the folded fortune cookies and the flat ones.  The old man was very polite and threw several fresh flat cookies into our bag before we left.

It is cool to come in here and see them shaping the cookies.  I do find it interesting that they want 50 cents for you to take a picture.  I'm not sure how it's costing them anything, but this is just a minor gripe or comment.  It's still a charming place to visit.
author: Brent T.

description: My boyfriend first told me about this place when he suggested I bring some fortune cookies back to my family in Illinois. At first I thought, what a horrible suggestion.... until the day I had one and wow.... their flat fortune cookies are the best I've ever had! Everything is freshly made in the factory and pretty cheap at $4 per bag. The flat fortune cookies are a must try and can sell out on weekends, luckily I got the last few bags the day I went.
author: Lynn T.

description:
what an awesome and fun experience!  being able to peek inside the tiny and delicious smelling space, and see how the magic is made, was so exciting for not only my kids, but us adults as well!   the people were super sweet and made the job of a fortune cookie maker, look awesome.   
for fifty cents, you can even snap a photo! :)  -totally worth it for a selfie! 
and, to make the experience even cooler, you get a flat cookie to nosh on, while staring at the wall of delicious bagged ones for sale!   AND, on top of that, you can WRITE YOUR OWN FORTUNE TO STICK INSIDE A COOKIE!!!   
that. was. the. coolest!   
guess we all now know what my people will be getting for gifts now!   they'd make the perfect gift for anyone and they come boxed up in a little to go container.  

totally worth going to.  tourist or native, this is a must see and devour-all-the-cookies kind of place!
author: Briana R-k B.

description: Love. Finding the place is a little hard but its so worth it. You walk in and immediately see them making the fortune cookies. I ended up getting a bunch including the GIANT fortune cookies and wrote my own messages to put in them. They even let you snack on warm fresh cookies while you look around the place. I look forward to next time.
author: Kayla T.

description: Awesome little place and well worth a stop in Chinatown. This is a TINY little room and you'll be in and out in about 5 minutes, so don't expect a full "factory tour" experience. You'll get to see some workers shaping the cookies, you'll meet the owner who is super nice, and he'll offer you some fresh, still-warm samples. Definitely the best fortune cookies I've ever tasted! You can have them customized for special orders. I love this little place. If you're in Chinatown, it takes 5 seconds - go see it!
author: Brenda A.

description: These cookies are so good.  I bought a large bag yesterday, but I'll have to go back tomorrow for more, because I am almost out!
author: Michelle M.

description:
They THROW samples at you. And you'll walk out with an armfull of delicious and fresh cookies for $5

Interesting process to behold and very friendly people.
author: Arthur W.

description: Revisited the Golden Gate Factory to glance at the ladies making fortune cookie using the old fashion molds. They were selling also almond cookies, and other non-fortune cookies. They have a variety of fortune cookies. Nice owner. Free sample. Visit this place and try the fortune cookies!
author: Kitty D.

description: Even though it's a small area and it's hidden between a very tiny alley,  it was well worth it. Be sure to bring cash they don't except card. They do ask for tips before you take pictures, so don't be offended. They sell their fortune cookies flat and folded with messages. They offer original flavor and chocolate or mixed. It was a great experience I'll be sure to be back!
author: Alexandra Linette S.

description: I have to say that the place is not impressive at all. We had to stand in line which was ok, it was only about 5 minutes once we got in the old man taking the orders was rushing me to pay when there were 2 people in line ahead of me and I had not even picked what I wanted! I picked up a bag of cookies gave him the money and as I'm walking out he tried charging me for the cookies again, when I tried to explain I had already paid for them he literally rolled his eyes at me and said something in Chinese. I did not have a good experience at all, I will not be coming back to this place. The cookies were good but it's really not worth the time, money, and having to put up with really bad customer service.
author: Maria G.

description: We've heard all about this place and had to check it out. The line was long but the wait wasn't too bad. We are greeted by a man named Kevin and he gave us fortune flat samples. They were so warm and delicious! We bought four bags of cookies and then Kevin told us to write our own fortune to be put into a cookie. How awesome! We definitely had a great experience here. Kevin was so friendly and funny! Can't wait to visit again!
author: Sheryl S.

description:
I've been coming here since I was a little girl.  I remember my grandma navigating me through the streets of Chinatown to find this place.

Unfortunately this place is now primarily plagued by tourists but the fortune cookies here are definitely worth stopping by- I live in So. Cal so any trip to Nor Cal, we had to make a stop here and bring bags of cookies home for the rest of the family.

The men that run this place are super friendly and hand out samples of the cookies as you walk in.  These cookies aren't folded and don't have a fortune so don't be confused when you come here for the first time.  If you don't want a warm cookie, you can purchase bags of cookies that have the fortune.  I personally just eat the cookie so the flat ones are fine by me.
author: Erin H.

description:
LOVE the smell of fresh fortune cookies

addicting

this is a must go to place if you are visiting SF

once you step foot into the small store you can sense the chinese culture and how the place kept open for generations
author: Carol Y.

description:
Playing tourist is good for the soul.

People tend to forget what makes San Francisco great, especially those who have been living and working in the city for so long. Personally, it doesn't take much or long to rediscover that appreciation.

Case and point. In the midst of Chinatown lunacy is a fortune cookie shop. Yes, it's a tourist trap. But it also provides a glimpse of hardworking people during their daily grind. The shop has been around for more than 40 years. Tiny and narrow, maybe 5 people can go in at once. 

There's really not that much to look at. But I'm always amazed by the enormous cookie machine. The batter is automatically piped onto the circular press. Travel once around. And voila the cookie is cooked and ready! From the industrial to the human machine, the worker must work with the cookie while it's still pliable. It's about 20 seconds give or take. Grab hot cookie. Insert fortune. Form into shape. Repeat, repeat, repeat. It's so mesmerizing!

AND their cookies are great!!! I never eat the ones served at Chinese restaurants, but I love these! They're fresh and not overly sweet. Best of all, they're thin and crunchy! Yum!! Free samples when you walk in. And more free samples when you buy some cookies! 

Be sure to talk to the person in charge. He is so passionate about his work. We asked him so many questions and he just answered and spoke with such enthusiasm!

So if you ever find yourself in Chinatown, go check out this shop. Spare a few minutes and hopefully it'll brighten your day too! =)
author: Marti L.

description: I'm not the biggest fortune cookie person.   Nonetheless it was great seeing a place that makes them on the spot.   And it only seems fair that being in Chinatown,  you visit a fortune cookie shop.     So I checked this off the to do list.    They are a little pushy with the samples.    And a lady who walked in with her boyfriend summed up my feelings when she said to him, "we should probably buy something".     You kinda feel like you should.   I hate to see how they enforce the 50 cent photo rule.    Glad I didn't witness that one.  :-)   So I bought a small bag of fortune cookies and kept it moving.
author: Eric G.

description:
Yes, I was brave. I ventured into alleys in the Chinatown of SF (this place is literally a door in an alleyway)with my two little sisters at hand. They weren't scared so I had to be brave. Oh, the things they would do for fortune cookies.

This place is like a factoryish bakeryish thing. They make the cookies right in front of you, but in order to take pictures, they charge you $0.50 per picture!
They DO have samples, which is the most important part, according to the little ones. 
We bought a couple bags of the Flat fortune cookies ($3.50/ bag) because my sissy's liked them best. I don't think this place is exactly clean... but it sure is tasty!
author: Krystle T.

description: Hidden little place but still fun to see. You can watch the women making the cookies and they give you the ones that didn't turn out well. They also have chocolate flavor to buy and a lot of varieties, and you can make one with your own fortune in it.
author: Rachel R.

description: Great quick stop. Yummy fresh fortune cookies. The best is making your own custom cookie!
author: Celeste G.

description:
Make time in your trip to Chinatown to see this place. It only takes 5-10 mins out of your day depending on how long you stay there. 
They have samples of warm flattened fortune cookies that haven't been folded yet. 
You can also write your own fortune for $1, and they'll put it inside and seal it up and box it for you. It's a nice cheap souvenir for someone at home. 
And yes, pics are 50 cents, but just take a pic in your mind. They last longer.
author: Ashley B.

description: This place had such great reviews I had to check it out while I'm Chinatown. As soon as we entered we were surprised by how small the place was. There are three older people sitting and waiting for customers and will make some fortune cookies if someone enters so you can see how they are made. They give free samples of flattened fortune cookies and also sell chocolate fortune cookies. Other than that, it's nothing special.
author: Ashveen S.

description: This place is a must see. It's hidden away down an alley, just follow your nose. You start off with samples and watching them make them right in front of you is very cool. We even had a batch of custom cookies made for us and family, kids had a blast!!
author: David B.

description: I take a lot of my visiting friends here. They love it and the taste of the HOT samples are delicious. Just recently I went by to make another special fortune cookie for a friend who requested it. The visitors already there saw me give the cookie shaper my little item to insert within a fortune cookie, and were amazed that I could give them something and they can sit in a flat cookie, then shape it to make the usual fortune cookie we are used to seeing. The woman even cracked open the first version because she didn't like how it looked (my item was slightly too big), and put it into another. I was and still am very happy with it. I walked in 10mins before they closed and I was able to walk out the door with my custom cookie within 6mins
author: Tony L.

description: It's a very interesting place to visit. Surprisingly the cookies are still 50% made by hand since they need to roll the paper in but it's extremely fun to watch the process. You need to pay extra $.50 if you want to take pictures and they will give you those defected cookies (actually flat fortune cookie) to eat and you can really just grab as much as you want, the guy there gave us a ton of cookie for free
author: Micco W.

description: A fun stop in SF for sure. Take advantage of the large bag of flat cookies for $4 if you have no interest in the fortunes themselves. Most likely, you'll also get a handful of free samples. Hot off the press--delicious!
author: Christine G.

description:
It's kind of an odd attraction. You walk down this little alley, and come across this small, open warehouse with some ladies sitting in front of what looks like machinery from the 1940s. What are these ladies doing? Well, um, they are making fortune cookies. 

I felt a little embarrassed standing there watching them work - I felt like I was tacitly endorsing some kind of sweatshop labor. So I stood there awkwardly for a minute, then stepped outside to wait for the rest of my party to finish whatever it was they were doing in there. Tasting fortune cookies, I guess? Meh. I don't even like fortune cookies!
author: Patrick L.

description: Freshly make fortune cookies!  This place is a bit hard to find since it located on the small alley of the main street.  We have to asked a couple of Chinese ladies.  The man gave us a few pieces to try it out and it were crispy and tasty.  Small bag is $4 and big bag is $5.  They are nice and friendly people.
author: Food-Travel-Adventure A.

description:
One of the few tourist traps that are worth a visit.

Located on a side alley, this place is hard to find, but a fun place indeed. I bought a bag of about 100 FLAT fortune cookies for $3.75 and really loved them.
author: Bill S.

description:
Came here while wondering around Chinatown. The place is simi-difficult to find, as it's tucked into am alley with a tiny door, which made me feel like I was in a movie about to meet the guy who kidnapped my family. Thankfully, instead of evil-doers, the place is full of friendly, smiling faces. They hand out fresh cookies as you walk in the door, and you can watch as the women fold the cookies and place a fortune inside. 
They have a lot of cookies for sale, too, and not just your normal fortune cookies. They have specialty fortunes, dirty/adult fortunes, fancy fortune cookies that are chocolate and vanilla and shaped like a flower.. you can even order your own specialty fortunes! If I lived in San Fran I would be throwing fortune cookie parties all the time. 
It's definitely worth the visit, and even if you just buy a bag of cookies, it'll only set you back $3. Not too shabby, for sure.
author: Melinda R.

description:
This itty-bitty factory spot bangs out tons of fresh fortune cookies rapid-quick, but it reminds me of a sweat shop.  It's very small and dark and there are about 5 worker stations lined up one behind the other.  Each one of them has adopted a robotic sort of movement of taking the fortune cookie off the plate, inserting the fortune, shape and repeat.  It was rather sad to watch actually.

They have various sizes of fortune cookies in bags available for purchase.  $1 got you about 10 cookies.  The man behind the little desk was not very nice - not very much encouragement for a return trip.  

Do check out the man who plays the "er woo" instrument next door though.  He's elderly and has gray/silver hair - featured in the movie, The Pursuit of Happiness =).
author: Crystine W.

description:
You HAVE TO visit here at least once if you are ever wandering through Chinatown.

Why?  You get to see how fortune cookies are made!  and you can taste the most delicious fortune cookies, and they are absolutely as fresh as possible, still warm from their specialized cookie-iron-oven-thing!

It's a very very tiny hole-in-the-wall place, partway down a sketchy-looking alley, but it's OK, don't worry.  It adds to the "hidden gem" appeal of this place.  Since it is so small, it doesn't take long check out; you probably won't spend more than ten minutes here.  It's free to look, oftentimes you'll get a free sample, and it only costs a few dollars to buy a helluva lot of fortune cookies.  (Support your local businesses!)

I've also heard that you can order-ahead fortune cookies with your own custom fortune-message inside (weddings, corporate events, pranks?!).  If I were to make custom fortune cookies, it'd probably be a 50/50 mix of "You will die a fiery death" and "You will find true love on Flag Day."
author: Chris Y.

description: SF's Chinatown is much more than wandering down the tourist shops on Grant or the markets on Stockton. In between are the alleys and a lot of history. On Ross Alley is the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie Factory, which draws me in with a little bit of crunch and some sage words of advice.
author: Eric B.

description: Walked from like Union Square all the way here. Pretty tiny establishment that's inside an alley. As soon as you walk in, you can see a lady making the Fortune Cookies. You get free samples as well. You can also purchase Flat or Regular Fortune Cookies.
author: Juan F.

description: A fun place if one does not have a huge expectation of a factory tour like at Jelly Belly.
author: George T.

description: My favorite stop in Chinatown. A must see venue. It's nook and cranny location is supreme. A quick 5-10 minute visit to witness the making of fortune cookies. For a small fee, you can snap a photo. They sell their fortune cookies as well. The cookies themselves are aight, decent, but it's the art of what they're doing and the welcoming of the public to witness them, which gives them five stars.
author: David D.

description:
when I make it into Chinatown, I always make it a point to get a couple of bags of fortune cookies....just going into the store and smelling the cookies baking is mouth-watering.  I love that their cookies are so fresh and they always give free samples!

If you're in the neighborhood, don't miss this one!
author: M S.

description:
This is a pretty cool place off the beaten path!  These cookies are mighty tasty, and you can get fortune cookies that are flat and ones that are chocolate!

If you plan to take pictures, make sure to pay them first.  And definitely get a bag of cookies since you're there already!
author: Vira P.

description: Follow your nose to the back alley factory.  Be prepared to be handed samples from the old man running the front and cough up 50 cents if you take a photo.  Overall outstanding fortune cookies, wish they shipped these to restaurants in TX.
author: Anthony C.

description: Love this place. We always make sure to stop in if we go to Chinatown. So awesome to see how they make the fortune cookies and they're folded BY HAND! When you line up to take a picture (make sure to leave a tip :D) &/or buy some fortune cookies, they let you try a sample that's fresh off the press. SO GOOD because it's still nice and warm. My family actually loves buying the flats and feel like it somehow tastes better. My mom can fly through nearly a half bag in one sitting and she's isn't even one for snacking hahah. All the people are super super friendly! They have chocolate flavored ones for all you chocolate lovers. And I've been going here for years but never knew you could actually WRITE YOUR OWN FORTUNE!! And I guess they tuck it in and wrap it for you. They have a couple other little goodies too, my brother likes their almond cookies- a staple in every Asian household. It's slightly hidden in Ross Alley between Stockton and Grant, it might be easy to miss but keep your eyes out because it is a great little hidden gem!
author: Adrienne V.

description: Always a great place to visit and get the story behind the Truth of the Fortune cookie! Stop by and get a bag! Its worth every penny!
author: Aaron J.

description: What can I say...it's an institution. Fun for the whole family! Small and cramped, which is part of the charm, and you get to watch fortune cookie making in action (in bed). Grab a sample of chocolate or regular, and/or a bag of ADULT fortune cookies (don't have to add "in bed"). It's a favorite Chinatown stop!
author: Anne J.

description:
So neat to watch the workers folding the fortunes into the cookies.  Can take pictures but they charge 50 cents, even if you buy something.  It's only fair because they do stop for a minute as you take your picture.

But in addition to the entertainment, the cookies themselves are AWESOME!  Crispy but not crunchy and brittle.  Sweet but not disgustingly so.  Substantial but not so thick that they are hard on the teeth.  Maybe it's because you see them making them in front of you but these were the best I've ever had.
author: Eric M.

description:
Loooooooooove! I first came here on a school field trip in 2nd grade and have been visiting ever since. Yes, it is located in small alley (Ross) and the actual shop is quite small, only 5-6 people can fit inside at one time. You can watch them make the cookies and it is pretty cool! My 5 and 7 year old cousins were so entertained by this. If you want to take a pictures, they ask for .50 cents.  Now on to the cookies...I personally love the small flat coin cookies. They are sold as a small bag for 3.75. They also sell them in a larger size, chocolate flavored and of course the standard folded up cookie. Almond and Sesame cookies are also for sell but I think these are better at some of the bakeries down the way. I come here for fortune cookies! 

Check out the man next door, he was in Will Smith's "The pursuit of happiness". He is always outside ready to take photos!
author: Liana H.

description:
Well, people certainly weren't kidding when they say 'hole in the wall'.  It is located down random shady alley that would be hard to find if you were not with someone that knew where they were going (thankfully my vacation mate had already been!).  We happened to be there on a Tuesday afternoon so the shop consisted of the workers and just my group of three.  I am grateful for that since I had a little time to look around and appreciate the place.  No need to hurry and shuffle out if its empty.

Language barrier for sure, but it didn't matter since prices were posted clearly.  Grab what you want, pay the fine gentleman and he will put your goodies in a bag along with fresh handfuls of un-bagged cookies.  Cash only, bring a $5 or $10 and have it out, ready to pay.

I opted for a mixed bag of chocolate and plain, delicious little bites of heaven, so much better than a fortune cookie you would get after your meal at a Chinese place at home.  They will even let you make your own fortune and put it in the cookie right in front of your face.  Cool.  Oh and they have regular cookies too, I resisted buying them because I didn't want to carry them around town all day, but I sorta wish I did because they looked delicious!

It is very interesting to watch the ladies make the cookies in this small closet like shop, they work and work and work and pay no attention to you or what you do or say.

Pay them 50 cents for a photo, more than generous, I would leave a dollar.

Definitely a fun place to stop on your trip through Chinatown.
author: Jasmine B.

description:
Golden Gate Fortune Cookies is tucked in an alleyway.  Upon entering, it looks like a sweatshop.  No bigger than your kitchen, there is equipment taking up most of the space, and 2-3 people working inside.  Cookies come off of a conveyor belt, and they are sold in regular and chocolate in small bags for $5.  You can also create your OWN messages, and the lady will tuck them in fresh cookies for you.

Entry is free.  50 cents for taking photos.

Really worth the visit.
author: Angela P.

description:
Did you know that Fortune cookies are an American invention? San Francisco was deemed by the courts as the city where they first originated from and this little shop is a fantastic snippet into the life and origin of the fortune cookie. 

The visit here is quick. You are in and out in less than 10 minutes.  When we walked in there were birds inside the shop that became unsettled as we entered. So funny to see birds part way. I'm not sure how sanitary that is but it sure was amusing. 

There are 3-4 little chinese ladies sitting behind the cookie machines molding them by hand. You are offered broken cookies to sample. There is the regular version, and what seems like a chocolate version, which wasn't very chocolaty. You tip the ladies to be able to take a few photos. You buy some fresh cookies and are off on your way to explore the rest of china town. 

When you get home and re-open that bag of cookies a few days later, and they still taste fresh, you realize that your whole life you have been eating stale fortune cookies. Fresh fortune cookies are a once in a lifetime experience and a visit here to Golden Gate Fortune Cookies is not to be missed.
author: Oulie T.

description: Our favorite stop in Chinatown! The cookies are so good. Once you try a free sample, that's it. You will want to buy bags and bags of them to take home and share.
