The bagged cookies are fresh and delicious. We bought the large flat cookies, the small flat cookies, and a bag of the X rated fortune cookies (haven't opened them yet)! We are so addicted to the flat, crispy, delicious flavored cookies; we should have bought more! Next time, for sure :)
author: Jodie S.

description: A 'gotta stop' if you're in SF Chinatown.  Watch, smell and sample how fortune cookies are hand made in front of your eyes.  Fresh cookies in plain, chocolate varieties as well as other goodies.  Cost effective, fresh souvenirs to bring back home to share with friends, family and other hungry natives.  Give them a try.  Oh, cash only.
author: J H.

description: The cookies here are the best. People talk about Girl Scout cookies being good and those people have obviously never had cookies from here. BEST. COOKIES. EVER!!
author: Julian G.

description: It's cramped and in the cuts, but where else can you observe just-made fortune cookies coming right off the presses? This place is a Chinatown institution! They offer free samples as you wait in line, and they also have chocolate fortune cookies, and flat rounds of various sizes for those who'd like to conserve paper. They've got fortune cookies down to a science here!
author: Caralisa L.

description:
The only best tasting fortune cookies because they use expensive margarine better. I have tried others in Oakland and the one on Stockton Street, doesn't even come close. 

I try and get my monthly fix.
author: patrick s.

description: So glad there was not a line this past Sunday. Still enjoying their fortune cookie two days after I bought 2 bags and it tastes just as great as the day I bought them. Every fortune inside has been different too! They give you sample of their original and chocolate flat round cookies. You can see the cookies made right in front of you from a round cookie to when it takes shape. You will have to pay 50 cents to take a picture inside the shop.They also offer a variety of different cookies that they make there. It was so difficult to decided which ones to get because they have different flavors (chocolate, original, strawberry) giant ones, customizable ones, unshaped ones and regular ones. I ended buying the 3 $5 per bag of the 35 fortune cookies. The man that was helping us grabbed a handful of the warm round unshaped ones and put them in our bag. It was so good to munch on our walk back to our car!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Super fun great stop on your way through San Fran on the way to GG Bridge.  

Just a few blocks off Van Ness in Chinatown, this place pumps out a ton of fortune cookies.  North of the shop, just shy of Little Italy, there are a couple of parking garages.  

You can buy cookies or disks in a couple of flavors and see how they are made.

It's free but as noted 50 cents for photos.  On your way back to your car, get some of the US's best dim sum at one of the many other establishments.
author: Shawn S.

description:
Recently featured in a documentary in Australia, my mother-in-law really wanted to see this place. So straight off the plane, we drop in. I remember coming here when I was just a kid! Nothing has changed.

The same two old ladies she saw on TV in the documentary are still there dropping in little white paper fortunes, by hand no less, into awaiting fortune cookies. Talk about carpal tunnel syndrome! But it must be interesting for them as there are always tourists coming in to gawk. 

It costs 50 cents to take a photo! At least, that is what the sign says. There is also a supply of samples to taste, hot off the press, in an old cookie tin. 

BEWARE: The cookies are addictive. I recommend getting the bag of flat ones for $3.50. Why pay for extra air? Oh, unless you like reading all those fortunes...
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Came here to buy some fortune cookies for my roll dawg M.F. they didn't have the strawberry ones she had asked for, but they did have the chocolate ones.  

I walked in and the place was empty except for some old ladies and one grandpa manning the place down.  As soon as I walked in the grandpa gave me a cookie and showed me his chocolate selections.  I decided on a bag of chocolate fortune cookies (as opposed to the round wafers) until I changed my mind when I saw the novelty 'adult' vanilla & chocolate cookies.  When I put down the original selection and reached over for the novelty ones, the old man had a cute, yet dirty little smile... "Ooh adult cookie???"

After that I could only look straight down with no eye contact as he took my money and put a few more freshly baked cookies in my bag for me to eat.
author: Priscilla C.

description: Fresh handmade fortune cookies and friendly staff! Make sure and pay 50 cents  before you take a picture! Awesome little place!
author: Jess V.

description:
This place is as uniquely SF Chinatown as you can get. We all know fortune cookies originated in the U.S., with various cities claiming fame to its invention. With San Francisco being one of these, I wouldn't be surprised if Golden Gate Fortune Cookies was one of the first to start mass producing them.

You enter a tiny shop/factory off of a small alley. Instantly, you're greeted by a man who isn't too interested in showing you around or telling you what's going on. He hands a sample of a flat cookie, shows you what they're selling, and hopes you buy something and get on your way. it's their method of controlling the crowd with maximum profit. 

$0.50 if you want to take a picture of the workers, which isn't worth it because there are several on Yelp =P. However, the process is interesting and I'm amazed how these employees can do the same mundane task of folding cookies every day. Props to them for keeping me hopeful with these fortunes. 

About $4 for a bag of normal cookies. They come in standard vanilla but also chocolate. They have flat wafers as long as other cookies in stock. A bag will last you over a month if you eat them moderately, but they will go stale. 

Definitely not something you see every day and worth a visit, especially if you're from out of town.
author: Dmitriy S.

description:
I came here as a child in the 60's and pretty much over time things had not change!! The smell of fresh batter mix being cooked in the "fortune cookie machine" brings back memories of old Chinatown and Russian Hill where i had lived. 

I play a tour guide to a out of town guest who had never been in San Francisco's Chinatown. He was fascinated that they still hand makes them the old school way and  not being mass produced in larger amounts. It will be a sad day when they stop making it this way and give in to the fast and high production.
author: Wolfy W.

description:
I came here on my trip to SF! Their fortune cookies are authentic! It was very interesting watching them make the cookies right in front of me! 

The reason I am giving this place 4 stars instead of 5 is because it was hard to communicate with the workers, and I customized 4 fortune cookies and they scrambled them up! I had no idea which cookie said what!
author: Sophia P.

description: The best fortune cookies ever! They are perfectly crisp and fresh! We always have to stop in and pick up several bags for the family when we're here. We bought 8 large bags and the owner threw in a free bag and a bunch of samples! Yummy!
author: Rose A.

description:
A nice surprise during my last visit to San Francisco.

As many other reviewers have mentioned, it's a bit of a trek to get to the hole-in-the-wall fortune cookie factory. I felt less like I was in San Francisco and more like I was exploring the seedy part of New York. But the fresh fortune cookies were SO worth it! I especially recommend the chocolate ones, deep cocoa flavor and less than five bucks for a big bag. The free samples thrown in wound up coming in handy: I had something to snack on while waiting for an insanely-delayed bus ride home from the BART station. And they cookies are still tasty, a week after I bought them.
author: Alec M.

description: Very cool being able to watch the cookies being made! They are absolutely delicious and crispy. Can't wait to go back and get some more!
author: Leah G.

description:
Why do I keep coming back here? It's because it's so darn good. I've compared to one in Oakland and it just doesn't match up to this store. I usually buy the circular flat ones for $3.75 per bag. I even asked if they sell any discounted "misshapen" ones in case they sell it cheaper but they don't. The flavor is a little toasty and almondy. I have honestly finished one bag in a day. 
They do not have misshapen ones because they hand fold the cookie. (the one that I went to in Oakland uses a machine to put the fortune inside and fold it) 
Overall, my experience has never let me down, they are always extremely fresh!!!
And I will keep coming back for more.
author: Wendy Z.

description:
Somewhat disappointed Yelpers!  Tracked this place down, after reading about it elsewhere (I think "about.com").  I probably should have read some Yelp reviews first.  I was not prepared for the tiny little place that barely fits 5 people.  I was in a group of 10, with four of them being kids, and we couldn't all squeeze in there.  No chance of getting a group photo!  Which btw, are 50 cents.  Really?  50 cents for a photo?!

Having not read any reviews before going, I was expecting a big factory, with a tour or something.  Nope... You walk through a narrow doorway after entering off the alley, and you can take only maybe 10 steps in to watch a couple workers making cookies.  That's the extent of it!

The place smells yummy and we did get free samples of the flat cookies which were still a little warm and very crispy.  But ultimately, just tasted like a fortune cookie.  Now I know from reading, that the chocolate is where it's at.  Alas, we did not buy anything.  The guy rushed us out the door after taking pictures, because he said it was "too crowded".  So not the best customer service I suppose.

IF I happen to be in Chinatown, I might buy a bag of the chocolate fortune cookies next time.
author: Emily J.

description:
What a gem!  A teeny tiny "factory" but cool to watch the cookies being folded & fortunes inserted by hand by 2 people.  There is a $0.50 photo fee - lol.

We were given free samples of the fresh, crisp, subtlety flavored wafers (pre-folded).  Bought a combo bag filled with regular & chocolate fortune cookies + a bag of almond cookies.  Both were accompanied by more free samples tucked into our pink shopping bags.  We resisted buying the "adult" versions.  Hahaha.  

If you have a few spare minutes while in Chinatown, why not stop by to experience this unique factory?  Looking is brief & free.
author: Kim S.

description: My coworkers easily tasted the freshness of these cookies and they were quickly gone.  Way better to the ones you get in most restaurants and the bland ones from Panda Express.  These are good, but I personally prefer the taste and flavor of the fortune cookies made at Mee Mee Bakery on Stockton Street.  Personal taste buds may dictate which one you like best.  Still worth checking out as they sell other related cookies and snacks, such as cow ears and the flat cookies w/o fortunes.
author: Will L.

description: It is a very quick tour because it is so small.  You walk right in and watch for a minute, purchase some cookies, eat samples, then go out.  Worth the trip if you are in Chinatown.  Highly recommend making your own fortune.  They give you a cute little take out box to protect it.
author: Daphne H.

description:
My friend who used to live in SF shared a cute story once about the time she visited this fortune cookie place and bought two kinds of cookies, normal ones and "sehshee" ones...not being able to understand the seller's accent. It's only when she got home and opened up the bags to realize she bought normal and "sexy" fortune cookies.That being said I was fully prepared to not understand the fortune cookie transaction conversation. 

Located in an alley way with no real store front, or door, I walked in looking over my choices. I settled with three bags, one sexy mixed, one normal mixed and one mixed. Though it appears the sexy fortunes aren't really that sexy, nor do some of them make sense, it was worth buying for the story above alone. 

My three bags cost 13 dollars and the old gentleman selling, who I truly couldn't understand, even offered us a handful of rejected fortune cookie pieces after the purchase. 

The cookies are great. Definitely more fresh and less bad oil tasting then the ones you get at chinese places. It was also worth seeing how their still made by hand. I would recommend taking the time to stop by.
author: Roxanne G.

description: Great find. Neat to see women slaving over old machine making the restaurant industry fortune cookies in a tiny cubicle in an alley. It is hard to find. Won't be a long visit. Very hot inside. And the fresh cookies are awesome
author: Mew W.

description: I had a hard time finding this fun little cookie factory - down a small ally, but I was happy I did. My son and I were on a road trip, and we stopped to watch them make the cookies - and took some for the road.  I will stop in again when in town, I found it both interesting AND  tasty. (Once I found it, that is!)
author: Tammy G.

description: My cookie crack. I've gotten sooo many people addicted to these to the point where some have even brought an extra suitcase to bring them back home or I have to mail some out. These aren't your typical fortune cookies you get after a meal at a restaurant. No, these are freshly hand-made goodness with such an intoxicating aroma that you can smell down the alley. They have regular and chocolate ones for your to enjoy (but I prefer the original). They sell them in bags where you can get the non-formed ones at a better deal. They even have "adult" fortunes for fun. Their almond cookies are also good, but I can't leave this place without at least two bags of the flattened fortune cookies. The elderly gentleman also always throws a handful of cookies into my bags to enjoy as I walk around town. LOVE LOVE LOVE.
author: Kitty K.

description:
Just do it! 
This place is a little gem. The type of hidden treasure every city needs and you should visit - and let's face it, who doesn't love fresh fortune cookies.
I only knew about this place because a friend I was with has known about it for years, and I feel so fortune-ate I was with her at the time because I just know that I would subconsciously be sad for the rest of my lifetime for not knowing about this place.
The store is down a tiny alley and although there were a few people there (about 10) it still feels like you've just been whisked away to a magical hidden time. You can try some free samples and take photos of the team hand making fresh fortune cookies (for 50c per photo) but the best part is that you can buy them in bulk and they are dirt cheap. I've been living on them for 2 days now and they are taking over my life but I will be back again the next time I am in town.. that's for sure!
author: Elana G.

description:
This place is the coolest ever!!! Hard to find since it IS in an alley...I felt like I was in a movie waiting for the Ninja Turtles to run through.

We found this place only because a local took us here.  Thank goodness too, because I would not have been able to find it.  It is a really small store.  Really Small...with Big Thangs going on inside it!  

As we walk in their little entryway the smell of Fortune Cookie pleasantly greets your nose and all you see is Fortune Cookies of all shapes and sizes everywhere!!  You can watch them press the cookies right in front of you and buy them hot...so yummy when they're warm!  The fortune cookie melts in your mouth and is oh, so comforting to the tummy *sigh*

Coming back is a must...I just hope I can remember how to get there.  Eek.
author: Cat V.

description: We walked down the alley, walked in the store, saw the lady stuffing fortune cookies, and then we left.  Took us less than 5 minutes.  We came, we saw, and we are done.
author: Brent T.

description:
I came here for the smell, and that itself didn't disappoint.

However it's not a factory that you may picture in your head, granted you do see equipment churning out cookies faster than you can read the lucky notes.  There are bags of fortune cookies (different flavor, such as chocolate) you can take to go, and it costs 50 cents for picture taking.

If you're in SF Chinatown, you might as well drop by as it's a short walk.  But don't go out of your way for this, even if it did smelled wonderfully.
author: Sam L.

description:
Bring Cash!

This is one of the oldest fortune cookie companies in San Francisco and is currently distributed to about 80% of the market share in San Francisco's Chinese restaurants.  

The fortune cookie is very light compared to the ones I get in Denver and it has a very aromatic sesame taste to both the vanilla and the chocolate cookies.  They also do adult fortunes but some of the fortunes are a little lame in the adult bag.  

Some other Yelpers said that the cookies don't taste very good, I would have to disagree.  If they have ever had Asian dessert/snacks, they would know that it's not meant to be too sweet or too anything.  We like our stuff mildly flavored so it'll go great with our oolong tea or green tea.  Don't expect this to taste like American chocolate cookies.  

Like other Yelpers reviewed, taking a picture of the workers will cost you 50 cents per picture unless you can try to sneak one in.  We only took pictures outside of the store.  It's very interesting to have a fortune cookie company this big tucked away in a little alley like this.  But hey, that just adds to the characteristics.

I have been to San Fran twice in the last 5 years and have stopped by here both times.  Great stuff!  I bought 3 bags just so I can carry it back to Denver with me.
author: Sara C.

description: Very fun place to visit! It is a tiny hole in the wall in a alley, but it was very interesting to see the workers making fresh fortune cookies. You can buy a bag of plain or mixed chocolate for $5. They also have adult fortune cookies for 50 cents more, but the fortunes don't really make sense. The cookies are great!
author: Cara H.

description:
Walked down this alley with my iphone google maps telling me I am standing in front of it but couldn't see it. That's how small it is. Petrified while standing there with my phone out and big ole tourist camera out and some shopping bags. Thought I was going to get mugged for sure!

I finally walked around and asked someone in a nearby store who walked us there. Phew! made it! 

Walked in to this hole in the wall. A couple of women worked away and never looked up. I said hello and nothing. No one looked up. Ooooookay. Bueller? Anyone here? Am I being punked? I looked around thinking movement might get them to look up at me so that I can charm them and ask all about their cookies. Nothing. Charm went unnoticed as no one came to help.  "THANKS! GOODBYE!" I said on my way out. I wonder if they looked up then. I certainly never looked back. 

What a waste of time that was. Glad to hear some of you actually got to enjoy it. It's my fault for falling for the romantic way it was portrayed on The Bachelor! My version was not like that at all!
author: Brenda P.

description:
Quick stop to see fortune cookies being made!! Not a lengthy tour but really a "poke your head in" kind of thing. Worth the stop to see, try cookies, and of course buy some for the road!!
This is a free thing to do unless you take a picture in the shop (.50) or buy cookies $4 for a large bag!!
author: Erin L.

description: If you happen to be in SF Chinatown, this is a pretty fun place to check out. However, their fortune cookies aren't anything special in terms of flavor. When we walked in, they just had a tray laying out with flat pieces we could sample. It would have been cool to see them in action making the fortune cookies but I think they were taking a break when we visited. There were three workers there and they were just sitting and talking so it wasn't that exciting. The shop is pretty small. Even though it is tucked in an alleyway, it was pretty easy to find because it's towards the front of the alley. If you're a fan of fortune cookies or just happen to want to see some touristy spots in Chinatown, this is a place to check out!
author: Charlene L.

description:
This is a 3 person team in the front of the small store. 2 women are taking the cookies off the belt and putting fortunes as thye fold the cookie, the last person sees how long tourist are standing around and watching and buying or not.

If a person buys something, they get to stay longer. If not goodbye..
author: M C.

description:
This is a hole in the wall fortune cookie factory. If you ever wondered how they are made, you can see it first hand here. Last time we came here, there was a lady making the cookies. This time it was a man who was telling us we should buy the X rated fortune cookies. lol!

We have bought the chocolate ones and the flat ones. It's a fun little adventure and pretty cool to watch, not to mention the wonderful aroma.
author: Andrea V.

description: free samples as soon as you get in the door - wow do they make those cookies FAST. they are much tastier than any you have had in a restaurant. You can get "adult" fortunes, regular, or write your own. only 1$ for a box of normal ones. Itty bitty but tasty.
author: Nicole S.

description:
TIP #1: A must-see in San Francisco. It's so close to Downtown that you have to make a visit!

TIP #2: They sell cookies with dirty fortunes. 'Nuff said. 

TIP #3: Why not just get a bag of mass-produced fortune cookies, you ask? Well, this is San Francisco, and we like to eat local here.

This fortune cookie factory is the stuff of legends. Friends from my 7th grade class remember coming here on a field trip to Chinatown after reading Child of the Owl, but I have no such recollection. It's hidden in a historically-significant (which really means, as dingy and creepy as it was half a century ago) alleyway. And the fact that they produce magical fortune cookies, those oddly-shaped sweet crackers that hold the prophecy of your future (and your lucky lottery numbers)--well, I couldn't believe that I had never been here before!

You can't get much farther than several feet into the factory, but what you can see is something that looks like a sweatshop: rotating belts with hot rounds of not-yet-folded cookies; old women sitting next to them, methodologically folding cookies; huge tubs full of finished cookies. The sweet aroma of cookies--and fortunes--is in the air. If you're feeling adventurous, you can buy chocolate or sesame-crusted cookies; if you don't want to learn about your future, buy a bag of rounds and broken pieces. 

My boyfriend and I left with a $1 bag of six cookies. Two of my fortunes were the same--I think the universe is trying to tell me something.
author: A.L. H.

description:
Total tourist trap, and it's like the term "hole-in-the-wall" was made just for this place. Funny enough, the double-decker tour bus we were on had this listed as one of the attractions on their Chinatown stop, but once we asked them where it was, they couldn't tell us. We had to stop in a random store and ask, and they told us it was in an alley. Boy, they were right!

It was neat seeing how they made the cookies though (I always wondered!), and I managed to take a picture without them spotting me (I only saw the sign that said, "if you take a picture, please pay 50 cents" when I uploaded them to facebook a few days later. I guess they really meant it!) My friend and I got a mixed bag of vanilla and chocolate fortune cookies... I'd never had a chocolate one before, but it was good!
author: Cherine A.

description: Came by here on a Sunday late morning, the smell was wonderful! They women were very kind and the samples were so delicious and made hot and fresh! We got mixed bags of vanilla and chocolate fortune cookies- very good! And so are the just flat rounds! Will come back soon!
author: Ashley T.

description: Tucked away in a little side street of Chinatown.  The cookies were very good and lasted through the weekend.  Certainly is an exceptional deal.........better yet buy the rejects....so you don't get a fortune, you can live without it.
author: E A.

description: Tucked in a tiny alley that smelled bad. It's a lot smaller then I thought. My kids printed their own fortunes to be placed inside the cookies. Lady was very sweet and gave them to the other woman running the machine. Each cookie with our personal fortunes were $1 each and they wrapped it up in plastic and placed in the cute Chinese take out box.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Ahhhh
Walking down a dark and crummy alley.... Nothing is better than the aroma of fresh fortune cookies filling the air!

3.50 for a bag of flat fortune cookies... yum! A great snack for all times. Sad that the price went up (I remember getting a bag for $2.00 back in the day!)

You can get the traditional or flat cookies here... if you dont care about the little fortunes id recommend the flat version... more addicting than potato chips =)

You also see the cookies being freshly made here... awesome piece of history.  The old guy (aleays see him) usually throws extra piping fresh hot cookies in your bag as a bonus!
author: Kenny Y.

description: What a neat place, tucked in an alley. Have never seen fortune cookies be made pretty cool to see. Also cool to write your own fortunes and they put into a cookie- $1.50 for 2 personalized cookies, and 50 cents to take photos in the place.
author: Natasha F.

description:
This place makes me nostalgic. As a toddler, my father use to take to this obscure alley to buy a bag a fresh, still warm, round flat cookies. I would crunch on them while walking up and down through the bustling streets of Chinatown.

They make the BEST fortune cookies! Baked to perfection, they're crispy, sweet and addictive! You can finish a whole bag in one sitting without noticing! And that's the way the cookie crumbles- with a snap in your hand and a crunch in your mouth.
author: Tes Y.

description: I went here with my kids thinking it was a big deal and it's something great to experience but I was wrong. A tiny shop in a small alley with one woman folding cookies and one selling the cookies. No hello or welcome was given. As she said was don't get too close. We bought 2 bags and left. My kids and I were disappointed. Unless you just happen to be in the area I would not make a special trip and find parking for this. Watching donuts being made a Krispy Kreme is far more exciting I promise. Don't waste your time.
author: Mark E.

description: Super tiny & cramped place. My boyfriend decided to wait outside because there wasn't walking room & it was stuffy. BUT they give you a freshly made free fortune cookie when you walk in & I got a $1 bag of cookies too. Not too bad.
author: Selina F.

description:
Walking down Ross Alley at a totally leisure pace just a few hours ago... stopped in to chat with the old bak bak who gave me free samples and convinced me to purchase a bag for $3.75 for the old man's sweet tooth (yeah, i got one too, ok?!)....

The old popo at the helm, folding and zenning, watching this spot in history and wondering just how many decades of fortune cookie making transpired here.... 

I recently finished the Fortune Cookie Chronicles by that Harvard grad math lady, Jennifer 8. 'Twas fun.. i asked the dude how many they churn out, and he paused and proudly said, "30,000 a day!"

The florist next door has some stellar prices for the freshest flowers too... i talked with her too, inquiring about pieces and prices. 

Oh Ross Alley, if only *your* walls could speak (of the endless dramatic mah-jong gambling parlors and brothels)... what would they reveal?!
author: Jana C.

description:
The cookies were so fresh and good!  Pricing was awesome!

Placed an order and it was ready within 2 days... With personalized fortunes and all.

Getting there isn't that easy.  The alley it's found in is pretty dingy but the folks who work there are really nice (and barley speak a lick o'enlglish).  They gave me a big bag of flat fortune cookies.  The cookies were so fresh and delicious!
author: Marylouise R.

description:
The people who gave this place low star are just annoying tourists who don't have functioning taste buds. 

Anyway, went to visit my grandma's place one weekend and they always have a ton of snacks. So when I stumbled upon these flat fortune cookies in her pantry, my first thought was that these were the tastiest fortune cookies I've ever had. I asked where she got it and immediately went to grab myself a bag. 

For $3, you can get a big bag of crunchy goodness. I simply can't stop reaching for it n
author: Harriet W.

description: This place makes fortune cookies.  Pretty rad.
author: Michael E.

description:
Once you manage the task of actually finding this place, lol, it is well worth it. The taste of their fortune cookies is amazing, far superior to what you have had in the past. You can come in and watch them make the cookies, and the smell is soooo inviting. They will even make you custom fortunes for your cookies if you want to wait, very cool idea.

This is a must go to when you come to San Francisco.
author: Rob E.

description:
While adventuring in Chinatown with my 11 year old niece who was visiting from out of town I knew I wanted to take her here. I had never been but it was recommended to me from a friend. 

We found it pretty easily using my IPhone's google map and stood in line for only 5 minutes or so. They send you in, you can buy cookies right there on the spot, you can see them making the cookies, which my niece really enjoyed. We were given ample amounts of samples, plus what we had bought. They are cheap and YUMMY.

*BRING CASH*
author: Meghan L.

description:
Fortune cookies made right in front of you! This place is so awesome!

Definitely one of my highlights from my trip to SF. I loved being able to see them make the fortune cookie and just even seeing the machinery was so cool.

The staff were so pleasant. They give you samples right from the machine to try. The fortune cookies were warm and fresh. They taste so different than how they do when you get them from chinese restaurants. I normally don't like fortune cookies, but these I love. I even bought a bag to take home, which were really cheap. Even the ones I bought tasted fresh and better than the ones you normally get from restaurants.

As others have mentioned, it is a little tricky to find. Kinda creepy being in a alley in chinatown and all. But definitely worth the effort to hunt for! =)
author: Leanne D.

description: Other than the tight area for people to be gathered and heat from the ovens, the actual cookies are delicious. Worth just a quick stop.
author: Xavier L.

description: Nice hidden place for yummy cookies! I got a bag of almond cookies and fortune and loved them. It is a bit hidden but worth it. When we arrived there was a long line but it goes fast.
author: Lillian P.

description: This place is awesome! Simple fresh cookies that are ready when you walk in. They have a variety of cookies and any size to please your appetite. It's a very nostalgic space with a friendly staff, there's not much space in here, so get in where you fit in! Xie xie Golden Gate Fortune Cookies!
author: Alec D.

description: Every time I am in San Francisco I have to go there. I love watching the ladies hard at work. They are so fast. You must buy a bag of the cookies and beware you cannot just eat just one. Make sure you bring change so You can take pictures.
author: Paul T.

description:
Who knew a warm fortune cookie could be so delicious?!  When you walk in, the owner hand you free cookie rounds straight from the press, which are amazing.  

All of the employees here are family, and the old man in the front of the shop is super nice.  We opted for a photo (which I think he just ended up rounding up our purchase a quarter for), and he got right up next to me and acted like he was going to kiss my cheek!  It was hilarious and a travel photo that was totally worth the quarter.

Hot tip - bottles of water are $1 here.
author: Heather H.

description: Came here for the smackles, and I have gone back for about three times to pick up more smackles. If you don't know what they are, smackles are crispy goodness that are also known as "cow's ear cookie" (you would know if you are Chinese). Try it, it is addicting. The reason why it's 4 stars is because of the weird workers that aren't very good with customer service. It's fine, the smackles are good enough that I could ignore all rudeness and weirdness.
author: Nikole X.

description:
Eh...not sure what the big deal is with this one. 

It's a very small place and I literally peeked in, got a free cookie and was hurried out by the guy up in front. Didn't even really get a chance to look at the bags of cookies for sale. 

Lame!
author: Cindy B.

description: Make sure to add this to your walking tour of Chinatown!  I never knew how fortune cookies were made.  Make sure to buy ($4 a bag) both the traditional cookies and the flat ones.   You can put ice-cream on the flat ones and it makes a great treat! I think I like the flat version better than the traditional ones.
author: Kelly B.

description: This place is located in an alley so be sure to pay attention when looking for this place. The first thing we get when we walked through the door was a free sample. After we bought a lot of cookies he threw in 2 handful of cookies that just came off of the iron. So delicious!!!!
author: Kanoe A.

description:
This place is a must-see in SF.  Hidden in a TINY alley in China-town you can find this marvelous place with amazing women and men sitting and serving up your favorite Chinese treat.  

i can't imagine doing what they do all day long but stop by and watch them work their magic - bring a camera and make sure to leave with a large bag of flat (unfolded) cookies.
author: Kevin J.

description: There is no way this place is serve safe certified, but it is awesome, hardcore, down-the-alley in Chinatown cookie factory, with cases of butter just sitting out, crap sitting all over the oven and press (like money and the operator's beverage with no lid).  A must see, especially if you have kids because it is a quick stop and super interesting to see that such a small little "factory" can put out millions of fortune and almond cookies.  I believe they are the number one fortune cookie producer in SF, maybe in CA.
author: Joe R.

description:
After eating one of these cookies, every other fortune cookie you eat will seem stale! These are literally hot off the press as the lady is pulling them out of the mold and folding them. They are so delicious and flavorful and Chocolate fortune cookies! Yummy! I love making a stopover here if I'm in North Beach like tonight for dinner, gotta bring a bag or two back for the peeps at work and one for home. And I swear there are many many fortunes....This is a MUST if you are tripping through Chinatown! 

Haha funny side note: I brought an extra bag for my husband to take to his work tomorrow, what he doesn't know is that they were from the "special" pile of Dirty Sayings Fortune Cookies.....hehehe.....
author: Susan D.

description: Watch them being made! Very cool. Bring cash. No cards accepted. Hard to find down an unpopular alley, but worth the adventure off the beaten path.
author: Kate B.

description: We wandered in while exploring Chinatown. We were offered a sample which was delicious! Great place to pick up some souvenirs!
author: Kim G.

description: Truly a little treasure this place is!!  It's a hidden gem. The owner is really funny and friendly.  You can watch the cookies being made, make your own fortunes, and purchase the freshest fortune and almond cookies!  Don't miss the almond cookies- so light and fresh.  You'll get free samples of unfolded fortune cookies too. It's a great place to uber over to.  The kids loved it.  You'll be in and out in 15 minutes with a bag of these delicious treats!!  Do not miss this place.  If I could give ten stars I would!!
author: Suzy C.

description:
Coming into Golden Gate Fortune cookies, you are afforded the opportunity to purchase a plethora of different and novelty fortune cookies.  Original or chocolate, horoscope or adult themed, the cookies are all delicious.  I purchased some of the adult cookies, and not all of the jokes made sense, but what are you going to do?  

It was also a fun and unique experience to see how the cookies are made.  Granted, it wasn't really put on display for the benefit of learning, it is cool to get a quick look at how they are created.
author: Jack A.

description: First time down in San Francisco in YEARS since I was a kid, and I am so glad that I got to stop by here. I left with $26 worth of fortune cookies. I mean come on. That's a lot of cookies! Brought some for the office and also to send to my family and I have to say they are crispy and delicious. Yes, cash only! But totally worth the splurge! They also have some chocolate fortune cookies, and adult fortune cookies if you would like to give it a try!
author: Melissa L.

description: This is a small factory in an alley of one of many sidestreets. It felt a bit strange to watch people working and take their photo and this place is very small. It will take not more than a few minutes to visit.
author: Lauren K.

description: This is another one of Chinatown's landmarks. You can actually watch the fortune cookies being made right when you walk into the store. The smell of fresh baked fortune cookies is unforgettable and has been embedded in my memory for life. Witness a piece of history while you can. There are very few landmarks left, don't miss the chance to see it while it still exists.
author: Paul L.

description: Ok, I took off a star because for me it has lost its charm.  I have come here since the early 80's when nobody knew it was there.  Now, it is so crowded that the owners won't even talk to you.  Get 'em in, get their money, shove 'em out the door.
author: Jo N.

description: Very friendly ... Prices are right ... Packaged to-go items ... Fortune Cookies (variety of flavors) ... Almond cookies , sesame seed and others // the last hand made cookies (no automation)
author: Rob H.

description:
We had some time in the morning before the wedding to check out Chinatown. In general... I loved the place. Puts Boston's Chinatown to shame.

So we were in search of the fortune cookie factory. It took us a while to find the tiny street on our map. As we approached this tiny alley way, I almost didn't want to go down it. This couldn't possibly be the right street....

Well, it was. The 'factory' is this tiny shop with a few workers. You can pay a dollar and they will let you take a photo or two of them working. For another buck, grab a bag of 6 very fresh fortune cookies. They'll offer you a free fortune cookie disc (same thing as a fortune cookie, but not folded) when you walk in, just try not to buy a bag after you taste it. You'll immediately appreciate how stale the cookies you've been having your whole life are. 

This is a fun cutesy place to stop by. Don't expect a lot, and you won't be disappointed. A great place to pick up an unusual gift for someone you left back at home (who wouldn't appreciate a big bag of fortune cookies?)

Next they need to offer the opportunity to put in your own fortunes.
author: David M.

description: Definitely worth 5 mins of your time to check out how fortune cookies are made! We bought a little bag of fortune cookies for $1 and spent .50 cents to take a picture. The fortune cookies was fresh and tasty. Nothing compared to the ones you get at Chinese take out restaurants.
author: Jenn R.

description:
So I'm Chinese American and I read Joy Luck Club. I also know that fortune cookies are not something they serve anywhere in Asia. And I never have heard of this place. 

So when my new friend from Ohio wanted to go to the "Fortune Cookie Factory", I was very confused, there's a factory in China Town?? 

We were traversing around and being tourist in China Town when all of a sudden I see this long line of Caucasians in this dinky little alley. Thankfully, there were girls in line or else my sex trafficking alert would've gone off.... but no! There was a lil old animated man (see photos) passing out flawed fortune cookies to the line.. Curiosity got to me and I ventured to read the sign. The "Factory" is a whole in the wall place?? 

To be honest, I felt a little out of place. I was the only Asian in line (and probably the only one writing a review) ... but hey! I was there for friends! 

This place is really fun... not because they fit the Chinese stereotypes but because it's interactive. You get to see (however briefly) how fortune cookies are made. For $1 take a picture with the lady who makes fortune cookies and have WARM fortune cookies. (This was the highlight!) 

5 stars for the friendliness, the machine and the warm fortune cookies. It's definitely a novelty.
author: Amy W.

description:
Golden Gate Fortune Cookies are the best I've ever had all the others ones are crap that we get from the fast food places. 

My sister always brings me the cookies unwrapped you get more for the buck and it just taste better to me, flat and round makes it easy to eat and I love. LOVE. L-O-V-E that they give you extras to just eat when you buy some. FREE & it tastes good? That's the spot.
author: Sanora A.

description: Best fortune cookies around!! Every time I'm in the area, I HAVE to stop by and pick up a bag or two of the flat fortune cookies. They're inexpensive and delicious, perfectly baked, and just so addicting!! Hard to find, but just walk down Ross Alley (literally an alley...) and it'll be there!
author: Erin K.

description:
what i ordered.... fortune cookies

great tasting fortune cookies made in front of you

Fu Ling Yu says: i'm better off making cookies than making people laugh

ambiance... ok (only if they make the place as pristine as boudin did)
service... ok
cost... $- (fair)
author: Gors P.

description: Very neat and interesting place. It was much smaller than I anticipated. Tasty fresh cookies for a good price. Don't go during a festival or holiday though; the lines get really long when the shop becomes packed with customers.
author: Noel W.

description: It's kind of hard finding parking in Chinatown, but it's a lot better to just walk here, it's located in an alley. Soooo worth it! My boyfriend and I did the whole touristy thing and stopped by here to get some cookies for home. It's a small shop where they make fresh fortune cookies! The aroma bought me back to my childhood. BUT the cookies were soo yummy! I still have some! LOL. Pictures are $.50.
author: Irene N.

description:
Unique in freshly hand rolled fortune cookies. Chocolate ones are boring but standard ones are very good! Yummy yummy fortunes :-).

yes it costs money to take a picture but...who cares??? pay the guy! or better yet forget that and invest in more COOKIES! 

truly are great (well for fortune cookies) but i do wish had some now)...

anyone in SF wanna mail me some? i'll pay top dollar! :-).
author: Drew H.

description:
Fortune cookies taste great when you watch them being made. 

This little bakery just a block off of Grant Avenue in Ross Alley is a really cool.  This tiny shop manufactures thousands of fortune cookies every day and kids and adults are fascinated by the process. 

But the best thing is the fresh fortune cookies. I made a special trip to Chinatown just to pick up a bag to take back to the family. The fresh ones are a million times better than the ones that have been sitting under the counter at you local Chinese restaurant for weeks. You can also get them in "coin" format (not folded around a fortune and in chocolate flavor, but I like the regular ones best. 

Try them. You'll be back.
author: Jay K.

description:
A charismatic little shop on the most famous alley in San Francisco.

This is a must visit. If your a tourist come here. If your a local come here.
author: Justin S.

description:
After a not-so-nice dim sum experience, my boyfriend knew how to turn my "frown upside down" by taking me here!  This place was tucked inside an alley but inside was pure heaven.  My co-worker and I used to buy the flat fortune cookies (aka "tea cakes) all the time from the Longs/CVS across work, but GG Fortune Cookies was far better than the store bought ones, hands down.  I didn't think I would be able to eat WARM, FRESH FROM THE OVEN cookies but I did; and they were stellar.  The people working there were unbelievably nice and gave us free samples.  So addicting!!!  I was so hooked, I had to buy a bag to take home.  It came with 3 flavors - original, chocolate and strawberry.  I know right - chocolate and strawberry flavored cookies?!?

I may not go to Chinatown for dim sum, but I'm sure as heck wouldn't mind hiking up the "mountains" of SF for some yummy fortune cookies.
author: Deana M.

description:
This place will turn any frown upside down.

I needed a way to lift Deana I's mood after a horrid dim sum experience and I knew just the thing. It was my second visit and, like the first, the staff was super friendly and more than happy to give us several samples.

We walked away with a couple pictures of the shop, a bag of tea cakes and smiles.

Tip:
If you're not going to buy anything, make sure you bring $.50 for a picture.
author: Darshan R.

description: Soooo cool! You're literally walking in on several people assembling fortune cookies. You can buy as many as you want and even write your own fortune and have them put it in a cookie....marriage proposal idea anyone?! Definitely a must stop in Chinatown.
author: Asia F.

description:
This place has a very rogue shady feel to it...which I like in this case. It really has character. It's located in alley in Chinatown, SF where an older man sits outside signaling those who pass by to come inside for a peek.

I thought it was kinda funny that I had to pay 50 cents to take a picture of the inside. The fortune cookies are really good. Though I love Chinese food, I do not love fortune cookies normally as they taste styrofoamy and bland. However, the fresh cookies here were light and sweet. They gave my friend and I samples to try and she also bought a whole bag of them. I think they would go great with vanilla ice cream.

Anyway, I've wanted to see this place for a few months now so I am glad that I had a chance to stop by. It was neat to watch fortune cookies be made.
author: Trudy H.

description:
What will $1 buy you today?

A bag of fortune cookie flops. Do they taste any different than a whole fortune cookie? Nope! Still DELICIOUS. Maybe even better because it was only $1. 

Why 5 stars for fortune cookies? My super Chinese mother thinks they're great too... so I must too!
author: Lisa L.

description:
Free samples! More of a tip I guess.
You go down a random alley and you find this place. You look inside and you wonder what has happened inside. It's like looking back in time.

Follow your nose, it's worth the trip!
author: Nick L.

description:
The Glade/ Air Freshener people need to get their scientist developers over here and re-create the smell of this store to the masses. 

I hadn't been in forever (last time was five years ago with my high school students doing a scavenger hunt of Chinatown). 

Not much is left to be said that everyone else hasn't covered. 

Instead of Halloween candy imma be a chubby bunny by eating the bag I got through out next week :-P
author: Vicky T.

description:
The fortune cookie fortunes are actually fortunes and well written, I give them that. They have varieties of fortune cookie type items and even chocolate fortune cookies. 

I like that this place is tucked in the middle of an alleyway also and that it spews forth an imagery of history for the imaginative minds. 

My little nephew had his first fortune cookie from me on New Years because of this place, and his fortune was pretty cool too, and my cousin (so that makes him technically my second cousin, but in my family that feels weird so all the young'ns are just referred to as nephews/neices) said she will keep the fortune cookie for until he grows up and can understand it which I thought was neat.

You can't put a price on stories and experiences with all the right parameters, for that I am grateful for this place.

Oh yeah and the fortune cookies here do taste better, how much more I cannot gauge accurately, and it could be because it is fresh.

Minus 1 star for charging 50 cents to take a picture. Way to reinforce the stereotype.
author: Thanh T.

description:
This is just a fun, wacky place to bring out-of-towners. The grumpy old Chinese ladies just make this place awesome. The old man making you buy cookies is a real character as well.

Buy the adult fortune cookies and laugh at the somewhat suggestive fortunes. Totally worth a visit.
author: Harley C.

description: We went with our children 20+ years ago and the place still looked the same.  People still generous as ever.  The shop was crowded but I managed to pick some up.  We brought back 2 packages and it was so delicious.  Need to go back again to pick more up.
author: Duane C.

description:
First, let me be a total bitch and comment that some of the out-of-towners' reviews reflect a level of provincial backwardness and cultural insensitivity that I naively thought was missing from visitors to SF, but I guess I've been proven wrong.

Second, I love this place.  Took my 2-year old son by yesterday afternoon, early evening, and there were three guys in there, each one nicer than the one before, even though between the three of them they didn't speak more than 10 words of English -- which is FINE, and doesn't indicate unfriendliness or a lack of customer service or anything else, apart from a language barrier.  BFD.

The cookie maker did his best to cram my entirely willing and delighted son full of freshly-baked cookies, all the while working away and turning out lovely little shaped packages of crispy goodness; the salesman waited patiently while I dithered around trying to decide between conventional, flat, chocolate, or "naughty" fortune cookies, or sesame cookies or some truly sinful looking almond cookies (settled on the flats, will be back for the almonds), and the third guy just smiled and waved at my boy and taught him how to say "Thank you" in Cantonese.

This place, in business since 1962, is just one of the many reasons exploring San Francisco's alleys pays off.  Go!  Eat!  Enjoy!!
author: L D.

description: Made in front of you. Yes it's that good. Good luck finding it in Chinatown
author: Scott S.

description:
This place is great.  It is an authentic fortune cookie assembly line.  The women pour the batter into the mold, close the press and pop the cookies out.  They add the fortunes and fold the cookies by hand.  It is super quick, like a machine!  Very amazing to watch this great workmanship that goes into each cookies. 

The space is cramped, and shaped like a hallway.  This makes complete sense because it was originally a cookie making factory.  They did not envision for tourist and locals to come in and meander about.  So, there is an authetic feel to the experience.

There is a sign that says 50 cents for a photo.  In typical Chinese fashion, I thought that they were trying to nickel-and-dime you.  But then I realized that people probably came in to take photos, but did not buy anything.  Still, I thought it was a rip-off.  However, my friend paid the 50 cents, and the owner was very nice about it.  He let us walk partially into the assembly line and posed us for a photo in the factory.  We stood there, as someone took several photos of us.  So, it's actually worth it to pay the 50 cents for the photo if you want one, and it seems fair to the small business.
author: Sue N.

description:
3.25 stars.  I think that many can agree that pre-packaged fortune cookies boast little flavor.  What would the experience be like if you were able to sample the cookie right after its production?  The answer to that question can be found at Golden Gate Fortune Cookies, a fortune cookie maker located in an alleyway in the heart of San Francisco's Chinatown.  

When you arrive, if you are lucky, a nice older gentlemen will hand you out samples of fresh fortune cookie made from one of the two fortune cookie machines.  The samples arrive prior to folding so unfortunately you will not receive a fortune.  

If you want to take photos while you are visiting, you must pay a nominal fee (something like 50 cents).   The factory also sells their own fortune cookies (apparently including some "adult" fortune cookies that I completely missed) in case you want to leave San Francisco with an incredibly standard and painfully bland gift for alleged loved ones.  

Out of all the tourist type activities one can do in San Francisco, this is one of the least time consuming and marginally unique.  As such, it is probably worth at least a visit.
author: Yelper N.

description:
Get a hot sample for free and buy a bag for the rest of your walk through Chinatown! These tasty bites won't be sitting in your bag for long.

As far as the "factory" goes, I find it depressing, yet fascinating, to see these old Chinese people hand-folding super hot cookie rounds so I always try to buy a bag or two/make a small donation as a sign of gratitude for what they do.  They are definitely some of the best fortune cookies I have eaten - I have eaten my fair share and can easily discern a tasty one from a non-tasty one (*cough* Yum Yum Hunan).
author: Krystle S.

description: I come here every time I visit San Fran. I love the cranky old man. He was very nice letting us come in after hours.
author: Virginia M.

description: Great cookies, with very exciting X-rated cookies, which weren't that inappropriate. They taste much better than the normal ones. The only free thing that you can do in the store is take the free sample, as they charge you to take a picture of the historic fortune cookie machines, which were made in the 1950s and are still used.
author: Nico B.

description: Truly unique.  Free samples when you arrive at the shop.  Was there close to 5pm and there wasn't a line only a couple of visitors checking out the place like myself. They sell two types of the cookie, one the Fortune Cookie we all know and then there are the cookies that weren't shaped into Fortunes, hence the circle shape.  Regardless they taste good and is from the same batter.  Always the entrepreneur - the Chinese - they also sell an assortment of other Asian snacks and bottle water.
author: Angela N.

description:
Okay, I think this is a fair review.

If you are looking for a tourist attraction, gourmet fortune cookies, picture taking opportunities, or buying single cookies-this place is not for you.

If you are looking for a tiny shop, free samples, flat cookies, chocolate cookies, strawberry cookies, cookies in bulk, or great customer service-go here!

They take cash only, with each bag being about $4.75.  They speak English too, and they had bags of almond and sesame cookies too.

Overall, good place for cookies but not as a tourist attraction.
author: Susan D.

description:
Every single time I have visitors, I either bring them here or they want to come back after a prior visit.  The fortune cookies are good.  I used to hate fortune cookies but when you have fresh ones they taste pretty good (esp when you get ones still warm).  

They get three stars because they are a bit pushy about making you buy something.  I know that they are a business but sheesh, I don't always want to buy bags upon bags of fortune cookies.
author: Banana S.

description:
Attention tourists, go to this place!  This is real sf history and it is free! Save your money on some of the rip off tourist traps and come see something simple and unique. Very much off the beaten path, but not impossible to find. Tasty cookies that taste much better fresh than packaged and eaten weeks later!  
Ok, it is small and something does say that these workers aren't working under the best conditions, but hey it is what it is. They don't pretend to be nothing other than genuine.
author: Jason F.

description:
A little island of unique fortune cookie goodness in a section of town that seems to specialize in cheap, gaudy, Made-in-Post-Cultural-Revolution-China trinkets and wares you can find in dollar stores and Chinatowns the world over.

First (and only) visit was on the Real SF tour. Tucked away in an alley (too hidden for me to find a second time on my own without Google help), the few workers crank out fresh cookies and offer free samples and the option of putting personalized fortunes in each cookie. 

You did feel like you were imposing as a tourist, what with their sign asking you to pay for any photos you may take, but it was something different to see.
author: Amelia C.

description:
There are certain smells from my childhood that brings on a contented smile on my face.  Stepping into Ross Alley, the gently wafting scent of freshly made fortune cookies brings on that smile and always has the power to draw me in.  Personally, I usually go in for the flattened ones since I'm just there for the cookie not necessarily for the fortune.  And I love the free samples the old man always throws in.  Instant gratification of warm goodness.  My nieces (one in particular) love them, too.  The fortune cookies and "ox ears" make great gifts for out of town family and friends.  

But one of the best things I ever ordered were custom fortune cookies for Chinese New Year.  Made and cut my own New Year's greetings/fortunes, dropped them off and picked up a case of individually wrapped cookies the next day.  They were a hit!  Might have to do it again for the Year of the Dragon!
author: J. P.

description: The best 4 dollars I've ever spent. I walked in with no line walked out with 15 people waiting to come in. Buy the bag of reject fortune cookies (flat) they were great
author: Danny C.

description: This is a little fortune cookie shop tucked away on Ross Street. Don't be afraid to go down the alley, it will be on your left. It cost $.50 to take any pictures. They ask that nicely. Very cool to see the process of fortune cookies being made! It's worth it to go to Chinatown, to pop in this little shop, and explore the other stores in the area.
author: Jen V.

description: Do you ever feel like everything you pick up has a sticker on it that says "Made in China?" Or that everything sold in Chinatown is made in China? Well, not at the fortune cookie factory.  As most people probably know, fortune cookies are not Chinese and you can witness them being made in America if you know which Chinatown alley to visit. I love seeing how stuff is made and watching the gentleman crank out fortune cookies is no exception.  When you enter the factory, there is about 14 square feet of standing room and you are greeted with a sign that says, "50 cents if you take a picture," or something to that affect.  I'll gladly give this joint 50 cents for a picture!  I really liked that when I had my picture taken, one gentleman (the owner?) said something in Chinese to the fortune cookie maker.  Later I learned that the man must have said smile because I have a great photo with the fortune cookie maker flashing an enthusiastic smile.  What a neat little place.
author: Courtney K.

description: Hole in the wall factory in an alley. A little shady with it being so dark and I'm a little uncomfortable with all the boxes of eggs siting out in the heat. But I loveee fortune cookies and they make it really fresh. It's $5.00/bag. I personally think the $1.00/bag of fortune cookies at panda express is a better deal but at least here its fresh. :)
author: linda p.

description: This is a fairly small factory and is a bit hidden. The factory is a bit outdated but love the fact that it does illustrate how the fortune cookies are made and it is nice to grab a few samples to try. They also sell some freshly made fortune cookies and related products if you are interested for a fairly cheap price. This is okay for tourism purpose.
author: H. H.

description:
Pretty good fortune cookies and it's made fresh and prices are cheap.  Kinda found the workers to be a little rude as one older man physically (not hard) pushed me off to the side so he could grab something.  Ummm..using words would be nice.  

Came home and was eating a fortune cookie and I had some paper pieces in my mouth.  And I KNOW for a fact that I took the fortune out of my cookie.  I'm thinking a piece of paper had gotten into the cookie batter as it was cooking.  Can you say gross?  Wouldn't make the trip down here for these...wasn't worth it IMO.  But if you're in the area, grab a bag or two...
author: Esther Y.

description: This place is magical. You see the workers making cookies and you can find it by following your nose. It's in a alley way. It's fun just looking for it
author: Michelle V.

description: This is a cool little spot just to check out how fortune cookies are made and to tip the nice ladies who make them. I feel like you don't really get to know a city unless you wander aimlessly down alleys in Chinatown searching for dirty fortune cookies.
author: Cec D.

description:
I first came here on a school field trip many years ago.  You go down this little alley in Chinatown, stop at a door in the wall and enter a Willie Wonkaesque world of fortune cookie goodness.  There is this machine with open flames and chains that cook these wonderful almond scented little rounds that are then folded over hot metal rods to form the best fortune cookies you will ever eat.  

Many years later, my wife and I were re-introduced to Golden Gate Fortune Cookies by a friend of ours who is seriously addicted to them.  He swears that they are made with some secret, probably illegal, substance that that makes them so good and I tend to agree.  Every time my wife and I go into the City we try to make a stop and bring home several bags of sweet, crunchy goodness.  Our lives would be less without them.
author: Douglas L.

description: In a dark, shady alley in Chinatown is a hidden fortune ... fortune cookie that is. While exploring the area, I sneaked to watch the hard working ladies effortlessly fold the fresh cookies to be sold to restaurants and the public. If was unbelievable how they would pull the cookies off the hot cast iron mold and quickly stuff an optimistic fortune and fold it into the perfect shape. The ladies were sweet enough to give me samples of their crispy wafers with a light sweet flavor. They sold it in different quantities and other flavors (e.g. chocolate). For some small frills, go check out how they make it, drop a few dollars on a bunch and leave with a fortune.
author: Santi T.

description:
It's small. It's a madhouse. It's in an alley. It's perfect.

I love the smell of hot fortune cookies. I like the flat ones that they sell because it's just so much easier to eat than actual fortune cookies. I also like the white and brown swirl cookies they have. It's not chocolate people! It's actually a light savory sweet "lam yu" flavor. 

This place really captures a bygone era of Chinatown.
author: Minda w.

description:
Little hole in the wall for sure. BRING CASH! It's small, very small. You walk in and the older gent starts talking with you. I was able to understand him no problem, but wasn't certain what he was getting at. Didn't matter, chatted with him a bit and bought a bag of mixed chocolate and regular. Got like 20+ (maybe 30 or more) in the bag for $4.50...not bad considering you buy 'em at the grocery store for that much and you get like 10.

Got the regular, but there was a bin with adult fortune cookies...kinda curious to know what might be inside them that makes them adult...hmm. 

Anyways, $0.50 if you want to take a picture. The older gent sort of distracts you, so you don't really get to pay attention to how they are making the cookies. I do have to say, the chocolate cookies are yum yum yummy! Fortunes are decent as well. Check it out...don't expect to stay long, just grab a bag and go. Maybe two bags, since one won't last you the trip to the car (or your transportation of choice).
author: Lily K.

description: Come here to see people make fortune cookies!!! They are fresh and delicious.
author: Jaime K.

description:
My boyfriend warned me, "It's really really small. It's in an alley." And yes indeedy, it was tiny and it was in an alley that I couldn't even find the street sign at the corner. 

The factory is really easy to miss, if not for the tourists lining up. I went on a Saturday afternoon, and thank goodness it wasn't too crowded. I waited for about 5 minutes and it was my turn at the front of the line. 

The factory only had 3 ladies working in front of the fortune cookie machine, folding the waffles into cookie shaped, and throwing those that got hard before they could be folded in a tin box that was the sample box. It was interesting to see. Particularly interesting that there was a paper sign that said, "if you take pictures, please pay 50 cents"

The cookies are fine. Delicious. And they come in regular flavor, chocolate flavor, and come in flat or cookies shaped. And there is also adult version fortune cookies. 

Overall, it's a fun tourist site. :) But I think it's once in awhile kind of site since it is kind of small.
author: Judy L.

description:
Tasty ...

And enlightening!

Now I know the person in charge of my fortune is NOT God, but a Chinese man who charges 50 cents to take a picture of him and his fortune cookies.
author: J S.

description:
Love this place, best fortune cookies ever.  I will drive to SF just to make a fortune cookie run (and to stop at snow garden while im in chinatown).

My favorite is the little bags of multiflavored silver dollar fortune cookie disks.  they have regular, strawberry, and chocolate.  all fresh and light and tasty.  They last pretty good in the pantry if you ziplock bag them.

Bring cash cause they only take cash, the bags are a good deal for fresh fortune cookies and they will give you a sample while you are there.  the big fortune cookie machines are fantastic contraptions to watch.

Pass on the "adult" fortune cookies, they dont make any sense and arent funny.  Go with the standard or chocolate cookies.  Buy a bunch and you might get a deal.
author: Chris K.

description:
Golden Gate Fortune Cookies is a hidden gem nestled in the heart of Chinatown. I've been coming here ever since I could remember and I always leave grinning from ear to ear. Sugar. Flour. Eggs. Vanilla. Yum!!!

The cute elderly ye-yes, poh-pohs, sok-soks, and yi-yis that run this place are always so friendly, good-hearted, and smiley. Kudos to the freshly baked fortune cookies they toss into your bag free of charge. The 'cow ear biscuits' are heavenly as well. Better than Mee Mee's and slightly cheaper. 

The only thing that's changed after all these years is the prices. I remember when an entire bag of round flats only costed $2. Now they're $4.75. Oh well, I guess you can't really blame them. Inflation has taken hold of everything!
author: Colleen W.

description:
Ever since I was a kid, I walked pass this fortune cookie spot probably hundreds of times!

I've probably only gotten fortune cookies 4x here in my lifetime, but they're the best fortune cookies ever. The best part is watching them being molded into the shape you see everywhere. 

ITS ZEE BEST!
author: Kenny L.

description:
We learned of Golden Gate Fortune Cookies from my Aunt and on a family trip to S.F., we decided to make the trek to Chinatown and check them out. There is nothing like taking in the sites and exploring the alleys of Chinatown. This place is small and you just might miss it. Trust your nose and you'll find the right place.

We left with 3 bags of the flat fortune cookies and plenty of "hot off the press" samples!
author: Pete S.

description: Been coming here since the 80s!
author: Ben L.

description:
We decided to wander by here pretty early on a Monday morning - 9:00 or so - so we were the only people around.  This made for a somewhat awkward experience.  We stood timidly in the doorway, peering in, trying to figure out if this was the place, until a man inside yelled 'Come in!'

So we went in, and stood there watching two women at fortune cookie machines pluck burning hot cookie molds from the metal circuits, lay a fortune across the center, and then fold them - all so quick we could barely follow the process.  Except for the machine sounds, it was entirely silent and I couldn't shake the feeling that I was in a sweatshop, observing the workers work in a lineup.  Yes, I KNOW that wasn't what was going on, just how my extrapolating, dramatic mind interpreted it.  I'm sure it would have been less creepy had more people been in the space than just us, and had they been conversing, or smiling, or had there been any jollity to the proceedings and/or observations.

It was, however, really neat to see how fortune cookies are made - who hasn't wondered how they get that paper in there? - and I love that they're willing to show their process to anyone.  They've got free samples all over the place and fortune cookies are definitely better flat and straight off the press.  My boyfriend bought a bag, and I eyed the sesame cookies, but we had just eaten a gigantic order of dim sum from Good Mong Kok and I just couldn't imagine that I would ever be hungry again in my life, so I didn't buy them.  I regretted THAT one when I was on the plane later!
author: Hannah E.

description: I convinced my boyfriend to come with me, since I love everything sweet related. I'm glad we went because it was very cool to see the staff making the cookies right in front of us. The elder man that greeted us was so cute! He was very excited to hand out samples and explain the process, and he got very excited when I bought the almond cookies that there were selling, which were a deal at $3.75. I told the man "Gung Hei Fat Choy", Happy New Year, which made the man so excited! I loved him, and I wish I could adopt him as my grandpa.
author: Lisa H.

description: pretty cool...its in an ALLEY by the way...free samples and 50 cents for a picture! =]
author: Charlie L.

description:
I LOVE this little hole in the wall, literally, hole in the wall.

When you walk in, there's not much space but they give you free fortune cookie samples and then you can buy bags of the cookies for super cheap. 

I personally like to buy the flat ones and then have them with tea! 

This place is super hard to find, it's in a little alley, but definitely walk around and look for it, it's such a cool little place to check out!
author: Katlin L.

description: This is a must stop every time we go to San Francisco.  Love the smell of the cookies as you turn down the alley.  Usually pretty crowded; have your cash ready, try some samples and get enough cookies to last.  I've heard you can bring your own fortunes and have them added freshly made cookies.  Haven't done that yet but plan on it the next time we go:-)
author: Luann C.

description:
They had THE best almond cookies we've ever had.  It was a little hard to find, but with Yelp we got there.  
There was a man handing out the warm circular cookie before they are molded as samples when you walk in.  There isn't much room, but this is one of those spots where the smaller space made the experince better.  The kids loved watching the lady fold the cookies.  
This was a unique experience!  Worth pushing the stroller up the hill in Chinatown on Christmas day to see :)
author: Deborah M.

description:
This is a very hard to find hole in the wall.  Literally, a HOLE in the wall, down a shady alley.  But all alleys in SF, Chinatown are shady, aren't they?

But once you find it, you know you've got the place!  It's a small little factory making fortune cookies by hand.  There were two ladies working to fold the cookies - peeling the cookie from the hot iron with their hands, and folding the little notes in each cookie.  A man was standing near the front bagging the flat fortune cookies which I bought two bags of.  He gave us samples to try.  Warm and delicious!

I bought two bags.  And he put in an extra scoop of loose cookies into by bag so we could eat on our way out.

I asked if we could takae a picture of the ladies making the cookies, and they said "OK!".  Only thing, I didn't see the sign that said "If you like take picture, 50 cents."  My BF warned me of this before I snapped the picture, so we just left.  How  Chinese is that?  Oh well, no more peeect-cha!
author: JME C.

description:
They give out free samples of fortune cookies while you wait in line!

We were originally going to actually go inside to buy something, but due to my friends being at a nearby restaurant ahead of schedule, we cut our stay here short and just settled for that free cookie.

Also, they charge for photos ($0.50 I believe), so keep the lens cap on!
author: Kenny O.

description:
Went looking for the bakery as it was hidden in an alley way. I was hit by the aromatic delight before I even saw it! The owner offered some warm cookies as sample and I ended buying a big bag of the flatten ones. 

The owner threw in a few extra cookies that were still warm which I immediately started munching on as soon as I left the shop.

This place is a keeper, I will be back Golden Gate Fortune Cookies.
author: Jean K.

description: Really 4.5 stars. I was recommended by a customer who lives in San Francisco. I loved the experience of walking through Chinatown but going to the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie Factory, you have to walk down a seedy alley. Once you walk in you see how small and dingy the shop is, the ladies are sitting there with ancient machines. It's a sweat shop!! I promised my friend I would get her fortune cookies I got a bag for her and myself, once I decided what I wanted the owner was yelling 9 dolla 9 dolla I wanted to say hold your horses, but I was polite, paid and left. I saw alot of tourist going in there. I would never recommend this business to anyone you're rushed and uncomfortable. I have to say Chinatown was amazing it was like being transported to China.
author: Michele T.

description: Interesting place!  Takes about 5 minutes of your time and kids were amused by this place.   It's tricky to find because it's located in a tiny alley. Be prepared to pay the man $0.50 if you snap a picture in there.
author: Parents Choices O.

description:
It was really cool to walk around the little alley ways in Chinatown.  As part of a scavenger hunt we had to go buy a bag of cookies and then read a large sign in the back of the shop. 

The owner Franklin Yee is a nice guy handing out samples/mistakes.  I love how he directed me toward the Adult aka Sex fortune cookies. What are you trying to insinuate Mr. Yee? 

Note: If you want to take a picture of the fortune cookies being made, you have to pay 50 cent.  Got that?

I'll be back for a few bags of cookies and yes for the X-rated ones for sure.
author: Infodiva B.

description:
Love love love this place! So awesomely delicious!! Never thought fortune cookies could be so good! Hidden in an alley, so don't be alarmed! Makes the experience more unforgetable!! I definitely recommend this place! GO GO GO! What are you waiting for!?

P.S.
If you're thinking about buying a bag.. buy an extra one or two more. Trust. They will be gone inside your tummies in no time.
author: Joan L.

description: I arrived her just as a large group of school children did. It was so cramned in there that I could hardly move. But I did manage to snap some pics of people making fortune cookies, so I was satisfied.
author: Paul G.

description:
I was in San Fran and staying about 2 blocks from this place.  Saw that it got great reviews online so I walked here one early morning on my own while my husband wanted to sleep in.

It was kind of hard to find since it's in an alley way and the sign is quite small.  Once I walked in the man at the front was very friendly and gave me a sample cookie as I watched the workers in back make fresh fortune cookies.  i bought a small bag of 6 cookies for $1 and was on my way.   The cookies were fresh and who doesn't like getting a fortune!

I definitely wouldn't go if I hadn't been staying close.  It's not the most amazing tourist attraction but if you're already in china town it's kind of fun to see them make them by hand.  Kind of a sketchy alley too but I was there pretty early in the morning and there weren't many people around.
author: Jen D.

description:
Oh....the great flavor of fresh made fortune cookies..YUMMY!
i always buy the irregular flat cookies.
not interested in getting a fortune.
just eating the fresh cookies.
these guys have been here forever...
use to come here growing up in sf.
wish i lived closer to buy more often.
will make my trip when i visit the folks.
better be soon, because i'm eating them fast!
:)
author: Kei ..

description: This place was kinda hard to find, but we followed other tourists so it was fine. They don't take credit cards so we almost gave up  (we had a $100 dollar bill) we asked if they had change and they did! So we got the flat fortune cookies, they were really good, the sample we had were warm but the bag we bought were cold. I felt like the fresh, warm cookies were way better. Cool production line in a tight space.
author: Andrea A.

description:
My friend said she had heard about this place on t.v.  We then went on the Ride the Ducks San Francisco Tour and the guide mentioned this place as well.  We knew we had to go.

We decided to take the trolley to this place.  The driver said it was about a block away from where the trolley was going to stop.  We walked down what I believed to be the steepest hill we walked in San Francisco and found the alley it was located at.  When we arrived, we were the only ones there.  We were able to sample cookies for free and buy cookies ($1 for a small bag of fortune cookies).  

Unfortunately, it quickly became crowded with customers so I was only able to do two "write your own fortune" fortune cookies ($0.50 per cookie).  I had also wanted to buy the adult fortune cookies but like I said, it was crowded and I just wanted to get out.  I guess I'll never know what pervy fortunes were in those cookies :( .

It's super cheap and as authentic as it gets.  I'm not deducting any stars for cleanliness/customer service, etc.  I liked it just the way it was.
author: Analily V.

description: Worth a stop at this tiny factory to watch fortune cookies being made. They offer samples of the flat vanilla ones. Cool. Buy a bag of vanilla and chocolate fortune cookies. :D
author: Lisa C.

description:
Being a native San Franciscan, I've always thought this was a tourist trap with overpriced fortune cookies and snacks. 

I change my mind.

The aroma of freshly made fortune cookies welcomes you as you step inside the factory/store. You'll almost always see two or three ladies sitting on stools plucking round cookies off the conveyor belt thing and shaping them into fortune cookies with their hands while they're still warm! The workers are friendly, and give out warm round cookie samples! That, my friend, is art. :D
