Prices are reasonable. I always leave the place with a bag of round fortune cookies (I prefer them over fortune cookies) while munching on samples they always throw in with your purchase. :)
author: Tiffany L.

description: Oh my good lord. DELICIOUS fortune cookies. First time I stopped by with my now ex and we took one look and said, "let's get out of here." It looks like a dumpy hole in the wall with a million health code violations. The second time I went here was with my fiance on the Chinatown ghost tour and I actually tried one of their cookies (the flat, unfolded fortune cookies) and they were delicious! Too bad we didn't have cash on us to buy a $4 bag
author: Rachel S.

description:
My fondest memory of this place is walking by the fortune cookie factory on my way to visit my grandma at the sweat shop in the same alley =)

Unfortunately, I never actually went in there when I was a kid. I finally had my opportunity 25 years later to go and get fresh fortune cookies.  

My quick 2 minute stop consist of buying the flat cookies, paying the man, getting the free handful of fresh fortune cookies after the man handled the money with the same hand and leaving. Although, I wish I could tell him, stop giving me fortune cookies with the same hand. But oh well, they still taste gooood =)
author: Kimmy C.

description: I love Flat cookies. I saw many tourists drop by there to pick up samples, but not buying any bag. An old man was very generous many years ago, but he asked $0.50  to take a photo even I purchased $3.75 cookies (Price was up also). I still love their cookies, but this visit was not happy one.
author: Vicki S.

description:
Boy, look at what one of the cookies i got last time i was there told me....

 ___________________________________________________
|                                                                                                                       |
|      Try to be more useful to find the perfect balance in your life        |
|                                                                                                                       |
|___________________________________________________|      ...(in bed)

Look, I'm already trying hard to be cool and funny, isn't it enough?? Gosh!

Hmm, ok. 

Well...  20 000 fortune cookies are hand-made each day by a couple of crafty chinese ladies in this closet size factory.

Here's to usefulness!
author: Margie B.

description:
This is a teeny tiny little shop where you can see how to make fortune cookies. Watch out - the entrance is literally in an easy to miss alley. I was about to walk past it when a grandpa-type man welcomed me and showed me inside. Oh, here's the shop! 

Photos are $.50, but I didn't take any. I could barely take in everything around me when the grandpa man started offering me samples of unfolded fortune cookies. I thought it would taste like every other fortune cookie I've ever had, but it was way better. So this is what fresh ones taste like. I wonder how old all the other fortune cookies I had ever eaten were. 

There were tons to choose from - regular, unfolded, swirl, and even ones marked "adult." I ended up getting a back of 30 for $3.75 and hoped it would withstand the trip back to Chicago. For the most part, the cookies survived. Oh, as an added bonus, the grandpa man threw in a bunch of warm, fresh unfolded cookies into our bag as we left. 

If you're a tourist in Chinatown, check this place out.
author: Christina G.

description: Five minutes. That's it. That's all you need to know about this grungy bit of cookiness.  Do not waste your time coming here unless you already in China Town. You walk in to this tiny place after going down a grungy alley. The sign says if you take a picture it costs $.50. They have three old fashioned cookie ovens with a miserable Chinese worker at each one inserting the fortune and hand folding the cookie. Big freakin' deal.
author: Mike M.

description:
Day 4 of MWLAWMBF:
As you walk down the alley, pay attention to the signs. I swear I walked down the alley once and I didn't see it until other people were crowding in front of it. Anyways, after our yummy egg tarts, we decided to go by the GG Fortune Cookie factory. I read on yelp that it's one of the best places to go. 

There is one lady making cookies - taking the warm cookies off the conveyor belt type machine and shaping them quickly. It was quite interesting and I wanted to take a picture. Taking a picture inside of the fortune cookie store costs 50 cents. I think that's a bit outrageous, but I guess it's a way for them to make more money. 

The fortune cookies are pretty cheap though. I got a bag with chocolate and regular fortune cookies for less than $5. If I remember correctly, it was $3.75 and a handful more cookies from the man selling them. 

YUM FORTUNE COOKIES.
author: Nina Y.

description: Great fresh cookies. A bit over priced for what you can get on the street. The place is tucked into a side alley so look for it.
author: Scott R.

description:
ANN: pretty cool place. hidden in an alley. although, the store itself is small. i think it was pretty neat to see how they actually make the fortune cookie right in front of you. the cookie itself to me was pretty average, IMO. tasted like every other fortune cookie out there. 

CED:  Cool place, but its super small.  This alley makes me feel like I'm in the old days.  The fortune cookies are fresh so they will be great, but the tour is basically bam bam bam, done.  Overall I'd say drop by if your near by, but not highly recommended.  Really cheap too.

VERDICT:  Go if your near by, otherwise skip to the next attraction!
author: Cedric R.

description:
Fresh fortune cookies. That's all that needs to be said. Warm and freshly made right in front of your eyes.  Nothing better than popping by and getting a fresh bag. But you are warned that after tasting these you'll never be able to look at those fortune cookies that you get at Chinese restaurants the same again. I love coming here. I try to come by here whenever I can. 

It's located in a weird hidden type of location, but as long as you have google maps you'll find it. I kinda like wandering around chinatown until I find it, but that's just me.
author: Tonie F.

description: We have been coming here since I was a kid.  Very unique place where they make there own fortune cookies in a very unique process with a large rotating wheel of little grills that cook the cookies in the precise amount of time as it rotates around to a person that folds the round cookie into the fortune cookie shape and inserts the fortune.  Pick up a bag of round cookies that have not been folded into the shape of a fortune cookie.  Buy a bag of cookies and they always throw in some free samples to try.  Without a doubt the best fortune cookie I have ever tried.  They also have chocolate fortune cookies.
author: Bill S.

description:
While wandering around aimlessly in San Francisco's Chinatown, we stray towards Ross Alley in hopes of finding hidden treasures. Jackpot. We found it. Staring us in the eyes is the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie Factory. The old Chinese man sitting in front greets us with a warm smile and directs us to go inside to take a look. "Hello. Hi. Come in. Hello. Hi." repeats the old man.

We go in to discover that the name of the place perfectly describes the images we are seeing. It really is just a fortune cookie factory. A lady is sitting in the middle of the room folding the hot freshly made fortune cookies from this huge oven/machine/contraption thing. Just think "Willie Wonka and the Chocolate Factory" minus the crazy Willie Wonka, minus the crazy magical effects, and replace chocolate with Fortune Cookie and there you go.

When you first walk in, a man on the right side opens some containers and offers you some free samples. On the left side is shelves full of fortune cookies ready to be bought. Each bag is ranges from $3.50 to $5 from what I saw. The lady, which I spoke about earlier, is working like a robot. 1. Grab hot fortune cookie circular dough. 2. Fold in half. 3. Wrap around a metal stick to give the cookie its curve. 4. Place fortune cookie in cookie sheet. 5. Repeat. Now imaging doing this for hours upon hours. I'm pretty sure she doesn't do it all day.... but talk about repetitive stress syndrome! Any lawyers out there?

So we purchase some bags of fortune cookies to take home. Cash only. The nice thing is when you buy a bag, the guy throws some extra open cookies in the bag for you to snack on while you are on your way. I thought that was a nice touch... Even though he's probably just trying to get rid of the defective ones who didn't quite meet up to the tough fortune cookie standards.

A cool thing happened while I was finished paying. A tourist couple open up a their tourist book and open the page to this place. In the description, there is a picture of that old man in front! That's crazy! The old man comes in, grabs the book and taunts the other workers in jest of his celebrity status. That gave us all a good laugh. On the way out, I had to take a picture with the guy. 

A few hours later when I arrived home, I opened my standard Chinatown pink little plastic bag and started munching on the defective fortune cookies. Still crisp and fresh. I smiled with happiness because 1) I was able to feed my hunger and 2) I was finally letting the defective fortune cookies fulfill their destiny.
author: Leo C.

description:
Who hasn't had a fortune cookie? Maybe if you live in the swamps of Florida or if you're a hillbilly. 

Not all fortune cookies are created equal. Theirs is one of the best in the city. It's a real, old-fashioned working fortune cookie making factory with the little Chinese "mo" (ladies) folding them into their famous shapes while they're still hot and pliant. You can get them in choc and strawberry flavors nowadays. 

If your timing is right, you'll see the train of tourists following their guide into the store for a visit and taste of the cookies and watch them leave with a bagful. The smell of those sweet, warm cookies just brings back great childhood memories. The alley, Ross is also full of history dating back to the 1800's, probably haunted stories too.
author: Ry T.

description:
I grew up munching on delicious cookies from Golden Gate Fortune Cookies, and I'm still enjoying them today.

I still remember visiting the tiny shop during a field trip while attending elementary school and standing inside watching in awe of how quickly the lady was inserting fortunes and folding up the hot cookies.  I still enjoy watching the process now because it truly is an artform.

My mom used to regularly bring home large bags of the round fortune cookie rejects for the family to snack on, and after she passed away my aunt took over supplying the family with these sweet, crunchy discs of golden goodness.  I don't see my aunt too often these days, but whenever I'm in Chinatown I do try to stop by and pick up a bag or two.

The cookies taste just as good now as they did back then, and I'll always love them for bringing back fond memories.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description: Oh, when it comes out of the fire, it's hot and crunchy and very light.  The best tasting little crunchy round cookie!  Some days I try to go in and buy the rejects, because it is cheap, but there are days that they don't make many mistakes.  Just following the smell down this alley around the corner of the shoe store on Jackson between Stockton and Grant (closer to Stockton).  I don't think they take credit card.  They do give out samples. $3.75 per bag with fortunes.  Flat ones are in a bag too without fortunes. Did you know SF made the first fortune cookies?
author: Helen L.

description:
This was another place my un-trusty little tour book said was a MUST SEE, when visiting Chinatown.  Even though it failed me the day before with the Grateful Dead House I thought it couldn't fail me twice now could it?

It was hot, I'd been looking for Ross Alley for far too long and had been through too many clouds of smoke and had been almost spit on one too many times that I was at my breaking point.  GBF#1 and I are looking and looking and looking for Ross Alley we couldn't find it because the end of the alley we were walking past only had signs in Chinese and unfortunately neither one of us reads Chinese.

Using my extremely acute analytical skills I pick an alley that just had to be it, it was but now the trick to find #56.  Nope that's not it, nope that's not it either, nope neither is that, opps sorry thought you were Golden Gate Fortune Cookies, oh wait there's the sign you mean that's it?  Wow so NOT what I expected.  I was expected something big and I was expecting to be able to smell the cookies baking like I do when ever I drive by Tsue Chong in Seattle.  Nope there was none of that. 

Anyways we walk in and are greeted by some very unhappy looking people folding cookies who pointed at a sign that told us if we wanted pictures we had to pay.  I decided not to take any pictures because I was completely underwhelmed with this place but than out of no where this man appeared and gave me a fresh cookie that made things a little better but not really because it was flat and missing a fortune. I guess if you like fortune cookies hunt this place out if not I don't think you'll be missing much if you decide to skip a trip here.
author: Me H.

description:
What do I love about Yelp? There's so much good to say about it but one of my favourite things is to find hidden gems, especially if you can explore them with local Yelpers.

I was honoured to have been shown around Chinatown but local Yelp legend Froyo Girl Lolia S. She took me down a little side road and before we arrived at the fortune cookie factory, my nose smelt some lovely baking aromas wafting out.

The factory is actually a little cottage industry with 2 or 3 automated machines cooking the batter but the final inserting of the message and folding is done by hand. Fascinating to watch.

As with all baked goods, they taste the best straight out of the oven, still warm in the hard. These fortune cookies were no exception.

Well worth a look even if you're not a tourist like I was. Thanks Froyo Girl!
author: Yee Gan O.

description:
What trip to SF would be complete without a trip to Golden Gate Fortune Cookies? On our recent trip to the Bay Area, I knew hubby would not leave without going by here. He just loves the flat fortune cookies -- the ones before they wrap cookies into.

Since we were in Chinatown, and after we'd walked around a while, I asked him if he wanted to go to GG and I mean, I knew he was gonna say yes so I don't even know why I asked. This place always gets 5 stars from me since no fortune cookie beats the ones from here.

We walk to Ross Alley and see a bunch of tourists wide eyed and looking at their guide books not sure if they were at the right place. I mean seriously, if you've ever been there you'd be a bit confused as well. 

Anyway, I picked up a bag and asked hubby how many bags. He said 'oh just one'. I rolled my eyes. You don't come to SF Chinatown and buy just one bag of these cookies. I didn't listen and picked up 2 bags. I asked the man in Cantonese how much and he said $7. WOW, I don't remember it being $3.50 a bag, but never mind, it's still worth it.

Now we've finished one bag and hubby I'm sure is really happy that I picked up two bags instead of listening to him. Oh by the way... it still costs 50 cents to take a picture so they didn't raise those prices any!
author: Anita L.

description:
WTF is wrong with me. I log in expecting to update my review, but I hadn't reviewed it yet!

I walked down the alley on a Sunday thinking they were closed, and secretly hoping with all my heart that they weren't. And they were one of the few stores open on the rainy Sunday! Yay.

I walked in and bought a few bags. There was no one in there, probably because of the rain. I took a picture today and didn't get charged $.50 for doing it. I wonder if it's because I bought like 10 bags though. 

Every time I've gone in there, there are always people coming and going. Not today though. The rain probably kept most people out. The regular fortune cookies are $3.50/bag, the chocolate and regular mixed are $4.50. 

I love this place. I always buy the flat ones and top off homemade parfaits with them. Or I just grab a few and eat them with vanilla ice cream. Yum.
author: Ming-Jou C.

description:
San Francisco's best kept secret! [Or by the amount of reviewers, might I say worst kept...] But really, this little factory is awesome and I wish it didn't take me so long to discover it. Tourists and locals alike need to know that this place exists.

I'm slightly confused by the claims of this place being hard to find. It's between the two most popular streets in Chinatown: Stockton and Grant, so it's in the heart of  the cultural environment and touristy shops that you're most likely also there to experience. Unless you completely lack sense of direction and/or you don't have a phone with a map, you won't have trouble finding this little gem. Use said sense of direction and maps to get to Ross Alley, look for the clearly marked sign above the entrance, and you are on your way to perhaps the best fortune cookies ever! 

The smell as you walk in is phenomenal... I was immediately greeted with free samples - flattened fortune cookies, and warm at that! The first bite was all I needed to know I was definitely buying a bag of them. They have different flavors, styles, and sizes. Everything is priced very well and with a purchase, you get a handful of additional free samples to enjoy after you leave the store. 

The environment is pretty cool. You can see all of the equipment that they use to make the batter as well as the ladies that actually insert the fortune and fold them up. It was very interesting to observe.

All in all, it was a great experience and the fortune cookies are out of this world amazing. If you're visiting San Francisco, stopping here is a necessity.
author: Heather V.

description:
Yum! It's always a treat coming here!! I always get a bag of fortune cookies here for $3.50 and the man always grabs a handful of the flat fortune cookies and dumps them into my bag! Yay!! :D

This place has a Chinatown feel to it, especially because it's in this alley! It's fun to just look at them make the cookies and see all the different varieties of cookies that they sell!! Look for the GIANT fortune cookie!!! ahahaha It's hilarious!! :D
author: CeCe C.

description:
As a native who grew up just around the corner, this place is the best. I come back often to get a bag of the flat cookies and on special occasions the fortune cookies.  (Don't care for the chocolate ones though). 

Came in today and got some cookies. The same old man throws in some additional cookies into the bag as a little treat. Always busy and somehow he knows where everything is. I love his accounting system. 

I bring out of town visitors here to see how fortune cookies are made, handmade of course. I love freaking them out by dragging them into an alley, telling a few stories of my youth and then getting some cookies. . . pretty funny. 

When I bring guests, I give a few bucks to take a bunch of pictures and it makes a great souvenir for my guests. It also makes these folks feel special since it is a unique and old school business and it's much appreciated. This place is the best and is a real San Francisco treat.
author: Stefan L.

description: Love this place never changes. The cookies are yum!
author: Syl M.

description:
Great place, the people are friendly.  I been there for at least 5 or 6 times, I;m sure they recognize me, but they still give me warm welcomes like I'm a new customer (although i never bought any cookie yet)
The free cookie are nice too, they were still warm when the owner press them out. So I always stop by because it is right next door to my acupuncturist's clinic
author: Steven R.

description:
Easily over a decade since my last visit to GGFC, I was so excited to find myself in this Chinatown alley again.  And, it was the perfect night - chilly and muggy but not too uncomfortable - a perfect night in sf, really.

I love walking through the city as if I'm a tourist - seeing things with new eyes.  And while this place was at once familiar, I felt like a child experiencing a new candy!

I was immediately snap-happy with camera in hand and must have taken 5 shots before I noticed the dilapidated handwritten sign requesting for $1 for each photo taken - oops.  We eventually tipped accordingly, since that didn't stop me from taking more photos.

They had a fun variety of fortune cookies and "flat" cookie rounds, plain and chocolate, large and mini!  There was also a whole shelf of large fortune cookies in a clear round plastic container, wrapped in a bow - photos forthcoming.

Coming here again just reminds me of how much I love SF - I literally drove about 20 minutes from home, but felt a world away...  small dark alley way, friendly (but obviously over-worked & exhausted) ladies working away, and warm, fresh cookie rounds...   This, coupled with loose leaf genmaicha green tea and a warm pink box of gai me bao - clearly a 5 star night!  (minus one star because while she unselfishly handed us a huge handful of extra cookie rounds, she did so just after handling our dollar bills - ewww - but I can't really be a germophobe in this setting, I guess!)

*Check out other reviews for tips on getting fortune cookies w/personalized fortunes!
author: Olma M.

description:
The other Yelpers ain't lyin' - this place is down a super-sketchy alley (reportedly the OLDEST in SF), and a little hard to find to boot, as Google map's directions will get you close, but not exactly there. We found it by chance, and by consulting the "Ross Alley" address. 

But anyhoo - I was glad we stuck it out and found it! It's old, cavernous, and kinda creepy, but they have bags of fortune cookies for $2, and lots of other delicious looking treats. 

That said, we must have visited at an off-time, because the people working there barely talked to us, and when I paid to take a pic of the woman pulling cookie forms off the awesome ancient machinery (they have a sign asking for $.50 a photo), she didn't even look up. 

We were there for approx. 10 minutes, grabbed some cookies and left - but it was still pretty cool and I recommend it for history nerds & fortune cookie lovers. 

Side note: my first fortune said "Try to practice frugality - it's important" - this while I'm on a splurge-y vacation! Whatevs.
author: Amie S.

description: You get to make your own fortune cookies?! Well I made a ton for my friends with funny messages. It's in a little alley and they also serve CHOCOLATE fortune cookies. I had fun going in this run down place and writing messages and seeing it get placed into the cookies. Everything is also cheap so if's a fun experience that won't rob your wallet. I'd only go here if I was visiting Chinatown though. Good times.
author: Andy N.

description: A tiny gem of a store hidden in an alleyway in Chinatown. They make all their fortune cookies (and not in the usual shape!) by hand... no pictures though, that'll cost you $0.50. We got several bags of the round, flat-shaped fortune cookies and they were very good! Nice crunch, slightly sweet, and fresh baked. Will be back!
author: Joanne L.

description: Heard about this place while on a double decker bus tour and after reading positive reviews on Yelp, I decided I NEEDED to check this place out. This little shop makes fresh fortune cookies and you can watch them do it, however, it really is TINY so it can get a little crowded inside. Although they charge 50 cents to take a photo, I considered it a "tip" for the people making the cookies so it didn't really bother me. They sell both regular and chocolate cookies and if you get the ones that have not been folded into breakable fortune cookies then you get more for your money...although no fortunes. The old man inside even gives you free samples when you walk in and then tosses a few more samples in your bag after you make a purchase. I recommend buying a large bag for $4.75 because you seem to get the most bang for your buck that way. They also have small bags of about 5 fortune cookies for $1. The cookies really do taste better than other ones I've had (mostly from Chinese restaurants), most likely because they are fresh and not stale and nasty from sitting on someone's shelf. I would definitely come back here to stock up the next time I visit San Francisco!
author: Brian P.

description:
Thank you, to all the Yelpers who took pictures and distracted the little Chinese ladies at the fortune cookie assembly lines to screw up and wait far too long to fold the little doughies so that the doughies become fortune cookie flops.  For $3.75, you get a heaping warm pile of fortune cookie flops that you binge on after you go back to your financial district offices.  

Unlike the other "Golden Gate" place in C-town, these guys are never "on vacation."
author: Emily H.

description:
If you are traveling through Chinatown this is a must see. After all, the fortune cookie was invented in SF!  I wouldn't go out of my way to see it, as its no more than a 5 minute experience.  

My friends and I wanted some more information: Who writes the fortunes? Where do they write the fortunes? Where was it invented? etc. Unfortunately there was a language barrier.  

I bought a bag of fortune cookies and plan to dip them in chocolate and decorate them.
author: Jessica G.

description: Way smaller than you expect it to be. You basically just walk in...some guy stops you about halfway and offers you some samples.....then points you to the shelf where all the stuff they have for sale is at and tries to get you to buy. 50 cents if you wish to take a photo but its really not worth it since there are tons of photos on yelp. Def worth to check out if you want to buy some cookies or want to see how they're made.
author: Obed C.

description: Must see for any trip to San Fran.  A hidden gem and really cool to see my fortune being made was worth the visit.  Super fresh and Delicious fortune cookies for sale and they threw in many hot of the press ones to munch on for the rest of the day.
author: William B.

description:
I love this place. 

The first time I went here was in February for my birthday weekend in San Francisco. I'm a southern californian and when I heard about this place I just had to go. It wasn't as hard to find as mentioned by some of the previous people because I guess I already had those expectations and I earnestly was searching for the secret alley-way that led to this glorious fortune cookie factory. 

Finally, I found it with my group of friends and yes, you're walking down the pathway to this delicious place and you can smell the lingering cookie smell becoming stronger, indicating you're getting nearer. Found it! 

It's just like others have described, a little tine cookie factory with Chinese people working there. We took pictures inside and they give out free samples for you to try. Since it was my first time, I didn't grab that many bags, but after devouring them on our way back home... I wish I had grabbed FIFTY bags! 

I got the multi-colored little coin shaped cookies. They were delicious. You can taste the individual flavors that was indicated by the color: pink (Strawberry), brown (Chocolate), and original (Original). Boy, eating those was amazing. Plus, we later went to Fisherman's Wharf and I swear a seagull was eyeing me. Eventually one snatched one  of my delicious cookies right out of my hands... be weary fortune cookie connoisseurs for the seagulls are keeping an eye on that delicious prize of yours.

So my friends got the "adult" fortune cookies. Let me tell you this, reason for the one missing star, the word "adult" indicated to my friends and me that it was suppose to be kinky. Actually, it's no where near there. It's the same mumbo jumbo fortune you would find in any other fortune cookie. I like the original ones because they have better fortunes in my opinion.

So in conclusion, if you are ever visiting good ole San Francisco and you stop by in Chinatown, don't forget to stop by the Golden Gate Fortune Cookies favtory. You won't regret it, it'll just make your day even better :)
author: Cindy C.

description:
My cookies have traveled from their birthplace in San Francisco...to San Diego....to Las Vegas....to Wisconsin...in order to get them back to people and PROVE they are the best.

Staff is super sweet and friendly....recommend the chocolate ones for sure.
You will never ever find a fresher tasting cookie of fortune anywhere else!

Be careful not to miss this stop whenever you are near Chinatown. Literally a random door into a yummy place.
author: Jessica R.

description:
small hole-in-the-wall place and only worth going if you're already in chinatown.  but if you're planning a trip to chinatown, you should go find this place.  half the fun is finding it (located down a small alley) but a great spot to take the kids for their afternoon sugar-fix instead of buying (another) crappy ice cream sandwich as some corner store.  definitely the real deal.  

bonus:  check out the ramshackle store-front across the street where an old chinese lady sells specialty paper and manuscripts that are designed to ward-off evil spirits!
author: Aaron R.

description:
This was one of the places that I wanted to visit in Chinatown San Fran. This was in a hidden gem of a back alley so if you're driving, it would be easier to get out of your car and look for the place because we had to drive 2-3 times around the block to realize that it was hidden in a back alley.

The old man gave the bf and I some samples...some of them were fresh and pipin' hot. I laughed at a sign that said if you wanted a picture with the lady making the fortune cookies, you had to pay an extra 50 cents. The bf bought the unmade fortune cookies (circular-shaped) because he said they're easier to eat. Haha.

I loved the smell of fresh fortune cookies. Oh man, now I'm craving some fortune cookies...especially fresh from the oven.
author: Polly C.

description:
This place is literally a hole in the wall!  It was actually quite easy to find, once you're able to locate Ross Alley in Chinatown.  We walked down the tiny alleyway, in search of the factory, and I was almost thinking that perhaps it didn't exist, but then my friend pointed it out.  It's such a hole in the wall, that you could totally miss it if you're weren't looking carefully.

I was expecting the type of "factory" that you'd see on those Food Network programs where they show you how cheese or candy is made.  This factory is MUCH different, MUCH better.  It literally consists of two, maybe three contraptions in the back churning out round fortune cookies.  As soon as you walk in, the nice old man working at the first machine will poke a circular, pre-folded cookie from the machine and hand it to you.  It's hot off the press!  So fresh that when I first bit into it, it merely dented because it was still soft.  After a couple seconds, though, it acquired the characteristic crisp, and it was probably the tastiest fortune cookie I've ever had.

Of course, the novelty of it all might have made it taste better too.  

Overall, it's a cute place, but most of the stars that I'm giving to this place is more due to location and atmosphere.  This really is historic Chinatown, the heart of it.  I mean, it's in an alleyway!  

And the cutest part of all:  next door, there is another tiny establishment, and the people there are quite proud of their fifteen minutes of fame. On their storefront, they have hand written, in black marker on a white piece of paper: I'm in this movie--The Pursuit of Happiness!

How cute!  Loves it!
author: Vivian C.

description:
I can't believe that someone said this place has "authentic" fortune cookies, when they're not Chinese at all. That said, this small shop is really cool. Smaller than most SF apartments, but they're always willing to let people come in and take a look at how these things are made.

5 stars for being able to buy fresh cookies, either flat or folded. And the cookies are sweet without leaving that gritty feeling that some fortune cookies leave.
author: Roy J.

description:
Hole in the wall in a shady alley in Chinatown. Gangster.

Being a 99.9% SF native, I am ashamed to say that it took me 22 years to learn about this fortune cookie factory. It really is a factory - you'll see the assembly line and machinery once you're inside. The man forces you to take samples (flat fortune cookies).

Normally I don't eat fortune cookies...you know, the ones they give you for free when you get your check? 

BUT THESE FORTUNE COOKIES ARE DIFFERENT. They are so crispy (they stay crispy for WEEKS...how? We probably don't want to know why), fresh and buttery. They are addictive. They must have crack in them, I swear.

My sister gave me crap about going all the way to SF to buy them. She said a fortune cookie is just a fortune cookie. No. She doesn't understand. 

My roommate demands me to get these for her every time I go home to visit. 

Their chocolate fortune cookies are moderately flavored. You know the Asian chocolate taste? Yes. The fake stuff. But they're quite tasty since they're blended with notes of butter and sesame (read: plain fortune cookie taste).

I recommend getting the assorted mix so you get a taste of everything.

Be aware: many tourists and school children frequent this place....AND no pictures allowed (unless you pay them..haha)

Go and you will never eat the commercial fortune cookies again.

And try to only eat one. I dare you.
author: Grace C.

description:
If it wasnt for yelp I would not have found this place! It's very tiny, in an alley, and you will have to squeeze around if there are other tourists there at the same time. You pretty much take a peek at the machines. Be sure to buy some ! MAny different kinds. Smells good. Sometimes they give samples. Very good price. Make great gifts too! 
CASH only!
author: Veranna N.

description:
Finding this place is half the fun. Make sure you take your nearest Chinese-speaking friend with you, because it's like a scavenger hunt and you need every advantage you can get. It's even better if you Chinese-speaking friend is actually of Chinese origin, because the Chinese people on the street seem to want to be really helpful to their kin.

Once you find the place, a long, open, hole-in-the-wall that doesn't quite live up to the expectations of a "factory," be prepared to pay $0.50 for a picture with the lady who folds the warm fortune cookies as they come off the press. Well worth the price, since the man working there will probably give you a ton of free samples - chocolate, strawberry and plain. And a bag to take home and enjoy will cost you less than $4. Whether you're a tourist or a local you has just never ventured over, its worth going to just once in life.
author: Jesal P.

description:
For her 4th birthday, the theme for my niece's party was Mulan.  Auntie Joc was tasked with procuring fortune cookies to be used as favors and I of course headed for GG Fortune Cookies.  I was ambitious if not somewhat arrogant in my task thinking I could go in there and ask any one of the many  fluent English speaking vendors for 100 *individually wrapped* cookies.  WRONG!  The old and monolingual Chinese woman from behind the counter looked at me like my nose hairs were on fire when I asked for individually wrapped cookies.  I repeated *One bag, one cookie!  One bag, one cookie!* over and over until she threw her hands up in the air and tossed  me a giant bag of fortune cookies--you know, the special kind with adult messages in them.  

Girl's search for cookie ends in misfortune.
author: Joc V.

description: BEST FORTUNE COOKIES IN SF! They're so addicting! They have a great mild sweet flavor and crunchy texture. Some of their fortunes are funny too. Only $2.75 for a bag!
author: Jean T.

description: Cute little shop, on Ross avenue, off jackson street. Snaps are 50 cents, and samples are free.
author: A R.

description:
Total waste of time....one small crowded room...one lone grumpy lady not wearing gloves making cookies (I must say that the machine was interesting though)...they'll yell at you if you take a picture...unless you pay them 50 cents....and worst of all....the cookies didn't taste very good!

I'm sorry....but the people that reviewed this place so well must have been paid....
author: John F.

description: This place is a joke! It shouldn't be called a factory...its just a small one story building in a creepy alley with fortune cookies on a conveyor belt! The employees try to rush you as you wait in a line to purchase your cookies. The cookies themselves  are mediocre...but I got a way better regular cookie down the street at Eastern Bakery.
author: Emma S.

description: I went here YEARS ago with my little brother's class on a field trip and it was pretty neat! If you get the chance you should definitely try to go here. They were really nice when I went and let me buy a couple bags of unfolded fortune cookies in different flavors. The best part was a little old man sitting at the end of the conveyor belt folding the cookies by hand. So cute!
author: Licia L.

description: You really get to see how small cookies are made.  Also people there so nice and friendly.  Cookies smell so good and fresh.  Must be a place to visit when you go to SF.
author: Lawrence C.

description: It wasn't want I expected. I'm glad I went but it's a 5 minute venture. There's a single line to view the shop and a man barking at you to give a tip. I've never been impressed with Chinatown in SF and this didn't do anything to change that feeling. Take your kids but don't have high expectations.
author: Chad U.

description: The place is located in Ross Alley in Chinatown.  The man in the shop gave us hot samples of unbent fortune cookies (nice treat).  You had to tip to take pictures.  The ladies seemed like they were working really hard.  It makes me wonder if the ladies up front were just for show and they actually have the whole operation in the back.  They also sell bags of cookies for $1/small and $5/large.  Nicer treat was the man next door to the shop.  He was playing his violin.  I believe he was in the movie pursuit of happiness.  We kept walking down and i think this is the same alley from that movie.  Cool find.
author: Joanne T.

description:
I love GG Fortune Cookie!  For about $3 you can buy a bag.  Although I prefer Lotus Fortune cookie on Otis St., this one will do since it's location is convenient .

Great place to take out of towners to get a feel for C-Town!
author: Wendy H.

description:
Got here just before a massive schoolgroup thankfully!

I thought it was pretty cool - I've been to SF before but didn't know about this place.  I loved watching how the dough is make and how they get folded by the ladies over a little metal post.  It's pretty cool that they're freshly made here, and you can walk out with a bag of the flat discs (before they're folded) or the actual cookies, in either the regular flavor, chocolate or both.

It's a quick stop when you're in Chinatown and a great tourist spot.  If you want a pic though, they have a sign asking for $0.50 though.
author: Katie F.

description:
I love fortune cookies and have always liked whenever I go to a very Oriental style restaurant and they serve them with some slices of oranges. I also remember the first time I saw fortune cookies was on Twilight Zone's episode.

I finally made it to GG Fortune Cookies as all this time I thought I would be able to walk right by the shop. It's in the alley without a sign of the place.

Such a lovely place as you walk through a clean and secluded alley. As soon as you walk in, you see the big machine happily molding and baking each round piece on the gas flames. The smiling ladies carefully put in each fortune and fold the cookies. Each piece truly handcrafted and they give you a couple warm flat pieces to taste.

The process is somewhat lengthy in time and labour intensive, and with a lot of love from the shop.

I love the original with a hint of sesame seeds and vanilla. The taste was unforgettable and distinguished from anything else you have tasted and any other fortune cookies you might have tried. They are really crispy and totally fresh.

I had 30 fortunes in 1 day and finished the whole bag the following day. Will have to go back and try out their chocolate and strawberry ones.

This is a place to learn a little bit of history of this American Chinese specialty and take a piece of fortune with you as you stroll through the historic Chinatown.
author: T L.

description:
They make the best and freshest fortune cookies around.  I've been going to get my fortune cookies there for decades and even though they have raised their prices..................it's the best!

I only buy the regular flat cookies, but next time will have to try the chocolate cookies.

Cash only
author: Nanana A.

description:
It's like a sweatshop of fortune cookies in here. 

Except there are only two or three ladies working in this sweatshop. 

If it's busy, you will get kinda pushed through and hustled to grab a bag and get the hell out... but, if it's slow, warm (sometimes HOT) cookies will be freely shared, and they might let you snap a pic without paying for it.

Why is it not 5 stars? 

Because two out of the four times I've been here, the bag of cookies I've bought tastes like green peppers. Why the heck is that?? Bad eggs? I have no idea, but, please, Golden Gate Fortune Cookies, get that green pepper taste out of your product. Then I'll happily bump up your rating.
author: Liz K.

description:
They have the best tasting fortune cookies anywhere - period!  It's not too sweet and always crispy.  You just can't beat the price on this wonderful snack - you can buy the fortune cookies with the fortune or you can enjoy the cookie in a different form at a much lower price -  the small discs or the large discs.  We like the small discs because you can just pop them in your mouth...yummy!  This is always such a hit and our friends love them!  

PS:  the owner, an older gentleman who's often sitting in the back is the nicest and kindest person...
author: Gloria H.

description:
Ross Alley could scare you. Golden Gate Fortune cookie Factory is probably the simplest factory in the world: one woman + one machine. I needed pass by 3 times to recognize them and I knew it had to be there somewhere as the pleasant scent of fresh baked sweets insanely fill the air... 

... and actually is not that I recognize them but that a Chinese man jelling "fortune cookies, fortune cookies!!" get out to pick me up. But If you are not as lost as I use to be, you will see the sign on the building with the name stamped on it... the second time you pass by. A woman is seated in a small stool with a tray of cookie's dough shaping the cookies faster as my eyes could even follow. And she was staring on me for a while... she and everybody else. After all, it was a Monday afternoon and I was the only tourist around. No English except for "fortune cookies and $1". The man gave me a pre-folded flat fortune cookie to taste. I choose the chocolate one. 

You know Fortune cookies are not the greatest cookies you can have but I am that one that always eat them for some reason, that you can name "The Fortune-in" for instance, and this ones were the best I tasted; warm, fresh and with flavor. Original, strawberry or chocolate. Its cash only. I had just $4 but the $1 bag is too small ... 1 large mixed 'fortune-in' cookies or 4 small bags? 

I didn't get fortune cookies but a large bag of sesame cookies instead, for $3.75 
 
After all, not like Fortune cookies are a Chinese tradition but American instead invented in the beginning of the 20th century and with a remote ancient origin in Japan; not to mention that a Caucasian in Chinatown with a camera looking quite lost and that headed up there because San Francisco's Lonely planet guide highlight them as "the bakery where fortune cookies are stamped out on old-fashioned presses and holded while hot as in 1909" (p81)... was already too much touristic acts for one day. 

And by the way, the sesame cookies were much much better that the best fortune cookies you can get. That I hear are sell at Golden Gate Fortune cookies.
author: Laura A.

description:
I can't believe it took me 8 years to get here and what an experience it was.  I couldn't stop talking about it all day. 

My experience was not much different from this episode of Family Guy.  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2JldJ3Kx8Xc

Here's how it actually went down. 

Old G Chinese: What you want?

Me: Uh...

Old G Chinese: Buy fortune cookie.

Me: I don't think so.

Old G Chinese: Try this! (Hands me a flat cookie)

Me: No, I want the sesame cookies.

Old G Chinese: Buy this! (Hands me a bag of sesame cookies)

Me: Thanks. (Hand him $10)

Old G Chinese: (Yells in Chinese to a guy, then stuffs my hand with change. 

Me: Thanks. 

Old G Chinese: Thanks (pushes me towards door.)

Classic! And yes, the fortune cookies are probably the best you will ever have in your life.
author: Roger H.

description:
Golden Gate is located in a great little alley way in Chinatown that couldn't feel more authentic if it tried. Sadly it's a well known place that has become a stop along some people's tours but it's not too hard to find your way there between tour groups (something you'll want to do because it's a very narrow space). The sweet old Chinese man who sits outside welcomes people into the shop, offers you a piece of their fortune cookie wafers, and kindly asks that you pay 50 cents if you want to take a photo of the 3 or so older Chinese women making the fortune cookies. I don't blame him at all for charging as I had just picked up a bag of mixed flavor fortune cookies from Mee Mee (which is probably going to last me weeks to go through) and I wasn't otherwise going to buy anything during from them on this particular trip. It's really interesting to see them folding the fortune cookies, it's just too bad I didn't get to taste a warm one or make my own fortune cookie (something you might be able to do if you ask them and offer enough money I'm sure). 

By the way this really is a factory and not a bakery so don't expect any sort of other goodies, a store front, or anything like that.
author: Matt E.

description:
Tucked away in a small alley in SF's Chinatown...there's a magical place that fortune cookies are born....

Well...not all of them....just the really good ones.

We walk in and this really nice old Chinese man greets us and hands us these warm and toasty flat discs....of course...they're fortune cookies...well...before they're molded into one.

Those have to be the best thing ever...the warm fortune cookie samples...

Didn't take a picture there...but did get a bag o'flops for $3.50.

That guy was really really nice!

Walked out with a warm cookie sample in one hand, and a pink shopping bag of cookie flops in the other....

If you're in Chinatown...you gotta stop by this place and pick up a bag of cookie flops.
author: Sean-Paul G.

description:
I have no idea what happened in here. I felt like I was just molested. We stood in line to see this tiny little fortune cookie sweat shop and were told to take a picture was $.50. I only had a $5 on me so I asked to take some pictures and if I could just buy a few sesame cookies, I did not want a whole bag. Somehow I ended up with the whole bag, a really awkward picture of us with a Chinese lady (no factory in the background) and then pushed back out into the street thinking " what just happened in there?" 

We did get some free samples of warm fortune cookie before it was molded into the classic shape, so these were like fortune disks. I was hoping we could make our own and customize our own messages. No such luck. Instead I just walked away with a bag of cookies and an awkward feeling.
author: Jessica M.

description: One yelper said it right, "off the beaten path" for dang sure.  We got so lost trying to find this place.  If I remember correctly it was off Washington and Grant.  About a block or so up from the intersection.  It's on the right side of the street.  We got lost further down by Walter U. Lum Alley.  Keep going up!  Once you take a right into Ross Alley, it is on your right hand side.  I walked right past it at first, so pay close attention.  You get some free (warm and fresh)  samples when you make a purchase.  Don't forget to tip 50 cents if you want to take photos.  I did it right away and the lady smiled and seemed happy about that.  They have some "adult" fortune cookies, but I decided to go with regular ones (mixed).  It was $4.75 for a bag.  Def check it out.  Best fortune cookies I ever tasted, probably because they were so fresh.
author: R R.

description:
This was a pretty cool experience.  My coworker heard about this place and wanted to check it out... first off let me say.. THANK YOU JEEBUS for my iPhone...  We would have never found this place in the tiny alley that it's in.

The people were friendly and offered us a sample.  It was pretty cool getting to watch them actually make the cookies there.  We each bought a bag of cookies.  They were so freakin tasty.  I'm sure they aren't much different than the regular ones you get, but these were fresh instead of sitting on a shelf for like 6 months.

If you are up in SF I recommend taking the stroll into Chinatown to check this place out.
author: Gabe H.

description:
Chocolate fortune cookies.  Get them.  

When a friend from San Diego said she wanted chocolate fortune cookies, we made sure Ross Alley was on our tour.  As the barber next door practiced "Red River Valley" and Wagner's "Bridal Chorus (Here Comes the Bride)," on a traditional one-string Chinese instrument, amplified all over the alley, we enjoyed the out-of-control taste of fortune cookies.  Walking out across the street, as dragon dancers rehearsed on the roof to the vigorous beat of drums and cymbals, it was truly a day in the life of Chinatown.  

I love being a tourist in my own city!
author: David D.

description: Yes, a big tourist trap.  But still, kind of neat to see the women seated churn out fortune cookies one after the other.  Pretty good ... esp if you can get a back of cookies that are hot off the press.
author: F. P.

description:
Awesome place to take a tourist. This is something that is off the beaten path of SF China Town's main streets.

The alley, structure of the building (or hole in the wall) looks a little dodgy but don't let their appearance fool you. Their fortune cookies are delicious and cheap. It is even better when they are warm. 

The old man, possibly owner,  has a quirky sense of humor and is very willing to pass out samples - one per person. He mentioned kids coming by and stealing a handful of samples. haha. It's a family owned  business which is fantastic. 

Just a note that photos taken inside of the fortune cookie shop will cost you $0.50. They also sell the fortune cookies flat, pre-shapped, and in chocolate! 

Definitely a great spot to visit in China Town. Highly recommended.
author: Diana J.

description:
This place is really hard to find. I would've never found it, but my coworker enticed me to go.  Imagine walking down this alley and you find an open door with these people working nonstop on fortune cookie machines.  It is wild.  The man did call me in say, "hello come on in."  That made me happy.  I ended up getting the $3.50 mix bag of flat cookies.  The lady gave me a free sample, it was so fresh and warm. 

I had a great time because it was my first time ever witnessing a fortune cookie be made. All my life they just appear on the receipt when we pay for our chinese food. Very cool to watch the process.
author: Michelle M.

description:
You walk down a scary seedy alley way in Chinatown to find this fortune cookie sweat shop with 5 machines, but only one working.

I went here twice.  Once with my husband and Asian co-worker.  And once with our Hispanic friends that look white, who were greeted really nicely and they got really good customer service.

The first time we came in, they look at us, offer us some samples and go back to what they're doing.  I asked if I can sample a piece of the chocolate fortune cookie and I got yelled at.  An Asian girl comes in, yells at them in Chinese, they get all crazy on her in Chinese and she leaves.  

WHAT WE BOUGHT:
  - Mixed Flat Fortune Cookies ($3.50/bag):  Comes with small half-dollar sized flat cookies with 3 flavors (regular, chocolate & strawberry).  The plain fortune cookies were very crispy and lightly sweet with a hint of sesame (probably from the sesame-covered cookies?).  The chocolate one is kinda like Cocoa Puffs, but less sweet.  The strawberry one kinda tastes faintly like Pocky.

  - Adult Fortune Cookies ($4.50/bag): Regular-sized fortune cookie shape with an Engrish "fortune" inside.  "Fu Ling Yu says..." some kind of weird abstract humor that doesn't really make sense.  Don't expect much from these fortunes... it's just for fun written by Sum Dum Gai.

  - With every purchase, you get a handful of regular flavor hot cookie wafers (air hockey puck sized) right off the cookie press.  

If you go here, bring non-Asian friends... you'll get better service!  And CASH ONLY!!
author: Mayumi T.

description: Took me a while to find it, but after some searching in dark allies, I finally came across a tiny hole in the wall with about three tables inside. I walked in and it was full of white tourists. My first though was, oh boy. But the man running the place was friendly and offered us the defect cookies as a sample. They were delicious. You can buy bags of chocolate, regular, or mixed cookies with fortunes or in disk shape for about 5 bucks. I even got a cute personalized one for my boyfriend. He charges 50 cents for pictures, I saw a lot of people wanting to take them. All of the people were very nice, and the cookies are great.
author: Kayla M.

description:
LOVE IT!!
I always bring people here when they come visit me (usually on the way back from getting pho or dim sum in Chinatown). It's dinginess is part of the allure and charm. You would expect for there to be some crazy fortune cookie making machine now that machine's are taking over the world but it's just a little lady putting fortunes into cookies.
Plus the reject cookies that are still warm make my day!
Note: take a look at the adult cookie fortunes - hilarious!!
author: Christina L.

description: Haven't been there in years. Brought friends there the other day and saw a sign that said it costs 50 cents to take a picture. Really? Come on. Was that to make a few extra bucks or discourage photos?
author: Cynthia L.

description: Our daughters demanded to go here. The proprietor invited us in before we got in the door. Fresh hot samples right off the cooker.Had never seen a chocolate fortune cookie, now I have. Invited our daughters to make a cookie. The highlight of their day by the bay.
author: Jack B.

description: Well worth a stop if you are in Chinatown. It's in an alley that looks spooky but is safe. Real hot off the presses fortune cookies and many other choices. Delicious. It's a very small hole in the wall shop with about 4 people working and one selling the 'merch'.  It looks like a 300 square foot sweatshop. I think it is. You will walk right by if you are not paying attention and reading the signs. We bought five bags of various items and got several freebies thrown in. Go here now if you are in S.F.
author: George C.

description: Old Chinese slaves I mean women show you to how to make goooood fortune cookie.  They are trying to sell fortune cookies and work their asses off for probably 5 cents an hour.  My gf strolls in and says we should buy some but with the walkway clogged with tourists she yells out she doesn't want to gain weight from eating them.  All the people left.  PWNED.
author: Fatty A.

description:
Interesting place. It felt on some level like going back in time.  It's free to get a peek at how fortune cookies are made and what a work shift in the factory is like.  This place is bigger than the Mee Mee Bakery (a fortune cookie competitor in China Town also offering a peek into their factory).  The bigger size mesmerized my kids. Don't linger too long --- I theorize that the most boisterous worker is purposely seated at the front of the place near where viewers stand.  After about five minutes or so, she began telling us to go buy cookies.  I'm going to stop short of stating that she demanded it because I think her simple lack of command over the English language made it only seem that way.  One other thing you should know, taking a picture inside the Golden Gate Factory will cost you 50 cents.  Just remember, you are barging into their workplace. 

Find out more about the factory and learn a bit of China Town history at:
http://www.sanfranciscochinatown.com/attractions/ggfortunecookie.html
author: Kristine D.

description:
If you can find it, GO! (Hint: Follow your nose!)

Teeny tiny factory with GREAT fortune cookies. The older gentleman is probably the nicest person I've ever met in my entire life. He will graciously stuff your bag full of free cookies as you leave and make you feel as if you are the one and only person he's ever given a free cookie to. 

Tip: Dont spend a lot of time deciding what kind of cookies to get. Just grab a bag of both regular and chocolate. They're super cheap. The place is tiny and while the staff is very, very sweet, it seems like a lot of the tourists were standing around in their way, not allowing the line to move through.
author: Amelia O.

description: If I'm in Chinatown I ALWAYS stop by the egg tart place and this pad.   I just get the regular chips--who needs to deal with snaping open a fortune cookie to get rid of the paper?  Yummmmmmmm
author: Sonny W.

description:
If you visit San Francisco, PLEASE be sure to stop here!

This difficult-to-find, out-of-the-way back alley narrow room is one of the true treasures of downtown Chinatown San Francisco!  Located in a place I wouldn't feel safe venturing into at night, by day it's an inviting, quaint little hole in the wall.

Entering the place, you find only a rather narrow isle and are immediately greeted by an animated, kind old Chinese man who welcomes you warmly.  I was then handed a couple of free samples of "flat" cookies, freshly made and still hot, by a sweet little Chinese girl about six years old, I assume the daughter of one of the workers.

Looking around you gives you a vision of a wonderfully disorganized area reminiscent of the tinkerer's workshop in "Chitty Chitty Bang Bang.", a single aisle with several operating machines, and open-air pipes and machinery in the back of the small area.  There isn't much space to move around in once you enter, but the bags of different kinds of cookies are within easy reach.  One can choose from "classic" fortune cookies, as well as chocolate, or buy a mix.  The "flat" cookies sans fortunes are also sold here, as well as some "swirled" chip-like concoctions that actually taste more like potato chips than cookie but are also quite good.

They also have bags of cookies with "adult" fortunes, but you won't find anything pornographic in them, or even really "adult"...just messages with slightly more risque innuendo than a typical cookie. I've certainly heard worse in PG-13 movies than what is written on the "adult" fortunes.

The prices are excellent for their wares, just be sure you bring cash as they don't take cards as far as I know...owing to the fact that their "register" was simply a jar of bills and change, there was no card machine or drawer.  Also, they request a small tip if you want to take a picture of the place, but it's well worth it.
author: Paul W.

description:
Nice place to go as a tourist, not somewhere to make a trip for. Very interesting to see how those little cookies are made. Bought a bag of cookies, 30-40 cookies for $3.75, as a souvenir. They were also selling small bags (4-6 cookies or so) for $1.

it's small, and crowded. Take a look around, snap a picture, buy some cookies, and then head out. Don't linger, don't try to pose for a picture, they need to keep people moving... of course, they will be more patient if you buy cookies. A must-see when visiting Chinatown.
author: Lucas A.

description: If you ever wanted to know how fortune cookies are made, this is your spot.  Pretty anticlimactic, but still kinda cool.  Ate a warm reject fortune cookie- that was fun.
author: Isaac R.

description: Located in historic Ross Alley, where once you could hire a lady of the night, you can now see fortune cookies being made by hand and even sample some that are hot and fresh. The owner is a blunt and to the point kind of guy who seems to prefer you pick your items and be on your way.  Not to say he is rude---he just has a business to run and well, space it limited for sure.  This is worth a trip up the hill to see this unique process and maybe buy a bag of dirty fortunes cookies for your friends.
author: Jessica F.

description: This was a very cool place to visit. The cookies were awesome...especially when warm. The chocolate versions were equally tasty. Check out the alley on the opposite side of the building. If they ever remake the movie, they have to film in the allley again
author: Jason R.

description:
My friend showed me this place when we wandered Chinatown earlier this year.

I brought back chocolate "misfortune" cookies (just the flat cookies without fortunes) to the office and they were very well-received!

Only downside is trying to figure out how to handcarry these guys on a plane! They take up a lot of room (cause you don't want to crush them), especially if you buy a few bags.

And they're so inexpensive and delicious, you definitely want more than one bag!

Love watching how quickly the lady folding fortunes into cookies works. I could stand there all day watching her. It's like magic.
author: Tracy S.

description: Delicious fortune cookies. You can purchase bags of folded with fortune or unfolded no fortune in different sized bags. They give out free samples. With purchase of a large bag they gave me about 5 warm unfolded fortunes. So good! Neat to see them being made by hand.
author: Zoe D.

description: I used to live in San Francisco yet every time I come to visit I find myself back at this place buying bags of fortune cookies. It's like dejavu every time I walk through the Ross alley way and through a small door where tourists are trying to manage themselves within a crowded entry space, turning this way and that, being handed handfuls of samples and at the same time deciding which bag of fortune cookie to buy: folded or flat, chocolate or vanilla, OR X-rated? Yup, that's right; you can buy a bag of fortune cookies with x-rated fortunes. You don't need to add "...in bed" to the end of your normal fortunes anymore ;)
author: Stacy C.

description:
Authentic and awesome.  Free cookie samples and a sneak peek at how all the cookies are made. 

Worth stopping by and checking out after a trip to Vital Leaf
author: Jacques S.

description:
As a kid who was born and raised in San Francisco and went to school in Chinatown for most of my youth, this place is definitely a favorite.   I ate fortune cookies for many years in my youth though I stopped in high school and through my college years.  

Recently though, I've re-discovered my love of the cookies, though I eat the flat ones and not the ones with the fortunes.  

One thing that I hope most non-Chinese people realize is that fortune cookies are NOT a staple of Chinese cuisine.  It has been speculated that the cookie was a japanese invention and then later added to Chinese-American cuisine during the early 1900's.  Regardless, the cookies from this shop are quite tasty.  Worth trying out !
author: Donald L.

description:
Tucked away in one of Chinatown's many alleys, this place is a total crack up...the woman who greeted us on our first visit is permanently etched in my mind! (And, if I ever do forget her, I just have to go back to my photo album and there she is glaring at me!) I swear we were in an episode of Seinfeld...visiting the "Fortune Cookie Nazi" demanding money from anyone who attempted to snap a picture of her. Who could blame her as countless hordes of gawking tourists cram themselves into this tiny factory - believing they have left Planet Earth - while grabbing handfuls of flattened fortune cookie samples before they are ushered out if they stay too long. 

I can't tell you how disappointed I was that she was nowhere to be found on our most recent visit. But, it was still a fun little stop-off on our tour of Chinatown...
author: Janet D.

description:
1. Step inside, making room for others.
2. Munch on the sample cookie seconds the Chinese guy hands you.
3. Buy some cookies, then scram.

No, they don't encourage you to linger. 

Yes, you actually do have to pay if you take a picture. 

The bags of cookies are a good deal, especially if you want non-cheesy and non-plastic gifts to take home to friends and family.

Now... go find it!!
author: Jen F.

description:
Three cheers for this sweat... errr, sweet shop.

"Don't give woman bicycle or she may peddle it all over town."
"Man who make war with woman during day get no piece at night."
"You can separate the men from the boys by the size of their toys."

and my favorite... "LEARN CHINESE."

I recommend that you pick up a bag of their "dirty" fortunes (which are really more suggestive than anything).  Or the flat reject-cookies and sesame-seed coated cookies.

If you have trouble find this place (trust me, you will), it's on an alleyway between Washington and Jackson streets in Chinatown.
author: Christina G.

description:
Gotta love free fresh off the factory fortune cookie samples!

I remember going here with my best friends in high school, playing hookie and going to a real hole in the wall place for fortune cookies.  Coming back, the place still smell delicious, and my daughter loves them just as much as I did.  

They've gotta be doing something right for being open all these decades!
author: Liz A.

description: Pretty cool little shop inside an alley. You can watch them make the fortune cookies on this ancient contraption that looks like it's powered by steam (probably, not really, heh). The man in the front was really nice and gave us free samples. I ended up buying a bag of regular and chocolate fortune cookies for $5. He even threw in extra free samples! Definitely a unique place to check out.
author: Francis F.

description:
You have to appreciate the novelty of this place! It's just a small Fortune Cookie Factory in the heart of Chinatown. A bit hard to find but worth the adventure! 

Where else will you find strawberry and chocolate fortune cookies? Fresh sample from the cookie line handed to you the second you walk in the door. Best greeting ever!!! 

Bring cash, they don't take credit. Ohh and for a unique treat at your next dinner party, bring your own fortunes, they will gladly slip them into the next batch of cookie for you. A unique souvenier to take home.
author: Marissa P.

description: I really thought I was in the wrong place.  Back alley in SF Chinatown?  Not the place that I necessarily want to be but hey if you want good fortune cookies, you gotta do what ya gotta do.  Word of advice, just go straight to the freshly cooked ones (flat ones) and don't bother with the bagged (especially chocolate) ones.  You'll thank me later.
author: Brad S.

description:
So this is a legit hole in the wall. And I don't mean that in a good way. 

I really don't understand the high ratings because this place is scary. There's one small room everyone bustles into, where ladies fold the cookies and some man tries to make everyone pay for pictures and buy bags of cookies. Yes, I do have "functioning taste buds." The cookies taste fine -- nothing special, except they're hot and "fresh." 

I did see many tourists and I'm sure that affects the experience, but... What am I talking about? There is no experience here. I don't see the charm in this little room. It reminded me of a small sweat shop, and I was disgusted by the people taking pictures of the old lady folding hot cookie rounds.
author: Sydney E.

description: Never seen or had a fresh fortune cookie before and there good.  It's a fortune cookie, stop by, get a bag. Worth the few mins to see.
author: Steven H.

description:
Cheap. Cookies. Fortunes optional.

That just about sums it up.
author: Alyce H.

description:
In the throngs of tourists and locals trying to get into this shop, I fell in love with a little old Chinese man. 

When we arrived, we were greeted by my little old man. It was a miracle to find the shop empty (gasp!) and get a full view of this amazingly awesome factory. Well, more like a one-person-finger-burning-showdown! I wonder if the ladies even have fingerprints anymore...

Anyway, the shop gets packed within two minutes of us being there, so we rush to finish up our purchases. While my friend is paying, my little old man was slipping more and more free cookies into her bag. Then, while trying to figure a way out, he nudged me and sneaked two more fortune cookies into my hand and smiled at me. ::heart swoon:: I'm sure he does that to all the ladies... 

Oh, and the cookies are yummy!
author: Christie P.

description: Down a dark hidden alley underneath a barely legible sign there lies your fortune cookie heaven. We were warmly greeted (at least I think it was warm because I could not understand him) and given samples of their fortune cookies. The place was small and a little depressing and we inadvertently paid 50 cents for a picture but it was still pretty unique. We also bought a bag of fortune cookies (half chocolate) for $4.75. Bill C. is lucky I don't really like fortune cookies. I hope he enjoyed those!
author: Tai F.

description: No trip to Chinatown is complete without a visit to Ross alley and its famous fortune cookie factory. It's such a hidden treasure. Also, do yourself a favor a read up on the history of Chinatown before your visit -- it really deepens the experience. Or take one of the free (donation-based) city walking tours.
author: Johnny W.

description:
"Factory" is an optimistic label....it's actually a somewhat sketchy hole in the wall in a random alley. But they give you free, hot off the assembly line samples of fortune cookies!

I'm not really a big fan of fortune cookies but these are fresh and surprisingly good. I wasn't planning on buying anything but women there were so nice, I got a $1 bag of about six cookies (it was a dollar! I couldn't say no!)

Bonus: just a few feet a way is "Delicious Dim Sum" where you can get, well... delicious dim sum for super cheap.
author: Meghan B.

description:
A lot of places sell fortune cookies, but none has the history and ambiance of this fortune cookie making gem located on historic Ross Alley. 

Growing up, I've had their fortune cookies countless times. They are always crispy and delicious. They have various types and you can buy them in bags at the store itself.

It's also a wonderful place for tourist to check out. The alley gives you a feel of "old" Chinatown and it's like walking into the past. The antiquated feel of this fortune cookie shop makes it unique. I've had friends tell me that they should "upgrade" themselves and make themselves more "effective" and "productive" for the 21st century. However, I disagree in that part of the charm is the genuine historic feel of this place. 

Walk in, ask for a sample, and talk to some of the workers. Every time I have to cut across the area, I purposely walk through Ross Alley instead of some of the larger cross streets because I am lured by the smell of freshly baked fortune cookies!

A great place to learn about Chinatown history and check out this fortune cookie institution for tourists! A true delight for the locals. Yummy cookies and great for gift giving. You can even ask for customized messages =) Time to get creative!
author: Tina C.

description:
This place is worth a visit. Staff was friendly, lots of free samples especially to the kids. The man who sells the cookies doesn't speak great english, the ladies in the back help out if he gets stuck answering, like about how many cookies in a bag? I needed to be sure I got enough for a class, the answer is 40. Cookies are cheap, interesting to see how they are made. It's like a 5 minute thing.

We didn't have any trouble finding the Ross Alley, it's right off of Washington between Stockton and Grant. Parking was tough on Sunday afternoon.
author: K M.

description:
Walking down many alleys in San Francisco's Chinatown can smell pretty fishy, except for Ross Alley, which lures you in with the aroma of the fresh fortune cookies being baked.

Ever had a hot fortune cookie right out of the oven?  It's a totally different scene, than the been wrapped in plastic and sitting in a box forever, scene.  I used to take those fortunes seriously, then I grew up, which almost ruined the whole experience.  Our walking tour of San Fran's Chinatown made me a believer in fortune cookies again.

Hello America!  We had the first fortune cookie, China adapted the use and custom many years later!  See how it pays to take the prepaid walking tours of a big city?  Or do what we have done many times and gather close behind and in ear shot.  

The fortune cookies are made right before your eyes and fast.  The hot cookies are peeled from a hot iron and formed over a rod and the fortune is tucked in and the final shaping is done.  Watch it again and again, because they will amaze you with their speedy skills.  They are one of the largest producers of fortune cookies for restaurant usage.  The two others being in LA and NYC.

The fortune they carry contain messages from Bible verses, lottery number or risque and you should take these messages very seriously, when in San Francisco's Chinatown, only!
author: DJ M.

description: This place is a hidden gem! Located in a small alley in chinatown. This is the best place in town to get bags of fortune cookie. They sell big bags of unfolded fortune cookies for $3.75 a bag and the grandpas who work there are super friendly and always give out samples!
author: Jess s.

description: Yummmmm....kind of hard to find its on an alley, nice people working and you get free samples...4 dollars a bag and 50 cents for a picture.
author: Isela C.

description:
A great San Fran relic! My friend demanded we go here when she came to visit and it was a fun experience. For some reason even the cramped and questionable cleanliness were out the window to me!

Bring cash! If you go here, make sure to buy a bag of flat fortune cookies, everyone loves them!
author: Christina P.

description: I love this little place, a true gem in that district of SF.  If you've never been this is one stop in SF you should make.  When you come upon the shop and the aroma begins to make your mouth water who can help but purchase some of the freshly made cookies they have to offer.  It's cool you can watch the ladies at work making those irresistible treats right before your eyes.  The fifty cents to take some pictures is well worth it as has been pointed out by others they do stop their work to part take in your picture and where else are you going to get this picture?  They're always warm and inviting, handing out samples, and proud of their wonderful product.  Make the stop here, you'll enjoy it.
author: John F.

description:
Here is the deal. 

For a tourist trap it is anything but. The people folding those fortune cookies are not there to care.  It is a great atmosphere. 

Down a little alley on Jackson Street, between Grant and Stockton. The place is a total hole in the wall and it looks like, despite it's massive sales of cookies, they have held true to their tradition and have not changed a thing to make it tourist friendly. Finally.

Tips:
Ask for a sample straight out of the freshly made bin.

Parking:
Don't even try in China town. Take the Stockton 30 bus and get off on Jackson. 

Price:
Is right. $3.50 for a regular good size bag. You can also get a mixed of chocolate, regular and strawberry for a dollar more. Or spring for the giant fortune cookie for $12. 

Bring cash.

Yelpified.
author: Aaron A.

description: The cutest little dingy attraction. It's worth the trek. Don't expect a lot, its a small shop with a huge line. The warm cookies are tasty and its a cheap attraction that you're sure to get a kick out of.
author: Kristina B.

description: I heard about this place from the internet.  It is a great place to visit and see how fortune cookies are made. It is a little difficult to find but finding it is half the fun. You can buy different flavored cookies such as chocolate.  I've seen a strawberry flavored cookie but they don't always have it.  A must see if you are in the area.
author: Ralph O.

description:
Were you aware that the fortune cookie was invented in San Francisco? Yes, it's true. At GGFC, you can watch real live chinese san franciscans on the factory line, peeling the cookies off the conveyor belt and folding them into the crunchy clairvoyant confections. 
You can also do a special order and have personalized messages put in your wedding/anniversary/chinese baby adoption party/bar mitzvah fortune cookies.
This is also a good one to add to your cheap-eats-in-Chinatown lists. You can buy a big bag of cookies for a few bucks here.
author: Rennie L.

description: Very small place and we were rushed in and out very quickly but it was still really fun to see the place. They had like 6 different types of fortune cookies and they had traditional almond cookies as well. Old man at the front was so kind though and shoved uncrimped fresh fortune cookies into our hands. Best i've ever had though i wish inhad the opportunity to buy alittle bag when i was there. Maybe next time
author: Brittainie B.

description:
I like eating.
I had a craving for fortune cookies for the past year...that's right year. Came to china town with the boyfriend and decided i NEEDED to stop by and when I did let's just say I left with around 3 bags full of cookies and by the time I got home I only had 1 bag left. Now the bags aren't small infact  they are rather big (that's what she said) and I ate all of it. haha they were sooo good.
author: Cristelle J.

description: I used to love to go to this place. it is now over touristed as it is a china town tourist stop now...I was craving fortune cookies so I ran in here to grab a bag... bad idea.. it was way to crowded with tourist... I had to squeeze in and swindle my way through the crowd. I noticed a sign .. 50 cents for a photo! wtf.. so cheap and cheeky of them... anyways I wasn't there for photos... I was there for fortune cookies... I finally managed to get a bag... I'm not happy with them. They did not taste remotely nice and the fortunes are horrible. The fortunes are not fortunes at all just sayings by some guy named fu ling yu who seems to hate women since almost every fortune cookie seems to say something negative about women.. Fu ling yu seems really twisted... the fortune cookies tasted weird.
