If you want to see people make fortune cookies then fine go here... but if you want a good tasting fortune cookie with a nice fortune then avoid this place.
author: Lindsey A.

description:
I dont know how those ladies make fortune cookies taste like lil round pieces of crack!

Every trip to SF, we stop by to grab some cookies to bring back to LA.  I complain about carrying them since you have to be careful not to crack them when i bring them on the plane.  But everytime I get excited when i get to open the bag and munch away.  I figured their not fried, so how bad can they possibly be :)

When you go here its like a huge step back in time, which makes it more awesome.  The samples they give you, amazingly fresh that they dont go stale even if you dont seal them up and put them in a ziploc.

One of the two things that are a must on my visit to SF Chinatown, some Dim Sum and Fortune Cookies!
author: cheryl y.

description: This is a place difficult to find and easy to miss. I was told by a nearby non-profit agency that this is where fortune cookies were first found. I kept going back and I would get multiple bags in differently flavors each time. The people there are very inviting and make you feel welcomed by offering you samples that are freshly made. Visitors are treated to witness how each cookie is made manually. The people there are always respectful and patient with everyone, including tourists who have trouble making up their minds.As for my personal taste, I would recommend any of the flat cookies as their freshness tend to last for a while. This is a cultural space and a can't miss experience.
author: Daniel L.

description:
This place is a must for bringing visitors to SF.  Shell out the 50 cents to have your picture taken in front of the old Asian ladies working at the fortune cookie machines who all look like they think you're a bumbling idiot.  There are bags of regular, chocolate, variety, and "adult" fortune cookies for sale, and they do promotional fortune cookies too.  I got the adult ones, but they're like the least racy fortunes I've ever read.  You do get a gem here and there though, like this one:  "Fu Ling Yu Says: Kiss is upper persuasion for lower invasion."

Waka waka.
author: Ellen S.

description:
America's fasination on fortune cookies...

How do you make them?
How do you fit in those notes?
How do you make them curl?
How do you come up with that?
Who makes them?
Who cames up with that?

Questions, questions and more questions..

Golden Gate Fortune Cookies may have the answers, but not to 'who came up with the idea'. After all, you have the internet...google it!

And NO! It's not a sweatshop.

ps: They're freshly made and you can buy them in bags at a really cheap price.
author: Rick W.

description:
The fortune cookies and the entire "fortune cookie factory experience" is great and is like none other, BUT...

I'm dedicating my 100th review to....SMACKLES! That's right, SMACKLES!

What are SMACKLES you ask?

They are treats that are thin, light, crispy, and semi-sweet. They are so addicting. Now I load up on SMACKLES rather than greasy potato chips. They come in packaged bags that come out to about $1.25/bag. Buy a couple b/c one bag will not last you even an hour. No joke.

The bag reads:

SMACKLES -
for snacking time - check!
as an appetizer - check!
for party time - check!
my Yelp approval - check!!

Ingredients include: enriched flour, sugar water, cocoa powder, vegetable oil, salt, and eggs.

They now also have fresh and crispy "mini disk" that are flat, a little bigger than the half dollar, unfolded fortune cookies. They come in 3 different flavors: original, strawberry, and chocolate. These make great treats as well!!
author: Veronica H.

description:
a.k.a. The Fortune Cookie Factory

Whenever I pass through Chinatown I have to walk down this alley and pop in and do my Gung Hay Fat Choy runs and say WHAT IZZZ IT?!?  Let me get a bag of those adult only fortune cookies and let me get a back of those sessame seed cookies, and a bag of fortune cookie waffers.

The warm waffers they give you hot off the cooker are bomb, especially with some hot tea.  They charge you to take pictures with them and sometimes they don't give you change like one time my cookies cost $8 and they didn't give me change on my $10, but they gave me a bag full of those warm waffers for free.

These alley ways in Chinatown are gangsta.  I always see old Chinamen gambling or playing Majong or some dommino-like games in old run down rooms in these alley-ways.

My cousin's ex-bf from Brooklyn told me a few stories that made me become a vegetarian whenever I'm in Chinatown areas.
author: Chris T.

description: Haza! So calling this a 'factory' is questionable at best. It's a small shop in Chinatown where they make fortune cookies. Quite a hole in the wall. But what the hell? You're in Chinatown, walk down the dark alley and buy yourself a huge bag of cookies for next to nothing. They had chocolate, strawberry, sesame seed and of course, regular flavors. I liked the flat cookies the best. Couldn't even finish the bag during the entire trip, while snacking in our hotel room. Anyway, if you're gonna do the tourist thing, stop here.
author: Matt R.

description: Worth a stop if you are already in Chinatown but don't go out of your way to go to Chinatown for it. Small place, only a dew people can fit in at a time. Cheap decent treats to buy. The two employees looked super pissed to be there but the older guy running the place seemed fairly nice & friendly.
author: Amanda C.

description:
I love fortune cookies.  Really, they can make or break my day with their messages.  I'm sort of superstitious- I read horoscopes,  look for signs and coinciding events and have obviously been wanting to go to a real fortune cookie factory for a long time. At last-- The cookies are fresh and beyond your average packaged fortune cookie, you can watch the old ladies folding the cookies, but most importantly, they have much to tell me with their little slices of paper.  I will now open a fortune cookie and place its message here for you to meditate on:      

"your lucky number for the week is number 2"

 whaaa?? Ive never had a lucky number of the week, but ok. keep your eyes open for twos.
author: Liz S.

description:
I'm munching on one of their flat cookies as I type this. Just too darn addicting. An entire bag of these suckers will disappear in no time. My wife and I bought a bag and didn't even put it out for her family and relatives (it's a big, big family) to share. Sure, call us greedy and selfish. But that's how much we love Golden Gate fortune cookies. 

Besides, they can buy their own bag since they live in the area. Plus we drove all the way up from LA to see them. There, I feel better.
author: Dru C.

description:
When I was growing up in San Francisco, my father would bring me by this factory to either buy a bag of cookies or grab some samples.  While in college and working as a Chinatown tour guide, I brought tourists here so they could see how cookies are made and sample them.  

Now that I live 900 miles away from San Francisco, I have to wait for an opportunity to visit my hometown and then buy several bags to bring back home to my family.  When I do have the opportunity to go back to San Francisco with my family, this place is always on the list of places to stop by.  All four of my boys love the cookies here.  It's definitely one of the hidden gems in Chinatown and no other fortune cookies can compare to these.
author: Francis Q.

description:
I think this is really the only place where you will see fortune cookies made in front of your eyes...a nice tourist attraction..

When buying cookies, you can get flat ones where it has no paper inside. We prefer those since its already a nice flat circle and its easier to eat. And whats kind of nice is that they do give you some extra just for the hell of it I guess..

Remember though, if you want to take pictures then you will need to pay. I think its 50 cents but they never clarified for how many pics so I'm not sure how it goes..but its smart~
author: phillip w.

description:
I headed to the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie factory during my lunch break today to buy some fortune cookies for a promotional event my company is having tomorrow.  I vaguely remember going to the factory once during a field trip in second grade. That was 20 years ago, and it hasn't changed much. 

The factory/store is very small, and the workers are right there inside the door, so there's not really much of a store front. But that's okay, as they were very friendly...especially the old man. 

When I told him that I'd like to buy a couple of bags of fortune cookies (half regular, half chocolate!), he shuffled up to me, smiled, and unexpectedly popped an unfolded fortune cookie in my mouth. 

So there I am, with one hand holding my umbrella and the other holding a ton of dim sum that I had just bought around the corner, and a flat fortune cookie in my mouth.  I must've looked like an ass.  For a split second I wasn't sure whether to interpret what he did as freeky-deeky or endearing, but I eventually  opted for the latter.

I then manage to give him my money, and a muffled "thank you".  

I heart Chinatown!
author: Karen F.

description:
Nothing beats fresh, warm, off-the-griddle fortune cookies!  I come here to get the large, flat discs- they're much easier to stuff in your mouth than the actual fortune cookies and really, the fortunes are just extraneous.  I can sit and eat like half the bag in one sitting.  Its also cool to bring out-of-town guests to this little alley- I mean, its not everyday that you see how fortune cookies are actually made.  Everything in Ross Alley seems like a throwback and its fun to see the two old ladies sitting at the machines and watch the fortune cookies come out.  

50 cents for a photo, but they usually throw in some samples for free.  It can get crowded in the cramped space, so its better to wait for your turn outside in the alley, looking at the celebrity photos on the wall outside the barbershop next door.
author: Angela H.

description: I went to this factory twice.  My first experience was wonderful already with warm cookie to try while deciding how many bags of cookies I should get. And my second visit last night was very unique too as I was trying to show my friend where the factory is located by dropping at 9:05pm. I just had a sneak peaking thru the gate since there was light still in the store. The owner came out and greeted us and even open the gate for us and welcomed us in the store. He gave us a handful of cookie to try immediately while my friend was deciding what to buy and how many bags.  At the end, we totally bought 7 to 8 bags of goodies with us. We love this place and I personally respect the history of this place so much.  U must pay a visit when u r around town in san francisco.
author: Elsa C.

description:
We stumbled into this place by accident this weekend on our latest visit to SF and only after getting off the main tourist path and entering this alley in chinatown. We figured what better way to experience chinatown than to just explore some of its alleys.

Well as we entered the alley we could smell that there was a bakery nearby. Taking a closer look inside the small shop we saw two elderly ladies using what looked to be an ancient press to pump out fortune cookies by hand!

Once inside we were greeted by a VERY FRIENDLY elderly man, who quickly grabbed a tin with hot and freshly made cookie samples, picked one up and without warning shoved it into my little sisters mouth :). The look on her face was priceless...

Needless to say we ended up buying a bag of those cookie rounds and now back home, only regret just buying one bag!

Had to take a picture (50 cents).

Definitely will be back.
author: Saul A.

description:
My aunt and uncle came into town and we decided to give them a whirlwind tour of the city.

Wandering around in Chinatown, we couldn't think of too many places to take them to....that is, until my cousin thought of this place. I have to say, I was a little wary of visiting it. After all..its a fortune cookie factory..how cool could it be?

Well, it was frickin AMAZING. We sat and watched someone make fortune cookies. She was so fast at doing it. I later found out they were putting FRENCH fortunes into that batch. HOW NEAT IS THAT? 

They also told us that we could bring in our own fortunes and they would put them into cookies. For 50 cents, thats a bargain and a great souvenir!
author: andrew c.

description:
Quite over-rated.  I walked in, paid my 50 cents (actually he kept 70 cents but whatevs), took a picture and was ready to go.  I tried a piece of fortune cookie scraps and it was run-of-the-mill.  Bought a small pack of cookies for a buck, for the novelty of it.

This really isn't a "factory".  Its a dingy room with two fortune cookie machines.  If you're walking through Chinatown, go ahead and stop by.  Otherwise I'm sure you can catch it on the Food Network or something.
author: Farida A.

description:
For $8 (including $2 bus fare):

- I tasted my first fresh, pre-folded (re: flat) fortune cookie (free).

- Got my picture taken with one of the hard working ladies that fold those bad boys day in and day out (.50/photo - but come on, give her a $1).

-Scooped up a bag of mixed 'fortune-in' cookies - half chocolate, half original - to take home ($4.50).

Other:

- A tiny place - a handful of customers and it's packed.

- Expect a short visit - We went on a rainy, Sunday afternoon and could only spend five minutes inside before the tourists started taking over.

- Share with non-San Fran friends - Skyped the family back home & opened fortunes 'together' (I opened and read them their fortunes). Awwwww.

Perhaps there's another place like this on Earth, but def not in San Francisco. Will def be going back.

P.S. The alley, during the day, is definitely not sketchy.
author: Stephanie F.

description:
When I was in 6th grade, I went on my favorite field trip ever - mostly because we got to stop at Golden Gate Fortune Cookies.  I think there was probably an educational value-add in the minds of my teachers, but I just wanted cookies.

I bought 500 of them for 5 bucks, ate them all by that night, then puked.

I love this place.

PS I think it was my fault that I puked (given the sheer number of cookies I consumed) not the fault of GGFC.  They didn't poison me or anything and it was totally worth it.
author: Caitlin D.

description:
Classic and never fails to deliver on the vintage joy that fortune cookie rounds bring.

You can purchase happiness, and it's $3.50 down Ross Alley.
author: Kat C.

description: Okay, what am I missing?  Yes it's cool it's tucked away in a little alley in mysterious Chinatown.  But there's about enough room for 10 people to squeeze in and the guy barely let's you even see what's being done and yells "Fifty cents for a picture!" and then gives you this vibe like "you'd BETTER buy something!"  We picked up a big bag of cookies for $5 but realistically we could never eat that many or get them home without being broken so we got 6 in a bag for $1 and he audibly sighed at us.  So we paid him the $1.50 (for the cookies and picture) and he kind of rushed us out.  It is not welcoming, you almost feel bad for the people working there and honestly those were about the most tasteless fortune cookies I've ever had.  Wouldn't go back and don't feel bad if you miss it, the experience isn't worth paying for.
author: A. S.

description:
This is a San Francisco must see! Where else can you snack on fortune cookies that are still warm? Tucked away on Ross Alley just off Jackson, this little shop caters to tourists and locals alike. The price for a bag of cookies seems to be locked into $3 for longer than I can remember. The flat cookies are the best--every time I share them at the office, I get another person hooked. They have chocolate cookies too now, but I still prefer the original recipe, which appears to be available online:  

http://www.sfheart.com/fortune_cookie_recipe.htm

well, good luck with that! I'll just go buy my cookies where I can enjoy the sites & sounds of chinatown!
author: Anne P.

description:
All my life, I'd never thought of people rolling fortune cookies. I always just thought they were some amorphous thing that grew that way or where there was a machine that spit them out in that particular shape. I never pictured 2 slightly disgruntled looking women rolling hot cookies near ancient looking cast iron machines and putting fortunes inside.

The shop is difficult to find. Don't bother writing down the address as none of the street signs are labeled. Know the nearest cross street and look for the unmarked ally that is assuredly Ross Alley. There are no numbers on Golden Gate either, just a small sign with the name, but if you pass close enough, you'll be able to smell hot cookies through the door.

The owner is very nice. Upon entering the shop, he will shove a basket of chocolate and regular cookies at you, unrolled and broken as sample pieces. Take one of each, then decide what you want. I like the plain misfortune cookies... the unrolled disks that come in packages of like 150 for about $3.50. The chocolate cost $4.50.

It's worth a trip in the area. It's fun for locals, especially to get some take home treats on your lunchbreak or on your way back from dim sum. And for tourists, it's a bit disappointing since it's a "factory" that's really no bigger than a closet. Check if out if you have the spare time and happen to be in the area, but don't go out of your way to see it.

On your way out, the owner will shove a hot cookie or two, unfolded into the palm of your hand or in your bag. Though it won't be steaming hot, that warm cookie is pretty damn tasty.
author: Stephanie H.

description: Yes, hidden gem to be sure!  Took my 9 year old daughter here and it was such fun!  They let us take pictures of the whole process and then the owner/manager/guy in charge took pictures with my daughter  ---- Awesome!  She will remember it always!
author: Ellie M.

description:
Every time we visit Chinatown, we stop by the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie. They offer free samples and always throw a few in the bag when you buy something.  We have 2 young kids.  They also gave them extra.  So, please visit after lunch or brunch.  Today, we bought a bag of mixed chocolate and regular fortune cookies for $4.75.  A bag of flat cookies were less, $3 something.  These cookies are yummy and the fortunes are traditional unlike some of the weird comments seen in other restaurants.  I've stored them in a ziplock bag and it lasts for some time. 

 And, of course, seeing them make the cookies on the old machinery brings back a taste of old Chinatown.  The walk down Ross Alley says it all, feeling a part of the history.  This factory is also part of the Chinatown walk and a good place to bring your visiting friends/family.

We park in the nearby garage and walk up the hill.
author: Christina T.

description:
This is a very fun place to visit in San Fran, and the cookies are really good.  

The first time I brought my wife here, into a dark alley in China Town, she became a little concerned, but was happy once we arrived.  It's a little bit of a tourist trap, and they even ask for 50 cents if you want to take a photo, but we visit it every time we are in San Fran to get a couple of bags of cookies.

The chocolate, unfolded cookies are the best.
author: Stephen S.

description:
i knew this was a must-see during my visit to frisco, so after researching and getting advise from my friends, i knew this was gunna be a hard place to find. but we were pretty lucky to have "stumbled" upon it while strolling through chinatown!

its really hidden, their sign is tiny, look for the alley sign "Ross", look down the alley, squint your eyes and try reading the little 2 X 2 yellow sign (exaggeration). anyway, the place is sooooo small, its amazing how many cookies is produced here. 50 cents for a picture? sure! why not! these gals probably make less than the average american worker anyway.  there was a very friendly old man who stood at the front giving us free samples. we bought a small bag mix with regular and chocolate fortune cookies for $4.50 to take back with us. =)
author: Sara C.

description: This place is a depressing tourist trap. It might be "off-the-beaten-path" because it is down an alley, but if they charge you 50 cents to take a photo of those poor women working in sweatshop conditions, then it's hard to pretend you've discovered something authentic here.
author: Sabbies B.

description: Seriously the BEST fortune cookies you will ever eat.  This is always a "must visit" site when I make my yearly trip to San Francisco.  Very tucked out of the way, down Ross Alley, but worth the trouble finding.  The free, warm samples are yum-o!  I always pick up an extra bag of the "adult" fortune cookies for some of my dinner parties.
author: Wendy O.

description:
What some people are describing as a scary alleyway seemed like a pretty and much-welcomed relief from the bustling main streets of Chinatown to me, so it's not that bad  ;)

I love fortune cookies. I have a soft spot for them. I've tasted them in four different countries, and all over the US, and these are, hands-down, the best.

Which shouldn't be surprising, since they apparently created the very first fortune cookies.

The two friends I took with me don't like fortune cookies (I have odd friends), but even they couldn't deny the deliciousness of their freshly-baked samples.

They also have the rarest of finds: -good- chocolate fortune cookies (normally I hate them).

Buy a huge bag folded with fortunes, or just as flat discs. They're cheap, yummy -and- a part of history. How can you argue with that?
author: Darrien A.

description: I only know how to find this place because I came here years ago, otherwise you'd miss it. But follow the trail of tourist down a practically unmarked tiny tiny street and you'll find an open door that leads you into a warehouse with people working on little stools meticulously folding cookie after cookie into little pacman shapes. They will hand out hot broken cookies that taste as delicious as it smells. Buy lots of the pre-packed bags of cookies to take home and eat more of later. These are REAL fortune cookies people. We don't have these in NY.
author: Kitty B.

description:
I remember visiting this place when I was on a field trip in second grade.  Over twenty years later it's still exactly the same w/ the same people running it.  The pure definition of "hole in the wall", as it resides in an alley way (Ross St......maybe considered a street, but it's really an alley).

They barely have enough room in there to form two lines.  I think no more than ten people could squeeze into their doors.  You won't be impressed by the view and you'll just see two HUGE cookie machines spinning, spitting out dough into molds and a lady popping them off inserting a small slip of paper and folding away.  I'm sure they've lost all sensation in their hands after handling so many hot cookies right out of the oven, but damn they're fast.

Considered a landmark in China Town and a must see for tourists.  It is kind of historical as it was one of the first fortune cookie makers around.  however the joy comes from getting samples right out of the oven and into your hands and into your stomach.  

Also, I never knew the cookies came flat as well til I visited here.  If you can do without the fortune, grab a bag of unfolded ones, or "discs".  You'll be amazed at how many you'll eat in one sitting (not recommended if you're on a diet).
author: Yehoy L.

description:
We went to the wrong place at first, down some stairs but then went back up after we smelled rice cooking so thought "this can't be the place".  Then a old man waved us into the next store with a smile saying to us "fortune cookie"!  

We were slightly shocked at how dingy the place is and the fortune cookie making equipment looks like it's an antique!  But again, that's all part of the experience of visiting this place.  It's been on my list of "got to see" next time I'm in Chinatown for a while, and I'm glad I finally visited. Cookies are fresh and tastey, we got a large bag of unfolded cookies. We had the old guy take our picture with the woman making cookies on that old press.  All part of the Chinatown experience, and we'll visit again.
author: Karrot L.

description: I love this place! It is a tiny place in the middle of Chinatown San Francisco, totally worth visiting. It doesnt need to be a long planned trip, but who knew the process for making fortune cookies was this quick and simple- yet not so much. To take a picture of the process you will need to pay (50cents- no biggy but be aware) and you can make your own fortune cookie- write whatever you want... fun times! They only accept cash, so be prepared!
author: Carolina V.

description: Traditional cookies=good.  Chocolate=not.  Don't expect a 'tour' of anything here.  I felt bad for the school group of 30 kids that showed up right after I walked in.  I hope they didn't plan on killing much time there!  What it is, is a small room with a few people seated next to a cookie iron.  If you take a picture, you will be asked to pay a toll (50 cents).  I splurged for 2.  The day I came a male was in front, screaming at me in Chinese. He yelled at me while taking pictures, so I had to show him my dollar.  He gave the two previous customers extra cookies in their bags. Not me.  I guess it wan't my lucky day.  Been there, done it.
author: JP i.

description: Heard from tour book places that this was a site to see.  We ventured down one day to try and find this place.  It's literally off of the beaten path and a very small building,  only 10 or less people can fit in.  The owner was very friendly and gave us lots of samples.  They were tasty / we bought chocolate and adult ones.  Good place to check out if you are in the area and to experience them making the cookies.
author: Sara S.

description: I came here one evening with a friend who found the review on yelp. This place is isolated in a dark little alleyway with barely a number visible. Our nose is what guided us to this... We were warmly greeted by an Asian man and the woman making the cookies.  We got a free sample of the flat cookies  and decided we needed to get at least a small bag each of the fortune cookies.  A small bag of 5 cookies was $1 - well worth the price [cash only] (and i got awesome fortunes!).  The freshness and crispness of the cookies were fantastic that only my taste buds, if they could talk, could really tell you how fabulously flavorful and delicious the cookies were.  I'd definitely come back to get a bigger bag.  Oh... and they also sell chocolate cookies and  'adult cookies' ;)
author: melinda m.

description:
10.12.13 with 1 other
located in a ally 

they have the best fortune cookies! so crispy and fresh! i like that they have the flat ones without the fortunes.

love their other snacks too.

not a big fan of the small shop but of course they cant help that, gets to crowded with the tourist, but i was in and out in a couple minutes to pick up a few bags.

other yelpers, said they were greeted by the old man and given samples, sad to say i was not when i went- he was chilling in the back watching, no greeting, no samples...sigh

CASH ONLY
author: Jay R.

description:
mee mee bakery or golden gate fortune cookies?
golden gate fortune cookies. handsdowwwn.
mee mee has a better location and actually has a storefront. but golden gate is FRESH and offers FREE SAMPLES! 

i definitely had trouble locating Ross alley but the smell of fortune cookies led me to the right place. right upon entering i saw the famous old man who offers free samples and as if on cue, he offers me some in a tin can. as i nibbled on the fresh sample, i searched for the famous adult fortune cookies and saw them to be located behind the sweet old man as if he was guarding it. unlike in the other reviews he didn't question my friend and me as we were debating between the adult fortune cookies or the regular ones. after paying him $4.50 for a bag of the adult ones he reaches for my change and grabs some more samples for me with the same hand. yes, it is unsanitary and yes i was a bit repulsed but FRESH FREE samples. i couldn't possibly pass those up. my friend and i happily left and immediately began munching on the cookies. 

though my friend was initially suspicious of this place she was easily hooked on them and wanted to return to get a bag of her own less than an hour after we had first went. this prompted me to get another bag in order to share with my family later on.  the mistake pieces were bagged and sold for $3.50 and so we each got one of those. the old man then tells me to put the bag i held back on the shelf since he would give me an even fresher one bagged only a moment ago (i knew that since i saw a worker literally JUST bag them). we left with more samples in hand as a bunch of tourists entered the place. 

this place is merely a factory with a couple shelves as the storefront so dont expect anything spectacular with the interior. but DO buy several bags since tehy will be gobbled up quickly.

whether tourist or san francisco native, this is the place to get your fortune cookies.
author: Wendy N.

description:
I can testify that everything Mr. Forrest Y wrote in his review below is accurate, as I was one of the native Cantonese speakers who accompanied him to said cookie factory.

Fob on Fob discrimination, it's a terrible thing.  

Yet the smell of freshly baked fortune cookies will last in my jar shaped memory...for as long as I shall live.
author: Sam W.

description:
After a dinner at Sam Wo's my friend brought us down a shady alleyway to this fortune cookie shop.  We walked in to see a lady pulling off baked cookie circles from a machine and folding them into fortune cookies, another lady cleaning another machine, and a man just kicking it in the corner.  

They had a bucket of unfolded fortune cookies that you could sample for free.  I bought a bag of the "adult" fortune cookies.  Fu Ling Yu's (get it? haha) fortunes were a little confusing, but it was still cool none-the-less.  The cashier even gave me a bunch of sample cookie sheets to take home.  

Everything was pretty cool except that they charge 50 cents if you want to take a picture of the shop and they don't sell chocolate covered fortune cookies (my favorite!). Other than that... they were super nice, you got free stuff, and it was a pretty awesome site to see in Chinatown. =)
author: Marilou A.

description:
I always get assed-backwards trying to find this place. With so many alleys in Chinatown, its sometimes hard to find this little hidden jem on the first try. Sometimes from the main street, you can smell the fortune cookies. Follow the aroma and you will eventually find this place.

Where else in the city can you buy a fresh bag of fortune cookies for three dollars and meet the ladies who make them? They offer traditional fortune cookies, flat cookies without the fortunes, chocolate fortune cookies and cookies with naughty fortunes.

I love this spot. It is one of my favorite places to take my out-of-town vistors because usually they have never heard about this place. It's a little secret in Chinatown, off the beaten path.
author: Kathleen N.

description:
The simple shock here is that humans "bake" fortune cookies. I always imagined them being spit out by an army of machines, a la the "Short Circuit."  But, as you will see at Golden Gate, there is a woman folding fortune cookies and laying em, rapid fire, on cookie conveyor belt.

The "grand tour" lasts all of 4 seconds.  Not that exciting.  "Fresh Fortune Cookies" taste pretty much like "Regular Fortune Cookies."
author: Fernando V.

description:
The rules: 

You must bring all of your out of town guests here.

You must buy at least one bag of cookies.  (I like the unfolded chocolate ones best.)

You must convince your out of town guests to pay fifty cents for a photo of the ancient machine and the lady folding cookies at the end of it.

You must smile and say, "thank you" when the old man yells, "HOT COOKIE!" in your ear and shoves an actual HOT COOKIE into your hand.

You must allow yourself a moment to feel superior to the rest of the fortune cookie eating world because fortune cookies were invented in San Francisco.
author: Miss Information X.

description: cute tiny factory. Its as large as my closet. We opted for the x-rated fortune cookies and they are more like the wtf cookie. Not x rated at all and most made no sense, oh well they tasted great
author: Kevin D.

description:
This is right next to my barber. 
They are not Marcus fans and do not think that I am amusing. 

Hot fortune cookies are good.
You can also bring in your own fortunes but make sure they are the right size or you will be scolded.
author: Marcus R.

description:
Wow, talk about nostalgia.  After visiting this shack, i was immediately taken back to oh....1974/76 to LA Chinatown.  Its nothing more than a run down building with some baking equipment, but it churns out the best damn fortune cookies on the pacific coast.  

I love the old school feel, and the old lady tossing samples out while collecting cash.  

My cousin really hit a homerun by taking me here to grab some snacks.  Cant wait to go back and get more.  

Thanks for the memories......
author: Shon T.

description:
Chinatown as I remember from my childhood, is rapidly disappearing.
I noticed recently that most of my fortune cookies were coming out of  LA or NYC. In a panic, I googled up GGFC to see if they to are now a historical memory also. To my relief they're not. Last time I took my daughter there was seven years ago. I think it's time to take another walk through old Chinatown to see what's left of it and get another sack of  my favorite fortune cookies.
author: calvin o.

description:
Okay so the man who greeted ME was NOT cute or friendly. He was actually really pushy and rude and was trying to get us out of there as fast as possible. So I got to spend like...30 seconds in here because I was so rushed. 

The 4-star review is for the fortune cookies....seriously the most delicious you will ever eat; if I lacked willpower, I'd eat the whole bag in one sitting. The X-Rated ones are, as one person mentioned, not actually X-rated. More like PG, but they're still good for a laugh. Just thinking about this place makes my mouth water. YUM!
author: Kate P.

description: It's like going to fortune cookie heaven! If you are in SF you have to go here. It is amazing to see how they do it, and to taste them a second after they are made is so worth it! Loved the tiny place, full of personality!
author: Maria C.

description:
This place was really cool to check out when it's not busy. Otherwise like one reviewer stated, be prepared for the not so subtle rush out.

Not really into taking photos of myself at these little places, so I guess I saved 50cents... But I gave it all back by buying two bags of cookies, the flat ones for a friend, and the mixed chocolate/natural ones for myself. I LOVE fortune cookies so it was cool to walk up here and check the place out. Watching them being made was kind of nifty, plus I got that Asian hook-up... the guy (old man really) gave me a bunch of extra cookies aside from the ones that I bought that came in the packaged bags... awesome!
author: Wonder W.

description:
Follow the sweet aroma down Ross Alley and you shall find a happy ending. 

Not THAT kind of ending, sickos.

FORTUNE COOKIES! Made fresh and assembled before your very eyes. These are so good and addicting. Personally, I prefer the disc shaped cookies. They have assorted flavors of chocolate and strawberry, too.

The factory is one of Chinatown's many hidden gems.
author: Annie L.

description: My husband and I went there after eight pm on Saturday nite and were bummed that they might be closed.  Luckily, the old man was on the phone and welcomed us in even though he was by himself.  He offered us samples and they were good! We grabbed a package of the swirl fortune cookies and made sure to pay the fifty cents for the picture. It was nice to enter a place with so much history.  make sure to snap a picture of the Chinatown map on the ground outside the shop.
author: Alice And Steve S.

description: Yummmmm! Wish I could come here everyday! Buy cookies to take home! U won't regret it! I love the flat ones!
author: Olivia G.

description:
I've lived here 5 years and hadn't visited this GEM until today.   It's a living, working part of San Francisco history and an absolute must-see.  

I am usually intimidated by Chinatown.  The frantic flow of the pedestrian traffic, the indecipherable signs, and the unfamiliar smells and sounds are often enough to send me fleeing.   So much for wandering around and soaking up the atmosphere!

This trip to Chinatown was different because I had a destination. I knew which alley to slip into.  I left feeling like I had new intimate knowledge of this city.

Oh! And if you come prepared with your own little 'fortune' they will put it inside a cookie for you!  ONLY 50 CENTS!  Wouldn't that be a sweet little gift or souvenir?!
author: Rochelle R.

description:
Best fortune Cookies in town ever!

Fresh cookies, and reasonable prices

in the little store, u can see how workers make cookies!

how excellent if u can try one right after cookies are made :)

it is always crowed, so u may need to wait for the cookies in a mood of  old style and tasty smell
author: Sue S.

description:
This is not "just" a fortune cookie.  I think that concept is hard to fathom until you have a fresh fortune cookie from the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie Co.  These are the BEST fortune cookies you're ever going to find.  Or at least the best ones you're going to find for under $3 a bag in SF China Town.  Lots of vanilla and a great crunchy, yet airy texture.  The shop itself and the difficulty in finding it just makes them all the better.   If you do go, skip the folded ones and get a bag of the "Unfortunate Cookies" (the flat ones everyone's been talking about).  You get even more for your money and I happen to think they also taste better. 

Be forewarned, if you live or work close to SF Chinatown, these are habit forming.  I used to work 2 blocks from here and had to make frequent visits to replenish my supplies.  Now I have to settle on my mother-in-law bringing us several bags every time she comes to visit us in Omaha.  

Of course I'm also a bit biased because I used their cookies to propose to my wife and they were heavily featured at our wedding reception :-)
author: Derek E.

description:
I've always taken fortune cookies for granted, it's always offered at the end of the meal at like PANDA EXPRESS. But little did i know how they were made or how they came about.

Anyways, i was at BORDERS reading a book about the history of CHINATOWN and there was a reference to a famous fortune cookie alley in San Francisco. That alley is ROSS ALLEY, and it's very difficult to find in Chinatown. So.... with my iPHone and with the GPS i located it! It's amazing that I walk by it at least 20 times and never noticed.

But my new iPhone 3G found it, hahah! The factory is very small with a tiny little sign. There's also a lot of curious tourists who randomly walk by and discover it. Inside is a small room with older employees workin the fortune cookie machines. A rotating conveyor is filled with round chips, and they are all flat. Some of the flat ones are thrown into a nearby can and never become a fortune cookie. Others are folded in half by using a metal rod, and at the same time, a paper slip is placed inside. It is then curved into shape by hand and air dryed.

Ok!! I have told you how they are made. But what about the origin of the fortune cookie? They were never invented in China. Some say they were first served in the JAPANESE TEA GARDEN in Golden Gate Park. Others say they were first made in Japan. Even L.A. has bragging rights to the origin of the first fortune cookie. 

But whatever the case, this place on Ross Alley is special. They give you free samples to try, yummm! The cookies are fresh from the oven, so fresh that i can't stop from eating half a bag! ;) Anyways, this is a recommended  place with 5 plus stars. And of course, it's worth taking a picture of the place for 50 cents. 

Don't forget bring your friends from out of town here. :) Or to check out the triple x fortune cookies, they are sort of hidden away.
author: herm p.

description: A fun free way to experience fortune cookie making in a small authentic setting in the heart of San Francisco.
author: Kristin P.

description: This is a must see spot in San Fran.  Tucked away in an alley in China Town you can see how they have been making fortune cookies for years.  I'm pretty certain the equipment they are using hasn't been updated since the '40's.  If you have found this place you have found the inner workings of China Town.  Good luck getting back.
author: Scott M.

description: What a cute little shop! And it smells absolutely delicious. An old man sits outside to wave tourists in and as you walk in, the fortune cookies are being baked and shaped. He offered us the fortune cookies that weren't so fortunate, that turned into a flat pancake, instead of the usual fortune cookie shape. And as a Yelper that loves to take pictures, I noticed the sign to not take pictures and if we did, they take a donation of $1. A must-visit when seeing Chinatown!
author: Anne T.

description: This is a fun must - do that won't take too long.  Bring cash.  Yummmmmmmy cookies!
author: Cassie P.

description: After eating dim sum with my mom, we decided to get fortune cookies for my grandma (she loves the flat ones). This was actually my first time going to golden gate fortune cookie factory although I grew up eating them. Walking down alley, we could smell the aroma of the cookies, like fresh waffle cones. We walked in and were greeted by a happy older man. He offered us samples and I was more than happy to accept.  It's really cool to see the machine used to make these cookies, and then see each cookie hot of the press hand molded.  We settled for bags of flat cookies and the friendly man threw in an extra handful if cookies. How nice! I suggest if you haven't had a fresh, warm cookie from here you should!
author: danielle l.

description:
Fun to watch and fun to sample.  Located in Ross Alley, a reminder of those "bad ol' days", this tiny cookie factory went from unnoticed to becoming a touristy destination.  

What I really like about this place is the price.  I've been going there for years to get fresh baked cookies and the price hasn't gone up at all (still $3 a bag).  Cookies come in either folded like your typical fortune cookie or flat discs.

The owner is quite nice and usually gives free samples for you to munch away.  

There no other place like it.
author: Vvn W.

description: Ok, you just have to stop by the factory when in SF.  The "factory" is a small shop where you get up close and personal with the folks making (hand folding!) fortune cookies.  We arrived just after opening and were welcomed in.  Our kids made cookies and we had a great time.  Be sure to buy a bag of the fortune cookie chips...easier to eat on the go.  After having one of their cookies no other fortune cookie will do.
author: Jim C.

description:
This tiny, hard-to-find shop is tucked away in an alley, but worth your time to stop by. There's not much to look at--two women hard at work pinching and folding fortune cookies--but it will give you a whole new appreciation for the process. I wish there was a brochure or sign, at least, giving some history or background on the place for passersby; I guess this is why you pay for local tours. 

As for the product of this labor: unlike the mass-produced cookies you'll find elsewhere, these are delicious. They taste...golden. They also offer chocolate (!) which taste cocoa-y at first, but then provide a subtle spicy aftertaste. Now, if only someone would work on making the fortunes more clever...or maybe I need to get the X-rated ones.
author: Mary R.

description: Smaller than I imagined but very cool. Bring your ca$h!
author: Josie C.

description:
Definitely hard to find.  We were in front of it, saying the address, looking around like idiots.  Finally a small Chinese man invited us in.  If you take a picture of the workers be sure to leave a tip... consider it good fortune.

We bought some regular cookies and fortune cookies.  The fortune cookies were the best I've ever had, not that these things are exactly a delicacy.  

Visiting this place takes about 10 minutes, tops to check out, so don't make this your only stop in Chinatown.
author: Jay B.

description:
This place is a little hard to find and is tucked away in a little alley called Ross Alley. Even though I checked ahead of time, I still could not find the place and got directions from someone walking down the street in Chinatown. The alley is easy to miss, and I know I have walked by it at other times when I wasn't specifically looking for Golden Gate Fortune Cookies. 

The factory is the size of a large closet or small room, so be prepared for something that is about a 2 minute visit. It smells so warm, inviting and fresh as  you walk inside. It is pretty neat to see at least once because you can see how the cookies rotate through the machines and the worker lady sticking the fortunes in at the end before they are folded. Make sure to pay 50 cents to take a picture of the workers and machines before leaving with a warm, tasty sample.
author: Cynthia D.

description: Crunchy but not sweet enuf. Not friendly at all.
author: Josh F.

description: Best fortune cookies.  Although the two ladies making them looked quite unhappy to be there.
author: Kelly K.

description: Eh. I wasn't impressed. Smelled great in there but the cookie didn't back up the hype. The line is long and the place is super crowded. Don't get it.
author: Nay S.

description:
So Chinatown is kind of my second home because we frequent here so often... but I did not know of this gem until I stumbled upon it one day walking back to our car.

Me: "Oooh it smells so good!"
Husband: "Oh yeah, this place is a really famous fortune cookie store."
Me: "What, why didn't you ever tell me before?  We come here every weekend and I've never known about this place?"
Husband: ::silence::

Sadly for me, I discovered this place so late.  However, husband was saved when he bought me a big bag of un-twisted aka flat cookies for me to savor on.  I liked the idea of not having to crack open my cookie every time I want to eat it and take that piece of paper out (it's the laziness in me...).  Flat fortune cookies are the way to go!  And these fortune cookies were warm and made just right!
author: Ibbs K.

description: It's true, nothing at any restaurant tastes like the samples they give you right off the assembly line (see Derek's unfolded 'Unfortunate Cookies'). But make sure you "Stay behind the yellow line!" I went there long ago for the sexy cookies which have been discontinued for the time being, but there is still quite an assortment, including chocolate. Take some tourists here and they'll find it authentic, but the tour lasts no longer then 30 seconds.
author: Kim G.

description:
This is a fun little place to swing by while in Chinatown. Watch fortune cookies being made on this wild looking fortune cookie machine/griddle. Who ever came up with that thing is a genius. I could watch it make little cookie discs for quite awhile, though that probably says more about me than the machine...

Like others have said, there are regular fortunes and "adult fortunes" though in my experience many of them are just plain crazy. They hand out fortune cookie "duds" as treats/samples. Tasty!

They charge you to take a picture of the place though so be prepared to fork over a buck or take your pics on the sly.
author: Amanda W.

description: I've been coming here for years. I love the free samples and watching the workers fold the cookies in front of your eyes. We always bring home a bag of flat rejects. Great flavor and obviously fresh since the production line is about one foot from the food display. The purveyor usually throws in a few extra samples with every purchase, but CB and I scarf through the samples and have opened the bag soon after we've left the store. Great value and a little bit of an adventure discovering the store for non-residents like me.
author: Cathy C.

description:
Sorry for bringing down the optimism, but it's a hole in the wall that makes fortune cookies. Can't rate it, "I've experienced Better" cause how many fortune cookie factories are there...and can't rate it "I'm a fan" because I'm not a fan.  I wanted to venture out here because I recalled seeing it on Mr. Rodger's Neighborhood, when I was a little boy in Texas.  Unfortunately, I don't really like fortune cookies, so this review's gonna be skewed and debbie downer.

It's in an awesome alley where you wouldn't wanna be trolling in the dark.  They sell a lot of fortune cookies and you guilt yourself into buying a bag because what the hell did you come here for.  Then you get home and eat 5 and never touch the other 300 that are left over. If you're bored and want to venture out in Chinatown, might as well check out to say you've seen it.  

One note that bugged me (read if you're nit-picky about sanitation): The guy who made our transaction, hooked us up with giving us some fresh flat fortune cookies.  Great gesture, but in doing so, he handled our money, wiped his nose and digged into the bucket of cookies all in one swift sequence.  He also runs the machines that pumps out the cookies. I didn't get giardia or anything, but bad sanitation practices bug me...like waiters who touch the mouth of the glass with their hands to place it on your table...or guys at Steve's Korean BBQ who cook shirtless and are dribbling in sweat...but I digress.

Anyhow, check it out but don't expect anything amazing or historical. I can't see myself coming back here over and over again...
author: Tsubasa O.

description: This is just a neat place to see; not spectacular. I love commercialism! There is now a sign that if you want to take a pictures of the young women making the fortune cookies; it will cost you a $1. Well this is America. You can get regular fortune cookies, chocolate fortune cookies and unfinished fortune cookies. Just plain and round with not fortune inside them. If you have never been here before I would make sure that you map directions to go. I have been here a few times, but there are so many little alleyways that it is a little tough to find it just based on your memory.
author: Rander P.

description:
If you're ever strolling through Chinatown, be sure to stop by this tiny fortune cookie shop and take a peek inside.

We were greeted by a friendly, old Chinese man who encouraged us to shuffle in closer and observe 1 of the 2 workers doing her thing at one of the fortune cookie making machines. It's neat seeing how they're made and watching them put their quick folding & stuffing skills to work. You're also given a fresh, flat, fortune cookie to munch on while you watch!

All in all, it's fun 3 minute stop!

p.s. I heard that they have x-rated fortune cookies!
author: Tiffany M.

description:
4/4/06 - Another mandetory stop on Gail's personal tour of San Francisco for out-of-town guests. Sometimes I feel they're a little less hospitable than I want them to be (maybe it's because I'm Asian and a local?), but they do give out samples, and the walk down Ross Alley is pretty fun.  Listen for the clicking of mah-jong tiles, and look for the celebrity snapshots of Michael Douglas and River Phoenix outside of the nearby barbershop.

3/6/07 - Hey!  The barbershop is gone!  But the chocolate fortune cookies are still pretty tasty...
author: Gail O.

description:
From the way it appears this is a part of history of Chinatown.
I'm a local, born and raised and I have visited this establishment just last summer. Finally I remember to write my thoughts of this factory.
It's somewhat a large place but not much walking room. It's basically a fortune cookie factory. Handmade with a furnace that heats the cookie dough. It's a tight fit when you get to this place which is hidden from the city streets. You may purchase the tasty cookies that were made rite there. How about that? The staff are very friendly and they love taking pictures and giving out free samples. The fortunes paper is placed in the cookies by hand. Pre-bagged cookies for sale. The cookie smell wonderful.
Cash only.
author: Smooth R.

description:
Definitely on my list for the next SF China Town visit.

Very friendly, we were offered FREE samples.  We bought some sesame cookies, almond cookies and chocolate fortune cookies and some "naughty" adult fortune cookies.

It takes a whole 10 minutes out of your visit to the area, but if you are going to do the tourist China Town visit you got to go there.
author: a a.

description: Stopped by on a tour and was amazed this tiny place makes so many fortune cookies a day. I loved the sign that asked for 50 cents to take a pic. Many gladly obliged.  The old man selling cookies and taking money was friendly and gave me a sample. Wow it's so good when it's fresh and still warm.
author: Benny H.

description: If you live in San Francisco or traveling through, this is a must go to place. The fortune cookies are so fresh and delicious. They even have chocolate flavored which was my favorite. You can smell the sweet aroma down the alley, you just have to follow the scent. You can see people make the cookies right in front of you.
author: Grace G.

description:
I have been in this place a number of times in the last 10 years, and it is always the same...terrific.  The original owners are there, and the fortune cookie assembly line is something you do not expect to find in Nob Hill. It is a must see if you are in the area.

Nothing beats eating a warm fortune cookie (where else will you ever be able to do that?).

In the same ally is a barber that played a traditional Asian instrument in the movie "The Pursuit of Happyness" and has cut the hair of many celebrities.
author: Dan E.

description:
I think it was about 10 years ago when my sister last came here. She was determined to come back to get some fortune cookies, but all she was able to remember was that it was located on some side alley. We even had a bit of trouble finding it with our GPS, but when we finally found the place it was totally worth it.

When you walk in you can see the cookies being made fresh right in front of you. It's amazing to see that they're actually hand folded, rather than just being mass produced by some machine.  The owner gave us some free samples. There's nothing better than eating a warm cookie. They don't fresher than that! You can buy cookies folded or flat without the fortunes. They also have strawberry and chocolate flavored ones...yum! The flavors and freshness make these some of the tastiest fortune cookies you'll ever have. 

This place is also known for their "adult" fortune cookies. When my sister asked for a bag of them the owner said, "They are not for kids! They are for adults!" My sister was like uh...I'm 28. haha! He was really nice and gave us some bags of cookies that weren't even out on shelf...they were way better than the ones on the shelf. Tip: it pays to be nice and be friendly with the owner!
author: Kristen R.

description:
Maybe I went at the wrong time of day, but after reading the rave reviews, I was pretty disappointed by my visit.  

It's fun to discover this little factory, and neat to see the women quickly making the cookies, but we were not offered samples and I wasn't sure who to ask. It's a tiny place and we felt in the way and didn't want to linger.  We bought a bag of cookies, which were tasty.  I wouldn't go out of my way to see it.
author: Lauren J.

description:
We swing by here as often as possible.  I love the people here--- the little dude who walks up the line of people (yes, there is often a line, but it moves really quickly) with samples--- he is darling.

For a real treat, pick up a bag of the triple x-rated fortune cookies.  They are HILARIOUS because they are triple x-rated maybe by 1960 standards.  Pretty darn tame, so the best part is that they are labeled as being so risque. 

But my favorite are the almond cookies.  Holy crap---- I could easily devour a whole bag in a matter of minutes.  I would beat that competitive eater someone Chestnut at eating these almond cookies, I bet.  I'm like the Cookie Monster with those things.  Like posessed.  They are THAT good.

Right, so go.  This place is TOTALLY San Francisco.  Make sure your tourist friends check it out for sure, too.  Not to be missed. 

And did I mention the almond cookies?
author: Dele P.

description: I have found the origins of the mysterious fortune cookie from which all my luck has stemmed. I was expecting monkeys working the gears of some magical machine while a man bangs away on a gong. Instead I see only chinese people sitting down in chairs doing repetitive folding of the cookie dough while it's still hot. Ancient chinese secret revealed!
author: Andrew F.

description: This place is really a hidden gem.  You get to see up close and personal how fortune cookies are made by very humble and hard working women.  It smells divine in here.  The women seemed oblivious as I walked around taking pictures and just observing, and just continued working and speaking in their native language.  I bought bags of cookies, and they were delic.
author: Ashley E.

description: In my opinion, no visit to SFO is complete without strolling down Ross Alley to pick up some FRESH fortune cookies. Don't forget to add "in bed" to each fortune. In fact, that's the only difference between the regular fortunes and the "adult fortunes". :)
author: Charles L.

description:
This place has been there forever...I first found it by wandering around on my own in Chinatown.  What a treasure....especially if you LOVE fortune cookies even without the fortune.  You can buy them in "disc" form before folding and wrapping......mmmmmm I will buy in bulk!  Fun for everyone.
Jerren
author: Jerren A.

description: Like Yoda leading me to "The Force" an old man wearing a sweater in a narrow alley lined with Chinese paper lanterns stated in heavy accent-"Fortune Cookies!". I could smell the factory fresh cookies as I approached and my journey to find the factory had ended. Since 1962 Franklin Lee has delighted folks with free samples and a look into an ancient tradition. The sign states factory but really there were three young ladies methodically removing warm cookie dough from the conveyer, filling it with a white fortune slip (xxx rated ones too), looping them around a pin and folding neatly on half. Voilà!  Fortune cookie!  I left with two bags!  Another bucket list item checked off.
author: Kalipo K.

description:
Our new associate wanted to wander around Chinatown and, somehow, we ended coming here after eating lunch nearby. This place is compact and yet does not deter flocks of tourists from purchasing bags of fortune cookies at reasonable prices. We were lucky enough to be the only ones in the factory as they churned score after score of cookies.

We ended up getting a small bag of "baby" sized cookies which were not folded and another small bag with different flavored cookies -- strawberry, chocolate and plain. 

The kicker for me was being able to try sample after sample... they even throw some in when you purchase cookies.
author: S L.

description: Place is a hole in the wall, but just what I expected based on other Yelper's reviews. Four basic kinds of cookies & then variations on the fortune cookie (chocolate, swirls, large & small flat cookies). People look crabby, but they are kind of  nice if that makes any sense.  They do give samples and the fortune cookies are good - not that weird cake batter taste that some fortune cookies have.  It cost $1 for a small bag of fortune cookies and $4.75 for a large bag.  When you are at a Chinese restaurant and you get a fortune cookie after dinner, we always want more, but when you can have as many as you want, how many fortune cookies do you actually want to eat?  We bought a large bag of fortune cookies, a mix of regular and chocolate flavored.  I wish now that I would have bought some of the other cookies, but they seemed to only have large bags of those for sale.  We were in there kind of late in the day, so more variety may be available if you go earlier.   It's interesting to see the ladies working to make the cookies.  Yes, there's a sign saying that it costs 50 cents to take a picture of them working - don't expect them to take notice of you or smile!  I definitely think it's worth finding the place, sampling and buying the cookies, and taking a picture - it's fun.
author: TL R.

description: Love the Chocolate fortune cookies. A fun and friendly place to visit with the kids.
author: Carol O.

description: Favorite place to go for some yummy fortune cookies, they make em fresh right in front of you, and usually give you free samples as well.
author: Monika T.

description:
"You want sexy fortune cookie?"
I, ah.....
"You want sexy fortune cookie?"
Ummm....uuhhhh.
Do I say yes and end up in some back room, blindfolded and strapped to a table? Do I say no and risk offending the sweet looking lady working the fortune cookie maker. I do not know what she is asking me!!! 
That is what my first minute inside this shop was like. Come to find out they make regular fortune cookies and cookies with adult themed fortunes, hence the "sexy fortune cookie." This is a great little hidden San Francisco spot. You can actually watch the warm cookie dough come out in a circular pattern and get folded into the fortune cookie shape. While we were watching they kept giving us the warm cookie dough circles that were being popped out of the machine. Tasty. The shop is the actual factory and it felt intrusive to stand there watching everyone work, but they were really welcoming. Excellent spot to bring out of town guests.
author: Bucky K.

description: We discovered this place on a recent visit to SF.  It's a tiny storefront operation.  The owner came out to greet us and, I admit it - we did the tourist thing and watched wide-eyed as the cookie maker operated a huge, old machine.  We must've looked hungry ... the owner offered us lots of yummy free samples.  Bought 3 bags of disk cookies.  A week later, they're still fresh!  You've gotta go there!
author: J M.

description: I never laughed so hard in my life. finding the place is itself an adventure. i think its a must see SF attraction. say cheese and pay a buck!
author: Sun P.

description:
visited 11/17/09
as soon as we walked in, they gave us flat fortune cookies to taste. then I paid to take a picture with the lady working the fortune cookie machine. it was only 50 cents but we gave her a dollar. which led to the little old man giving us more cookies. the cookies were really yummy. I happen to love fortune cookies and think these were the best ones I've ever had. the shop is really tiny. luckily there weren't very many people there so I was able to walk right in and get up close.
author: Liza M.

description:
This place is awesome/hilarious/totally unique.  Through a work project, I was faced with the challenge of making 200 custom fortune cookies.  After some internet sleuthing, I found that most other vendors took days and cost about 10x as this local gem.  Other reviews were super helpful (thanks Yelp!) and I knew to go in there with the fortunes pre-cut and pre-printed (2.25" x .5" in case you were wondering).  We scored some take-out boxes from Clement St and expect that the final product will look teriffic. 
For $16 you get a bag of 100 fortune cookies.  They're open late, and when I walked in at 7pm, she asked me if I wanted to pick it up later that evening, and handed me a stack of fresh cookies as she escorted me out the door. 
Best part of all was that I needed a reciept for my expense report.  I guarantee this is the first time the finance department will see a reciept fully in Chinese.
author: Heather C.

description: Hella free samples!!!!! Adult fortune cookies available there too!! Haha super sweet and friendly people working in shop.
author: Michelle W.

description:
Tucked away in an alley in Chinatown you'll find these darling, nimble-handed ladies folding fortune cookies at an impressive rate. They greet you enthusiastically, they'll take your picture for a mere quarter - maybe expect your entire body to be missing from the image, or your body with no head as catching everything in frame doesn't seem to be all that easy. You walk away with some nice, funny photos.

It's worth the authentic--brief--experience, and an inexpensive bag of flat rounds or a chocolate/regular mix bag of fortune cookies.
author: Natalie D.

description:
My granddaughter and I have visited this place several times and had a blast every time.  Last December, she took 50 "fortune slips" that we had printed at home and the lady smilingly tucked them into our cookies.  What fun! 

The place is tiny, so you can't stay long.  If you want to take a picture you must pay.
author: Patti C.

description:
As usual, this place is always packed with tourist enjoying how they make their cookies. I always get the flat round cookies to eat while watching a movie (movie night) vs. popcorn and make my smoothie vs a soda. I always buy the fresh cooked flat round cookies and take it to work for snack. It taste a lot better and fresh compared from the chinese restaurant gives us after we pay our tab. 

Unfortunately, due to economic reasons, they raised the price and now it's up from 3.00 to 3.75 or 4 bucks. If you don't care I recommend for you to least go here and try. If you don't like it, you can always give to a homeless person.
author: Lileth M.

description: this place is small, real small. can get kind of hectic when more than 10 people try to all cramp in and watch the lady bending the round flat cookies into shape. it's so simple that it's amazing. i thought it'd take more work than that. i wasn't going to buy any at first, because i thought well cookies are cookies, they all taste the same. SO WRONG. these fortune cookies are PERFECT. i bought a pretty big bag for 3 dollar and some change. here i am eating the last one, and very much regretting not buying more. so sad :(
author: Anh L.

description: The cookies are really good here. I buy the unfolded cookies.  They don't explode when you break them in half like a folded cookie. They are only $3.50 a bag so I usually buy three bags.  It is fun to watch them come off the machine and you normally get a free sample.  As an added bonus, they normally throw a few hot ones right off the machine into your bag when you buy some.  Like most cookies, they are even better hot.
author: Jason W.

description: I always take my out-of-town visitors to the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie Factory during my walking tour of Chinatown. The souvenirs are ediable--the workers will give you some rejects to sample.  It's amusing, free, and definately worth a visit considering the fortune cookie's roots are said to lie in San Franciso.  In 1914, Makoto Hagiwara, a Japanese American, introduced cookies bearing thank-you notes at his Japanese Tea Garden in Golden Gate Park and served them at the 1915 Panama-Pacific Exhibition, San Francisco's world's fair.  Thus the Fortune Cookie was born.
author: mandy f.

description: Pretty neat little factory ;] Stop by for a quick lesson on how fortune cookies are made. The women are amazing! The place is kinda dark and hidden, but they are very welcoming, give you free samples, and let you take pics!
author: Laurie c.

description: Another visit to my favorite norcal city and made sure that I stopped by this place.  My friend and I walked up and down Jackson St. looking for Ross Alley (one of the oldest alley ways in SF where there were Brothels and gambling), we found a alley in hopes that it was the right one.  As walking through the alley, we found a sweet smell and used our nose to guide our way to the factory.  Continued walking down the alley looking for the place, but couldn't find it. Walked back down the alley again and found the teeeeeney tiny sign and voila a little shop with the cutest man making the fortune cookies.  Seeing the machine making these cookies was so intricate and yet simple.  It was great...the cookies were yummy also...
author: Crystal H.

description: This place have been in San Francisco's Chinatown for a long, long time! They still make their cookies the old fashion way! Their cookies are soo yummy! I love coming here and watching the women make the cookies. They use their hands and pick up the hot cookie from the pan thing and they put in a fortune and make it into the shape.
author: Janet Z.

description: This fortune cookie sweatshop is one of those truly classic old Chinatown experiences that should not be missed.  I'm gonna buck the trend though, and say their batter is a bit too light and eggy for my taste.
author: Rick H.

description:
Are you looking for sweets?  Old lady hears, "Are you a sweaty person?  Did you say sweatshop factory?!"  No no...I meant the fortune cookie factory in Chinatown, in the narrow Ross Alley.  Ooh, ok then.  
 This place has been here as long as I can remember.  Yea those good ole days, the field trips, the taste tests, fortune readings, and touristy shop visits.  Those diligent ladies make the best tasting fortune cookies here -- must be that ancient thousand year old secret recipe eh?
Way better than those pre-wrapped cookies that they pass out in some take out places.  Very Crunchy..and they come in strawberry, chocalate, & vanilla flavors. All shapes and sizes too.  Who said you couldn't find dessert for under $5 in the city here.  For $3-4 a bag, I sure had enough to munch on the way back to the office and share with co-workers in anticipation (who always sense the smell of freshly baked cookies or anything edible for that matter = ).   Have a sample to taste and you won't leave without buying a bag or 2 to go.  If you know the nice lady there, she may give you some extra goodies as she packs your bag.  They have Smackles here too.
A place you can't pass up!  Enjoy.
author: Eric Y.

description: Pretty neat place! I'm kind of obsessed with Chinatown... I know it's not the most popular place in San Francisco, but to me it's kind of magical and hectic and alive, so this was a treat. Unfortunately, we were cash-less and couldn't get the full tour + picture, so my experience -- and, consequently, review -- is fairly limited... BUT it was fun to even just find the alleyway (we kind of stumbled upon it, actually) and then walk up and down a few times until noticing the entrance to the small factory. It's a bit of a tourist trap, surely, but it's also a historic San Francisco landmark (and it smells darn swell)... and there's this interesting plaque right outside the shop, a little bit down, which features a brief historical background of alleyway construction in Chinatown. Quirky and fascinating.
author: G. J.

description: as my friend led me down the alley, I got a little bit scared...especially when she told me to turn right at some shop with metal bars and not much signage.  I walked in... there were some cute elderly people in a line using the machine press making cookies. Great cookies, not overly sweet, good texture to the cookies. Great hidden little gem!
author: J C.

description: I was a little freaked out walking down the alley to get to this place, but ohhh it was nice.  They gave us free samples and we looked at the lady making the cookies by hand.  Then we bought a bag, and the dearest man took my daughters face in his hands, kissed her, and gave her more cookies.
author: Sarah K.

description: For what it is, this place is just cool. Everyone should visit once. You walk in and--bam--you're on the "factory" floor where you'll see the cookie-making process in action. Don't expect to spend much time here--a minute at most to observe the cookie assembly. Do expect to buy something; you'll feel guilty not to. But nothing is more than a few bucks, and you'll have enough cookies to last several months.
author: Patrick G.

description: We love this place.  Fun, delicious and a tradition that we go here when in SF.  Nothing quite like a fresh fresh fortune cookie.  Great machinery too
author: Debbie D.

description: Was in SF for the weekend, thought I'd try to find it. Found the alley and smelled the cookies. The people inside were very nice, I got plenty of free samples and I ended up buying a bag of the multi flavored flat cookies (strawberry, chocolate, and plain) and some almond cookies, total $7. I will have to go here again!
author: JoAnna L.

description: I'm not 100% sure and I'm sure someone will correct me if I'm wrong but this is literally where the fortune cookie was invented. Great stuff, great prices.
author: Erik S.

description: The little man who usher's you in is soooo cute...  He tried to teach us how to fold the cookies when they came hot off the press.... A lot harder then they make it look..... He will also give you a sample of a fresh cookie... we are talking still warm here.....I like to buy a bag of the flat cookies.... And make sure you ask about the x-rated cookies.... Soooo cheesy and fun.... Hand them to friends.... they get really confused!?#@
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Somewhat ironically*, an out-of-towner introduced me to the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie, tucked away on Ross Alley in a spot I'd never have found were it not for this SF-savvy tourist.

In the year or two since, I've been back to the fortune cookie factory a half a dozen times, always with friends who have not yet discovered its charm.  The hot-off-the-press, flat-disk (pre-folding) fortune cookie samples are incredibly delicious, and its practically mandatory that you walk away with a bag of finished cookies.

Last time I was here, my travel companion bought a bag of the X-rated cookies, which turned out to be more laughable than pornal**.

*Did I use that correctly?
**Practically a real word.
author: Hannah J.

description: Loved the cookies here! When my friend pointed me to the direction of an alley, I was skeptical, but then I tried the free samples and I just couldn't get enough. It was so cool watching the lady fold the fortune cookies! Amazing! I definitely need to go back! :)
author: Janet T.

description: Well worth a stop.  The kids thought this place was great.  And the cookies are good, really good.
author: Maria S.

description: It is not very often I come to San Francisco these days but when I do come by to visit relatives, I try to make it a point to stop by this hidden treasure in the heart of Chinatown.  I remember this place quite well as a child where my grandmother used to brought me when I visit my grandparents.  Still to this day, this is by far the best tasting fortune cookies in NorCal, but the my main reason that I frequent this place is to buy a few bags of fortune cookie flats (they are also known as "rejected" cookies that cannot be folded) for snacks while I am at work or watching tv.  On another note, as good as the "flats" are, my favorite is the mini fortune cookie chips as they have more flavor than the "flats" but then again, you are paying a little more for the "mini" bags.
author: Ang C.

description: Make sure to bring your out-of-towner friends over here to this historic site. It can be hard to find so make sure you know where you are going first to avoid looking like a dick. This is the place that invented fortune cookies and they are still going at it. The offer several different alternatives for satisfying your fortune cookie fix but I suggest going for the flat ones. They are so so good damnit. The bags I buy never tend to last more than a day or so in company. Getting the handful of warm cookies is the best. Great for gifts.
author: Sven S.

description: Super fresh and crispy! They'll give you some to sample and more free cookies when you purchase something.
author: Benjamin G.

description: Chances are the cookies that come with your takeout order from the neighborhood chop suey joint were made here. Unfortunately, what you'll find inside them these days are not so much a fortune as they are a psychiatric observation (Your weak nature allows others to abuse you emotionally), along with a series of lucky numbers that never win Lotto.
author: Gourmet G.

description: Didnt really receive great service there but well, therir fortune cookies are great and fresh! Only $4.50 for a bag of mixed chocolate and regular for your sheer enjoyment over tea break is worthwhile. USe the lil numbers on the back of your slips to buy lottery and see how lucky you really are! :D
author: Topazskye L.

description: This place is definitely worth a visit.  Be brave and try the salty cookies.  Also, took a bag home and they were fresh after opening for over a month.  It was a nice gift for the office.
author: Nicole S.

description:
I have been to SF's Chinatown on countless occasions since it is near the Immigration Court.  Yesterday, however, was the first time I had visited Golden Gate Fortune Cookies because I rarely get around to actual tourism in the City.

The ladies here were very used to having their pictures taken and I was even able to get a small video.  The cookies were good for fortune cookies although cleanliness isn't this establishment's forte.  All in all, it is a must not miss in ChinaTown.
author: M R.

description:
What a BAD ATTITUDE! I called up this place to order some fortune cookies. A man who obviously didn't speak English eaked out the words "Washington and Jackson" then hung up despite my trying to ask for someone who speaks English. I immediately called back and the same person answered the phone again. I tried to ask him in my broken Chinese for someone who spoke English; another man who spoke broken and just barely understandable English was put on the phone.

The man asked me what I wanted. I asked for a price on 100 individually wrapped fortune cookies. He quoted me $22. I asked for the price if I ordered 200. He said it's still 22/100. I asked the price for 300. He then went into an ANGRY RANT on how his "costs have doubled", sarcastically asking "how much do you want to pay?", "do I want them for free?". I then figuratively stepped back and told him that I don't understand what he is trying to say. He YELLED, "I don't care if you order 300, 1000, or 10,000, it's still the same price!" Then he hung up on me.

Also, what kind of BAD ATTITUDE place charges 50 cents to take a picture of the business. (There is a sign that states that as you look in from the street.) Clearly this is a MONEY HUNGRY BAD ATTITUDE PERSON that just is bent on his bottom line and unfortunately doesn't give the slightest care for any kind of proper business demeanor.

He gives Chinese people a bad name and perpetuates an unfortunate stereotype and I take offense as a Chinese American.
