We went to deal with Fornia Fortune Cookies in Oakland where we dealt with an extremely nice owner named David who not only sold us cookies at a cheaper price than Golden Gate, but he stayed open late for us as well. His cookies are delicious too. Please see my review on Fornia.

Incidentally, I asked my friend to call up and speak in her native Chinese to them asking for a price quote, and a woman quoted her $20/100. What a piece of work!
author: A S.

description:
I've been here three times now and I get a different experience every time.  The first time, it was all new and fun and cute, etc.  We bought flat cookies and they were delicious. They cut us a deal where we bought several bags and ended up getting one free or something like that, I think it was 4 bags for 10 dollars. I went again about a year later with my friend from out of town, and we got 2 bags for 5 dollars (I think they're normally 3 each).  I was joking about how they must give an "Asian Discount," which seemed to be the case.  

This past weekend, I went with some real Chinese speakers and the store quoted me $3 for the bag, the white people price!  I asked our native speaker to bargain for two for $5, but she was refused.  I was digging around in my wallet to try and get exactly five dollars to bargain with, but ended up only having 1 dollar bill and 5 quarters plus a bunch of dimes, nickels and pennies.  As my wife and I started fiddling around with the change, the store owner said something in Chinese to our companions, then asked us, "where are you from?"  My wife responded, "Berkeley!"  He looked perplexed and said, "you're... local?"  At this point, my wife and I finished counting out the change, enough to buy one bag.  Yum!  I asked our friend what the owner had said in Chinese: "are they foreigners?  they don't seem familiar with the money."  Shocked, I yelled out, "They're calling _US_ fobs?!"  The shame tingled in my cheeks for the rest of the afternoon.
author: Forrest Y.

description: This gem of a place is just one example why it pays to explore all the alleys in SF Chinatown.  GG Bakery is cool step back in time where all your out of town visitors will love the sight of old-fashioned fortune cookie making.  On a Saturday afternoon, you'll also be treated to an extra musical canvas, courtesy of the neighboring barber who happens to be a righteous violin virtuoso too.
author: Alfonso E.

description: Definitely something to pass by if you are a tourist. You get to watch one of the local ladies in chinatown mold a piping hot fortune cookie. The place even comes with samples for u to try! ^.^
author: Jason C. J.

description: There is barely three square feet to stand in this tiny operation but I do recommend stopping by if you are ever in Chinatown.  The smell is fantastic.  They do ask you to pay $0.50 if you want to take a picture but you can buy fresh cookies on the cheap.
author: Ruby F.

description: I Love this place. My aunt has been taking us here for years. I love how they give you samples when you get in...flat, warm, FRESH fortune cookies are the greatest! They even have some with x-rated fortunes! Prices are pretty good too, $3 a bag.
author: Trina A.

description:
i didn't really know about this place until a couple years ago...
it's a small place much like a sweatshop where they crank out those fortune cookies...
you have to pay them if you want to take a picture.
you can buy fortune cookies in a variety of sized packages... even 'adult' fortune cookies.....
author: charlotte s.

description: I love walking down the alley to this place. . .seems so mysterious! And then there it is - tiny, and lots of cookies for cheap! It is so cute they ask you to pay for pictures (I can't blame them one bit though). Visitors always love this place!
author: Sarcastic T.

description: A hole in the wall place but the goods are delicious. The egg custards or "tan thans" were the best I have ever eaten.  I would return here again and again.
author: addoo d.

description: Finally made my stop here and checked this place out. There was no street sign since I was always looking out for Ross Alley but  I was passing the alley on Jackson Street and noticed a bunch of tourists hovering outside and I figured it was probably an interesting joint. Bought my pack of fortune cookies and watching the ladies fold the fortune into the cookies delicately. A dying art I would say, since there is probably a mass production of this in other places.
author: Yan M.

description: i love hole in the walls.. i remember randomly walking by this place years ago.. and i had to come back again.. which i did recently.. and the fortune cookies are still crispy and delicious.. props to the ladies who hand out free cookies..
author: Stan L.

description: This place is like Fortune Cookie Museum...kind of like when you go inside Krispy Cream and you see how their doughnuts are made...that is the same concept with the fortune cookies made here.
author: Prescott T.

description: Tasty cookies, neat place to stop on a Chinatown tour.
author: Rachel B.

description: A party planners secret weapon: Bring cutouts of your own sayings or anything typed on small strips of paper and they'll stuff them into fresh baked fortune cookies for you.  They're great favors for parties or special events and the price is incredibly cheap.  No need to plan ahead, they can do it the same day and right in front of you depending on how many you want.
author: Diana M.

description: I brought my 12yo niece here for a taste of SF. The place is tiny and we saw two women working on cookie-making machines, two girls packaging cookies, and two men doing administrative tasks. We tasted chocolate and regular flavor cookies and bought a huge bag for $4.50 to go. We were also given a big handful for free. The women working the machines have a sign saying "50 cents for a photo" and they are probably serious. Overall, a nice and very interesting experience that did not take a lot of time. I combined this with a tour of Chinatown.
author: Marina N.

description: Awesome, this place looks like it has not changed since 1962.  Very small with the owner handing out samples.  you can also order custom cookies.
author: Robert M.

description: Glad I went - but the tape on the women's fingers grossed me out.  I can only imagine how many blisters she must have from peeling the hot cookies off of the irons.  But, despite the sweat shop feel it was super cool to see how they are made.
author: Ranger G.

description:
This place can get really small and crowded, but provides an interesting learning experience.  I had no idea making fortune cookies was still such a manual task.  The workers were wearing (non heatproof) latex gloves and literally pulling the cooked batter off from the griddle and shaping them.  

The owner was sort of bossy and stingy with samples.  She was offering only the regular-flavored fortune cookies (who doesn't know what this tastes like??), and was refusing to give people samples of the chocolate, unless you ask in Chinese.  So don't expect to be able to try all sorts of novelties, as earlier reviews may suggest.  Times must be hard....
author: Ana L.

description: Holy crap, I can't believe I found this place!  Neat spot to check out when you're in Chinatown.  I recommend picking up a bag of the "naughty" cookies.  They'll have you cracking up.
author: Megan A.

description: Fortune cookies are delicious!  Free samples, but be sure to try the hot ones.  Yum!  The fortune cookie oven is quite amazing to see...
author: Vinnie P.

description: I never thought I could love a fortune cookie.  My sister brought us a bag when she vacationed in SF, and my kids and I ate the whole bag in two days.  They're light and crispy with a slight sesame flavor.
author: Sherry D.

description: A must on tourist  visit  to SF's Chinatown. Ross Alley is not the most glam of side streets... Okay it is a little dirty and scary looking especially as it starts to get dark out. But do not fear! It is perfectly safe. When you reach the fortune cookie factory it is this tiny hole in the wall with a few ladies making the cookies by HAND on these extremely hot and small machines. Fascinating to watch. You can also eat their broken/mess up cookies for free sometimes as samples. The best part is that they have usual fortune cookies for sale. You can buy chocolate fortune cookies, half choc half regular, and ones with naughty fortunes. Also if you are getting married or have a special occasion, you can talk to them about making custom cookies.  It is worth checking out, even for a few minutes as it is a part of the local flavor. Cash Only! And down the alley jtle further is a training place for a troupe of Dragon Dancers- Check that out too if you can...
author: Ella V.

description: Eversince I was into Chinese food and culture, I always have and always will love comming to this hidden gem in Ross Allie.  The owner, Franklin Yee and his staff are very nice, letting you watch the fastest hands in the west as another yelper said crank out fresh, excellent tasting fortune cookies the old fashioned way.  I love the aroma of fresh, hot dough that beckens you into the shop.  I love all of the flat duds that did not make it as they give you quite a few while you are there.  There are plenty of large bags of cookies for purchase; they all have some great fortunes.  Just be forwarned that they charge you for pictures (I think 50 cents. each.)  So, for excellent fortune cookies, a cheery staff, and an eyeopening experience, the Golden Gate Fortune Cookies Company cannot be beat.  Keep up the good work guys.!
author: Brian S.

description: this place makes the best and freshest fortune cookies. the staff is super nice and give you lots of free samples that are warm bc they were just made. a big bag of cookies is 3.50 which is a great deal for such yummy fresh cookies.
author: chloe w.

description: Very nice place. The staff is extremely pleasant and nothing compares with their fresh fortune cookies. The chocolate ones are to die for, and you can choose from either the traditional fortune cookie or the plain flat ones. And if you every wanted to see how they put in the fortunes, they have an ongoing presentation. Definitely worth the short walk off the main drag of just half-a-block.
author: merle s.

description: mm fortune cookies.. i been going to this place ever since i was a little girl because my grandmother knows the ladies that work there. they always are super friendly and would give lots of free samples. its pretty cool seeing them fold the cookies because they do it so quick. its a definite stop for anyone whos ever been interested in how fortune cookies are made=)
author: christy w.

description: chinglish gets you a long way here! i'm american born chinese but i know a little bit of cantonese. they love it! when i was graduating from highschool i had customized fortune cookies made here. i printed and cut my own little fortunes and had them put the papers inside the cookies. i said something that translated to "can  you put these things inside those things?" their response...."no pob-bem!" chinese people are awesome!
author: Regina C.
